   (C)   An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action
appealed from, unless the zoning administration certifies to the board, after
the notice of appeal has been filed with it, that by reason of the facts stated
in the certificate a stay would, in its opinion, cause imminent peril to life
or property. In such cases, proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by
order of the board and on due cause shown.
   (D)   The board shall fix a reasonable time for hearing of appeals, give
public notices and due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same
within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing any party may appear in person or by
agent or by attorney.
   (E)   The board may, in conformity with the provisions of this chapter,
reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or modify, the order, requirement,
decision, or determination appealed from, and may make such order, requirement,
decision, or determination as ought to be made, and to that end shall have all
the powers of the zoning administration. (Ord. 54, 5-26-1953; amd. Ord. 2964,
4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-8-6: JUDICIAL REVIEW:
   (A)   Any person, including the department of aeronautics, on behalf of and
in the name of the state, aggrieved by any decision of the board of appeals, or
any governing body of a political subdivision which is of the opinion that a
decision of the board of appeals is erroneous, after first exhausting the
remedies provided by the board, may present to the circuit court of the county,
a verified petition setting forth that the decision is erroneous, in whole or
in part, and specifying the grounds of that error. Such petition shall be
presented to the court within thirty (30) days after the decision is filed in
the office of the board. Any judicial review sought by the department of
aeronautics, on behalf of and in the name of the state under this section,
shall be without prejudice to action by the department under section 16 of the
airport zoning act.
   (B)   Anything in the airport zoning regulations to the contrary
notwithstanding judicial review proceedings under this chapter shall be
governed by the "administrative review act" of the state.
   (C)   Upon presentation of the petition hereinbefore mentioned, the court
may allow a writ of certiorari directed to the board of appeals to review such
decision of the board. The allowance of the writ shall not stay proceedings
upon the decision appealed from, but the court may, on application, on notice
to the board, and on due cause shown, grant a supersedeas order.
   (D)   The board of appeals shall not be required to return the original
papers acted upon by it, but it shall be sufficient to return certified or
sworn copies thereof, or of such portions thereof as may be called for by the
writ. The return shall concisely set forth such other facts as may be pertinent
and material to show the grounds of the decision appealed from and shall be
verified.
   (E)   The court shall have exclusive jurisdiction to affirm, modify, or set
aside the decision brought up for review, in whole or in part, and if need be,
to order further proceedings by the board of appeals. The findings of fact of
the board, if supported by substantial evidence, shall be presumed to be
correct, and no objection to a decision of the board shall be considered by the
court unless objection shall have been urged, unless there were reasonable
grounds for failure to do so.
   (F)   Costs shall not be allowed against the board, unless it appears to the
court that it acted with gross negligence, in bad faith, or with malice, in
making the decision appealed from.
   (G)   In any case where these regulations, although generally reasonable,
are held by a court to interfere with the use of enjoyment of a particular
structure or parcel of land to such an extent, or to be so onerous in their
application to such structure or parcel of land as to constitute a taking or
deprivation of that property in violation of the constitution of this state or
the constitution of the United States, such holding shall not affect the
application of such regulations to other structures and parcels of land 1 .
(Ord. 54, 5-26-1953; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 620 ILCS 25/27.
CHAPTER 9
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2-9-1: Establishment Of Board
2-9-2: Appointment; Terms Of Office
2-9-3: Secretary; Duties
2-9-1: ESTABLISHMENT OF BOARD:
At a special election on April 17, 1951, the voters of the city approved the
adoption of the provisions of an act, entitled, "an act to provide for the
appointment of a board of fire and police commissioners in all cities, villages
and incorporated towns of this state", as amended and which prescribes the
powers and duties of the board 1 . (1963 Code; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff.
5-4-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/10-2-1 et seq.
2-9-2: APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners appointed by
the mayor with the consent of the council. Said board shall consist of three
(3) members, whose terms of office shall be: one for one year, one for two (2)
years, and one for three (3) years. Each commissioner hereafter appointed shall
serve a term of three (3) years and until their respective successors are
appointed and qualified. (1963 Code; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-9-3: SECRETARY; DUTIES:
The board may employ a secretary, or may designate one of its own members to
act as such. The secretary shall keep minutes of the board's proceedings, be
the custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, keep a
record of all examinations held, and shall perform all other duties the board
prescribes. (1963 Code; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
CHAPTER 10
VETERANS' MEMORIAL COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-10-1: Creation Of Commission
2-10-2: Term Of Office
2-10-3: Duties
2-10-4: Budget; Salary
2-10-1: CREATION OF COMMISSION:
The Dixon veterans' memorial commission consisting of no less than ten (10)
members and no greater than sixteen (16) members shall be and the same is
hereby created. (Ord. 2357, 11-5-2001; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-
2015; Ord. 3219, 12-7-2020)
2-10-2: TERM OF OFFICE:
The members of the Dixon veterans' memorial commission shall be appointed by
the mayor and shall serve with the consent of the council for two (2) year
terms. The term of office of the initial appointment shall be at least five (5)
members for one year and at least five (5) members for two (2) years. The
chairman of the commission shall be elected from and by the commission members
for a term of one (1) year. The commission shall have the power to establish
bylaws and rules and shall have the authority to elect or appoint such other
officers as the commission deems necessary; but the chairman of the commission
or any other officer appointed or elected by the commission may be removed at
any time by majority vote of the duly appointed members of the commission.
(Ord. 2357, 11-5-2001; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015; Ord. 3219, 12-
7-2020)
2-10-3: DUTIES:
The commission shall make recommendations to the city council regarding the
acquisition of a veterans' memorial site, the design and development of the
site and the maintenance of said site. The Dixon veterans' memorial commission
shall meet at such times and in such places as the commission determines is
necessary. (Ord. 2357, 11-5-2001; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-10-4: BUDGET; SALARY:
The commission shall operate under such budget, if any, as may from time to
time be established by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city, but no
expenditures shall be made, including employees' salary, without the prior
approval of the city council. All expenditures shall be made in accordance with
this code and the Illinois municipal code. (Ord. 2357, 11-5-2001; amd. Ord.
2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)

CHAPTER 12
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANY BOARD
SECTION:
2-12-1: Compliance
2-12-2: Fee
2-12-3: Reports
2-12-4: Recovery, Effect On Policies
2-12-5: Companies In Default
2-12-6: Creation Of Foreign Fire Insurance Board
2-12-7: Officers Of Foreign Fire Insurance Board
2-12-8: Deposit Of Receipts
2-12-9: Rules And Regulations
2-12-10: Treasurer Bond
2-12-11: Disbursement Of Funds
2-12-12: Limitation On Debt And Expenditures
2-12-13: General Legal Requirements
2-12-14: Fund Records; Meeting Minutes
2-12-1: COMPLIANCE:
It shall be unlawful for any corporation or association, not incorporated under
the laws of the state of Illinois, to engage in effecting fire insurance, or to
transact any business of fire insurance in the city while not in full
compliance with all of the requirements of this chapter; however, this
provision shall not relieve any company, corporation or association from the
payment of any risk that may be undertaken in violation of this chapter. (Ord.
2649, 7-16-2007; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-2: FEE:
Any corporation, company or association not incorporated under the laws of the
state of Illinois, which is engaged in the city in effecting fire insurance,
shall pay to the city treasurer for the maintenance, use and benefit of the
fire department of the city, a sum of money equal in an amount to two percent
(2%) per annum of the gross receipts received for premiums by any and all
agents of any such corporation, company or association during the year ending
on every July 1 for any insurance effected or agreed to be effected in the city
by or with any such corporation, company or association during such year. (Ord.
2649, 7-16-2007; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-3: REPORTS:
Every corporation, company or association doing business in the city, or any
person acting as agent for or on behalf of any such corporation, company or
association, shall, on or before July 15 of each year, render to the city
treasurer, a full, true and just account, verified by the oath of the secretary
or treasurer of such corporation, company or association or verified by the
oath of such person acting as agent for or on behalf of any such corporation,
company or association. Every such corporation, company or association or any
such person acting as agent as aforesaid, shall also at the time of rendering
the report, pay to the city treasurer the sum of money for which such
corporation, company or association is chargeable, by virtue of the provisions
of this chapter. (Ord. 2649, 7-16-2007; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-
2015)
2-12-4: RECOVERY, EFFECT ON POLICIES:
The sum of money for which such corporation, company or association is so
chargeable, may be recovered of it, or its agent or agents, by an action in the
name of and for the use of the city, as for money had and received. Nothing in
this section shall be held to exempt any person, corporation, company or
association from indictment and conviction under the provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1 et seq. (Ord. 2649, 7-16-2007; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-
20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-5: COMPANIES IN DEFAULT:
No insurance broker or agent in the city shall place any insurance with any
company, association or corporation not incorporated under the laws of the
state of Illinois, which shall be in default for not reporting or making
payment as provided in this chapter. (Ord. 2649, 7-16-2007; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-
20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-6: CREATION OF FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD:
There shall be established a board known as the foreign fire insurance board.
The board shall consist of seven (7) trustees, one of whom shall be the fire
chief who shall hold office by virtue of rank, and six (6) members who shall be
elected at large by the sworn members of the fire department for a term of one
year and until their successors are appointed. (Ord. 2763, 11-2-2009; amd. Ord.
2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-7: OFFICERS OF FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD:
The members of the board shall annually elect officers to serve a one year
term. The officers of the board shall be a chairman and treasurer. (Ord. 2763,
11-2-2009; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-8: DEPOSIT OF RECEIPTS:
The city treasurer shall pay upon receipt the sums received pursuant to 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-10-1 and 5/11-10-2 to the treasurer of the
foreign fire insurance board. The funds so received shall be deposited by the
treasurer into a fund to be known as the foreign fire insurance fund which
shall be managed and administered by the board. (Ord. 2649, 7-16-2007; amd.
Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-9: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The foreign fire insurance board shall be empowered to adopt rules and
regulations for the efficient and effective management of the monies in the
fund. (Ord. 2649, 7-16-2007; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-10: TREASURER BOND:
The treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board shall give a sufficient bond
to the city. The bond shall be approved by the mayor. (Ord. 2649, 7-16-2007;
amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-11: DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS:
All monies disbursed by the foreign fire insurance board shall be approved by
the majority vote of the board for the maintenance, use and benefit of the
department. All checks disbursed by the board shall be signed by the treasurer
and the chairman of the board. All full time members of the fire department
will be given an opportunity to express their views as to how the monies should
be disbursed, but the board shall make all final decisions on disbursements of
monies from the fund. (Ord. 2763, 11-2-2009; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-
4-2015)
2-12-12: LIMITATION ON DEBT AND EXPENDITURES:
Without the express authorization of the city council, the board shall not: a)
incur debt or b) enter into any contract or other agreement for any
expenditures in excess of the unencumbered funds currently on deposit in, and
authorized for expenditure from, the foreign fire insurance fund at the time of
execution of any such contract or agreement. (Ord. 2649, 7-16-2007; amd. Ord.
2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-13: GENERAL LEGAL REQUIREMENTS:
The board shall comply with all applicable provisions of law, including,
without limitation, all auditing, finance, procurement, and purchasing statutes
and regulations, as well as all open meetings and freedom of information
statutes and regulations. (Ord. 2649, 7-16-2007; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015,
eff. 5-4-2015)
2-12-14: FUND RECORDS; MEETING MINUTES:
The board treasurer shall keep accurate and current records of the fund and all
accounts maintained thereunder, including all deposits thereto, withdrawals and
disbursements therefrom, balances therein, and all other regular and customary
financial and accounting information. As part of the annual municipal audit,
the fund shall be audited to verify that the funds have been expended by the
board only for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Dixon fire department.
The board shall have accurate and current minutes kept of all meetings
conducted by the board. (Ord. 2763, 11-2-2009; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff.
5-4-2015)
CHAPTER 13
DIXON RIVERFRONT COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-13-1: Creation Of Commission
2-13-2: Term Of Office
2-13-3: Duties
2-13-4: Budget; Salary
2-13-1: CREATION OF COMMISSION:
The Dixon riverfront commission consisting of ten (10) members shall be and is
hereby created. The mayor shall be an ex officio nonvoting member of the
commission. (Ord. 2759, 10-19-2009; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-13-2: TERM OF OFFICE:
The members of the Dixon riverfront commission shall be appointed by the mayor
and shall serve with the consent of the city council for two (2) year terms.
The number of members may be increased or decreased from time to time by
majority vote of the city council. The mayor, with the consent of the city
council, may remove any member for misconduct or neglect of duty. The members
shall be appointed in March of each year. The commission shall have the power
to establish bylaws and rules and shall have the authority to elect or appoint
such other officers as the commission deems necessary. Any such officer
appointed or elected by the commission may be removed from such office at any
time by majority vote of the duly appointed members of the commission. (Ord.
2759, 10-19-2009; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-13-3: DUTIES:
The commission shall make recommendations to the city council regarding the
riverfront area located between the Abraham Lincoln Bridge (also known as
Galena Avenue Bridge) and Veterans Memorial Bridge (also known as Peoria Avenue
Bridge) commonly known as Heritage Crossing; promote, encourage and foster the
development and expansion of the riverfront of the city of Dixon, Illinois; and
do all things necessary to improve, develop, revitalize, beautify, aid and
expand the riverfront of the city. Said duties shall also include, but not be
limited to, the making of recommendations to the city council with regard to
the use, protection, maintenance, acquisition and control of the riverfront and
the riverfront area commonly known as Heritage Crossing. The Dixon riverfront
commission shall meet at such times and at such places as the commission
determines is necessary. (Ord. 2759, 10-19-2009; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015,
eff. 5-4-2015)
2-13-4: BUDGET; SALARY:
The commission shall operate under such budget, if any, as may from time to
time be established by the annual appropriation ordinance of the city, but no
expenditures shall be made, including employees' salaries, without prior
approval of the city council. All expenditures shall be made in accordance with
this code and the Illinois municipal code. (Ord. 2759, 10-19-2009; amd. Ord.
2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
CHAPTER 14
ANTICRIME TASK FORCE COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-14-1: Creation Of Commission; Purpose
2-14-2: Composition; Appointment Of Members; Term Of Office
2-14-3: Rules And Procedures Of Commission
2-14-4: Funding
2-14-5: Reports
2-14-1: CREATION OF COMMISSION; PURPOSE:
There is hereby created the anticrime task force commission pursuant to
authority granted under section 7 of the anti-crime advisory council act, 20
Illinois Compiled Statutes 3910/0.01 et seq. The commission shall constitute a
local anticrime program under said section 7. The purpose of the commission
shall be to provide funds to local law enforcement agencies for activities and
programs designed to prevent crimes involving drugs and alcohol. (Ord. 2959, 2-
2-2015; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-14-2: COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; TERM OF OFFICE:
The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, shall appoint the
members of the commission. The commission shall consist of five (5) members. At
least three (3) members shall be senior members of local law enforcement
agencies in Lee County, including the city of Dixon chief of police, the Lee
County sheriff and the Lee County state's attorney or their respective
designees. Each member of the commission shall serve a term of four (4) years
and until his/her respective successor is appointed and qualified. (Ord. 2959,
2-2-2015; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-14-3: RULES AND PROCEDURES OF COMMISSION:
The commission shall adopt such rules and procedures as may be desirable to
carry out the purposes and provisions of this chapter. One member of the
commission shall be designated as chairperson by majority vote of the members
and shall hold office until a successor is designated. The chairperson shall
preside at all meetings of the commission. One member of the commission shall
be designated as secretary by majority vote of the members and shall hold
office until a successor is designated. The secretary shall record the minutes
and proceedings of each meeting of the commission and provide the city clerk
with a copy of the same within thirty (30) days of each meeting. One of the
members of the commission shall be designated as treasurer by majority vote of
the members and shall hold office until a successor is designated. The
treasurer shall collect and keep an accurate record of all financial
transactions and shall arrange with the city's finance director to disburse and
give receipts for all monies handled. The chairperson, the secretary and the
treasurer shall perform such other duties not inconsistent with the purposes of
this chapter as directed by the commission. No member of the commission shall
hold more than one office at the same time. (Ord. 2959, 2-2-2015; amd. Ord.
2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-14-4: FUNDING:
Funding for the commission comes primarily from fines levied against persons
who commit violations of city ordinances and are sentenced to court supervision
pursuant to 730 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-6-3.1, which authorizes such
fines to be contributed to a "local anticrime program", as defined in section 7
of the anti-crime advisory council act. (Ord. 2959, 2-2-2015; amd. Ord. 2964,
4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
2-14-5: REPORTS:
The commission shall submit an annual report to the mayor and city council. The
report shall review the activities of the commission and shall also contain
recommendations for further action to accomplish its purposes. (Ord. 2959, 2-2-
2015; amd. Ord. 2964, 4-20-2015, eff. 5-4-2015)
TITLE 3
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
GRADES
SECTION:
3-1-1: Base Or Datum Plane
3-1-2: Street Grades On Centerline
3-1-3: Slope And Grade Of Sidewalks
3-1-4: Establishing And Changing Grades
3-1-5: Grade Of Sidewalks
3-1-6: Established Grades To Be Used
3-1-1: BASE OR DATUM PLANE:
The base or datum plane to which shall be referred all grades and levels in the
city is hereby fixed as an imaginary horizontal plane one hundred feet (100')
below the northeast corner of the lowest doorstep in front of the B.H. Shaw
Building at the corner of East 1st Street and Ottawa Avenue in the city. (1950
Code)
3-1-2: STREET GRADES ON CENTERLINE:
All grades for streets in the city shall be on the centerline thereof and the
fixed points shall be at the center of the intersection of the streets with
each other or at the points at which, if they were extended, the streets would
intersect or at other points in the centerline of the streets authorized and
definitely located and all grades between established grade points shall be
straight lines drawn from one fixed point to the nearest fixed point thereto.
(1950 Code)
3-1-3: SLOPE AND GRADE OF SIDEWALKS:
All grades of sidewalks, unless otherwise determined by the council, shall at
the outer edge thereof, be at least six inches (6") above the grade of the
streets on which the sidewalks are located and the sidewalks shall slope toward
the street with pitch of one inch (1") in every four feet (4') except as
otherwise provided by ordinance. (1950 Code)
3-1-4: ESTABLISHING AND CHANGING GRADES:
The establishment of any grade by the council shall fix and determine the
permanent grade for the street for which it was designated, but such
establishment of such grade shall not be construed to authorize any person to
change or alter the existing grades or conditions of any street or sidewalk or
any part thereof until ordered altered by the council. (1950 Code)
3-1-5: GRADE OF SIDEWALKS:
All sidewalks, streets and alleys or parts or portions thereof to be built or
constructed in the city, where not provided for by special ordinance, shall be
built and constructed upon a grade to be established by the council upon
request. (1950 Code)
3-1-6: ESTABLISHED GRADES TO BE USED:
No person shall construct any street, alley or sidewalk upon any grade other
than a grade established by ordinance. (1950 Code)
CHAPTER 2
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
3-2-1: Short Title
3-2-2: Definitions
3-2-3: Compliance
3-2-4: Permit Required
3-2-5: Permit Fee
3-2-6: Application Permit; Deposits
3-2-7: Application Permit; Requirements
3-2-8: Franchise Holders
3-2-9: Backfilling
3-2-10: Pavement Replacement
3-2-11: Tunneling Under Streets
3-2-12: Interfering With Access To Vital Equipment
3-2-13: Protect Adjoining Property
3-2-14: Refund Of Deposits; Lien
3-2-15: Violation
3-2-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter may be known and cited as the EXCAVATION CODE OF THE CITY OF
DIXON. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and
their derivations shall have the meanings given herein, when not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the singular number include the plural number, and words in the plural number
include the singular number.
BUILDING OFFICIAL: The person authorized by the council to act in the capacity
of building official; inspector shall be synonymous with building official. The
building official or such person, in public employment, as the building
official may designate as his representative shall be the administrative
authority of this chapter.
EXCAVATION: Any opening in the surface of a public place made in any manner
whatsoever.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any public street, alley, way, place, sidewalk, park, square,
plaza, or any other public property owned or controlled by any governmental
agency in a governmental capacity, excepting here from governmental agencies of
the United States Of America, the state of Illinois, and the county of Lee.
(Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-3: COMPLIANCE:
All excavations made in public places within the city shall be made according
to and in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, unless otherwise
provided by the council for a specific instance. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-4: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person, except a public works superintendent employed by the city, while
acting in his official capacity; or a contractor performing necessary work
under a contract with the city and under supervision and direction of the city,
shall make or cause to be made any excavation in any public place for any
purpose whatsoever without having first obtained a permit therefor signed by
the building official. Permits shall be issued in triplicate by the building
official to applicants only after requirements pertaining to applications and
permits hereinafter set forth shall have been met by the applicants. (Ord.
2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-5: PERMIT FEE:
A fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) shall be collected by the city from each
applicant other than quasi-public utilities for each permit issued. No permit
shall be issued by the building official to any person for any excavation for
any purposes whatsoever unless and until such person has completed an
application for a permit on blanks to be furnished by the building official;
application forms when signed as approved by the building official shall become
and shall be construed as excavation permits. Permits shall be made out in
triplicate, the original and copy marked "For Deposit Return" shall be given
the applicant. Copy marked "File" shall be retained in the building official's
office. Permits issued for sanitary sewer or water connection shall show
diagram of connection on reverse side for permanent record.
Each application for an excavation permit shall be subject to such conditions
and requirements as are herein and hereinafter set forth. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-6: APPLICATION PERMIT; DEPOSITS:
Each application for an excavation permit shall state the name of the person
desiring to make such excavation, the purpose for which the excavation is to be
made and the person for which the excavation is to be made, the location of the
cut in the street, the house number and street name or lot and block number and
name of addition, and type of street surface to be cut. A two hundred dollar
($200.00) deposit shall be required for all excavations, including, but not
limited to, excavations in concrete pavement or sidewalk, bituminous concrete,
brick pavement or sidewalk, tarvia or gravel street, or a dirt road.
Provided, however, if a person or business entity has been a registered
contractor with the city of Dixon building department for a period in excess of
one year and maintains said registration in accordance with title 7, chapter 1
of this code, said person or business entity may pay a five hundred dollar
($500.00) deposit for multiple openings, not to exceed eight (8) in number at
one time. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-7: APPLICATION PERMIT; REQUIREMENTS:
The application and permit shall state that the person to whom the permit shall
be issued agrees to prosecute the excavation work, and backfilling with the
utmost vigor, with as little delay and inconvenience to the public and the city
as possible, in strict conformity with the provisions of this code, with
provisions of all barricades, flares, lights, signs, and any other safeguards
as are necessary or shall be deemed necessary by the building official; the
person desiring to obtain an excavation permit shall further agree to remove
all surplus materials of whatever nature from the excavation site and restore
the site to as good or better condition than existed before excavation
commenced, to perform all work in conjunction with the particular excavation so
as to comply with all requirements as shall be set forth by this code, to hold
and save harmless and indemnify the city, its agents, officers, and employees
from any liability or responsibilities for damages to any person or property
injured by the performance of any excavation work or by the carelessness or
neglect of the person to whom the permit shall be issued or persons to whom the
permit shall have been issued. All permits issued pursuant to this chapter
shall expire ninety (90) days after date of issuance. Upon request, the
building official may grant an extension at the time of issuance for jobs which
would require additional time. No extension shall be permitted to extend beyond
three hundred sixty five (365) days from the date issued. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-8: FRANCHISE HOLDERS:
   (A)   No permit shall be issued to any person or business entity not
registered as a contractor in accordance with title 7, chapter 1 of this code.
   (B)   Utilities having a current franchise agreement with the city of Dixon
shall notify the building department in writing prior to the commencement of
construction of any street opening. In case of an emergency, notification may
be provided after the completion of the work, but in no instance later than ten
(10) days after the work has commenced. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-9: BACKFILLING:
All trenches and excavations shall be backfilled to the natural line or
finished surface as rapidly as the condition of the utility will permit or
within thirty (30) days of the date the permit is issued, whichever is sooner.
The backfill material shall consist of the excavated material or of trench
backfill, as herein specified. All backfill material shall be deposited in the
trench or excavation in such a manner as not to damage the utility. The filling
of the trench shall be carried on simultaneously on both sides of the pipe in
such a manner that injurious side pressures do not occur. The backfill for
trenches and excavations made in the subgrade and for all trenches outside of
the subgrade where the inner edge of the trench is within two feet (2') of the
edge of the pavement, curb, or gutter, shall be made with trench backfill
material unless the excavated material meets the requirements of the city.
All backfill material up to the height of twelve inches (12") above the pipe
shall be carefully deposited in uniform layers not exceeding four inches (4")
thick (loose measure). The material in each layer shall be firmly compacted by
ramming or tamping with tools approved by the city, in such a manner as not to
disturb or injure the pipe. The backfilling above this height, except trench
backfill or excavated material meeting the requirements of state highway
backfill material, shall be done by one of the following methods:
Method 1: The material shall be deposited in uniform layers not exceeding
twelve inches (12") thick (loose material), and each layer shall be compacted
by ramming or tamping with tools approved by the city.
Method 2: The material shall be deposited in uniform layers not exceeding
twelve inches (12") thick (loose measure), and each layer shall be either
inundated or deposited in water.
Method 3: The trench shall be backfilled with loose material, and settlement
secured by introducing water through holes jetted into the backfill to a point
approximately two feet (2') above the top of the pipe. The holes shall be
spaced as directed by the inspector but shall be no farther than six feet (6')
apart.
The water shall be injected at a pressure just sufficient to sink the holes at
a moderate rate of speed. The pressure shall be such that the water will not
cut cavities in the backfill material nor overflow the surface. If water does
overflow the surface, it shall be drained into the jetted holes by means of
shallow trenches. Water shall be injected as long as it will be absorbed by the
backfill material and until samples taken from test holes in the trench show an
approved moisture content. The contractor shall bore the test holes not more
than fifty feet (50') apart and at such other locations in the trench as
designated by the engineer. As soon as the water soaking has been completed,
all the holes shall be filled with soil and compacted by ramming with a tool
approved by the inspector.
Backfill material which has been water soaked shall be allowed to settle and
dry for at least ten (10) days before any surface course or pavement is
construed on it. The length of time may be altered if deemed necessary by the
inspector. Where the inner edge of the trench is within two feet (2') of the
edge of the pavement, curb, gutter or curb and gutter, the provisions of this
paragraph shall apply also.
At the end of the settling and drying period, the crusted top of the backfill
material shall be scarified, and, if necessary, sufficient backfill material
added, as specified in method 1 of this section, to complete the backfilling
operations.
Trench backfill material or excavated material meeting city requirements and
above the first twelve inches (12") above the pipe, shall be compacted by
either method 2 or method 3 of this section.
The method used for backfilling and compacting the backfill material shall be
at the discretion of the contractor. However, if the method used by the
contractor does not produce results satisfactory to the building inspector, the
contractor shall be required to alter or change the method being used to a
method approved by the building inspector.
When sheeting and bracing have been used, sufficient bracing shall be left
across the trench as the backfilling progresses to hold the sides as firmly in
place as practicable. Any depressions which may develop within the area
involved in the construction operation due to settlement of the backfilling
material shall be filled in a manner meeting the approval of the engineer.
(Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-10: PAVEMENT REPLACEMENT:
The existing pavement shall be removed for a width of one foot (1') along each
side of the trench.
If the existing surface is either concrete or brick, the trench backfill
material shall be placed to a depth of eight inches (8") below the finished
surface elevation. The surface shall then be replaced by pouring and finishing
an eight inch (8") concrete slab of class SI concrete to meet the existing
surface.
If the existing surface is bituminous concrete over aggregate, the trench
backfill shall be placed to a depth of ten inches (10") below the finished
surface elevation. An eight inch (8") concrete slab of class SI concrete shall
then be placed to a depth of two inches (2") below the existing surface and a
bituminous concrete surface (B-5 or I-11) shall be placed and thoroughly
compacted to meet the existing surface.
Cold patch material or concrete with a double layer of five (5) mil poly
(minimum) separation may be used to surface the trench only as a temporary
measure when hot mix material is not available. Within thirty (30) days of hot
mix material being available, the cold patch or concrete shall be removed and
replaced by hot mix.
If the existing surface is bituminous concrete over brick or concrete, the
trench backfill shall be placed to a depth of ten inches (10") below the
existing surface. An eight inch (8") concrete slab of class SI concrete shall
then be placed to a depth of two inches (2") below the existing surface. A two
inch (2") hot mix surface shall then be placed and compacted over the concrete
slab after it has been cured and primed.
Cold patch material or concrete with a double layer of five (5) mil poly
(minimum) separation may be used to surface the trench only as a temporary
surface until hot mix material is available. Within thirty (30) days of hot mix
material being available, the cold patch or concrete shall be removed and
replaced by hot mix.
When the existing surface is gravel or crushed stone, the trench backfill
material shall be placed to a depth of eight inches (8") below the existing
surface. Eight inches (8") of crushed stone surface course shall then be placed
and compacted to meet the existing surface. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-11: TUNNELING UNDER STREETS:
No person shall be permitted to tunnel under any street, alley, sidewalk, road,
pavement or public place unless authorized by the city. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-12: INTERFERING WITH ACCESS TO VITAL EQUIPMENT:
Excavation work done by any person shall be performed and conducted so as not
to interfere with access to fire hydrants, fire stations, fire escapes, water
gates, hospitals and any other vital equipment designated by the city. (Ord.
2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-13: PROTECT ADJOINING PROPERTY:
Any person making an excavation shall at all times and at his own expense
preserve and protect from damage or injury all adjoining property by providing
proper sheeting, bracing, shoring, and drainage. The person making the
excavation shall be solely responsible for all damage to public or private
property resulting from or occasioned by the excavation. On all excavations in
any public place in the city the person making the excavation shall provide at
his own expense such barriers, barricades, fences, lights, flares, torches,
sign and warning devices as the building official shall require for safety and
for convenience of any or all the general public. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-14: REFUND OF DEPOSITS; LIEN:
   (A)   Deposits shall be kept separate from the other city funds. After the
person to whom the permit has been issued has completed all requirements as set
forth in this code, said person shall return the permit copy marked "For
Deposit Return" to the building official. The building official shall inspect
said excavation site and if all code requirements have been met to his
satisfaction, the building official shall sign said copy and forward it to the
city treasurer who shall refund the amount deposited for the specific
excavation.
   (B)   A deposit for multiple openings shall be retained by the city building
department until a request for refund is made by the contractor. Upon
completion and approval of all work performed under all open permits issued to
the contractor, the building official shall authorize the city treasurer to
refund the deposit.
   (C)   If within thirty (30) days of the date the permit was issued or on
such date otherwise specified in the permit, the person to whom the permit was
issued has not restored the street, alley, sidewalk, pavement or public place
to as good a condition as prior to the opening as determined by the building
official or his designee, the deposit shall be used by the city to restore the
excavated area to as good a condition and such portion, if any, of the deposit
not expended to complete the restoration shall be refunded to the depositor.
Any costs incurred by the city in excess of the deposit shall be reimbursed to
the city by the applicant within thirty (30) days of the date the city requests
reimbursement for payment of the costs incurred in excess of the deposit.
   (D)   Such cost, if not paid within said thirty (30) days, shall be a lien
upon the real estate affected if, within sixty (60) days thereafter, the city
or the person performing the repair work files notice of lien in the office of
the recorder of deeds. Such notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting
out: 1) a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof,
2) the amount of money incurred or payable for the repair work, 3) the date, or
dates, when such costs and expense were incurred. The person to whom the tax
bill was sent for the general taxes on the property for the last preceding year
shall be served a copy of the notice of lien; service shall be made personally
or by certified mail.
   (E)   Upon payment of the cost and expense after notice of lien has been
filed, the city or person in whose name the lien has been filed shall provide a
release of lien. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
3-2-15: VIOLATION:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter or failing or neglecting to
comply with any requirements shall be deemed guilty of a separate misdemeanor
for each and every day during any part of which such violation or noncompliance
occurs. Any person who violates any provisions of this chapter may further be
refused any permits until he shall have complied with the provisions of this
chapter. Any incidence of violation of this chapter shall be cause for the
building official to immediately revoke or suspend an excavation permit without
prejudice to other action on the violation. (Ord. 2781, 5-3-2010)
CHAPTER 3
STREET OBSTRUCTIONS
SECTION:
3-3-1: Encroachments Prohibited
3-3-2: Building Material (Rep. 2020 Code)
3-3-3: Removal Of Obstructions
3-3-4: Throwing Ashes, Debris, And Yard Waste
3-3-5: Snow Or Water On Sidewalks
3-3-6: Merchandise On Sidewalks
3-3-7: Use For Storage Or Display
3-3-8: Removal Of Tools And Materials
3-3-9: Loading Materials Across Sidewalks (Rep. 2020 Code)
3-3-10: Sidewalk Openings; Specifications; Bond
3-3-11: Reflective Markings On Dumpsters
3-3-1: ENCROACHMENTS PROHIBITED:
No person shall make or cause to be made any enclosure, bay window, building or
structure of any kind upon, over or across any street, alley or sidewalk. (1950
Code)
3-3-2: BUILDING MATERIAL:
(Rep. 2020 Code)
3-3-3: REMOVAL OF OBSTRUCTIONS:
The owner of any building, fence or other structure which extends into or
encroaches upon any street, alley or sidewalk shall remove it. The Director of
Public Works may direct the removal of such obstruction or encroachment at the
expense of the person maintaining, causing or erecting it. (1950 Code; amd.
2020 Code)
3-3-4: THROWING ASHES, DEBRIS, AND YARD WASTE:
No person shall throw, place, or leave, or permit to be thrown, placed, or
left, any ashes, debris (including, but not limited to, dirt, filth, garbage,
solid waste or rubbish), or yard waste (including, but not limited to, grass
clippings, leaves, brush, and tree branches) in or upon any street, alley, or
sidewalk. Notwithstanding the foregoing, it shall not be a violation of this
section if such items are placed curbside in approved bags or containers
pursuant to the city’s solid waste collection and disposal program.
(1950 Code; amd. Ord. 3408, 8-19-2024)
3-3-5: SNOW OR WATER ON SIDEWALKS:
   (A)   No person shall pile, deposit or cause to be piled or deposited or
allow any other entity with which it has contracted, to cause to be piled or
deposited, any snow or ice upon or against a fire hydrant or upon any sidewalk
or upon a public right of way, except for the public right of way immediately
adjacent to the person's property. Further, no person shall pile or cause to be
piled any snow so as to obstruct the vision of any intersection of any street,
avenue, boulevard or alley within the city. (Ord. 1918, 12-18-1995)
   (B)   Every owner and every person in charge or control of any building or
lot of land in any area of the city zoned "B-1 limited neighborhood business
district", or "B-2 general business district", or "CBD central business
district", shall remove and clear away or cause to be removed and cleared away
snow, ice, sleet, or freezing rain from the sidewalks in front or abutting said
lands within twenty four (24) hours after the cessation of any fall of snow,
ice, sleet, or freezing rain. In the event snow, ice, sleet, or freezing rain
on a sidewalk has become so hard that it cannot reasonably be removed, the
owner and/or person in charge or control shall cause enough sand or suitable
abrasive material to be put on the sidewalk to make travel thereon reasonably
safe and shall maintain the sidewalk in such condition until weather permits
the owner to clear the sidewalk. (Ord. 2685, 3-17-2008)
   (C)   Any person found guilty of violating this section, upon conviction
thereof, shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not exceeding
five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and shall be
punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 2565, 1-3-2006)
3-3-6: MERCHANDISE ON SIDEWALKS:
No person, while receiving or delivering goods, wares or merchandise, shall
permit them to remain on any sidewalk longer than two (2) hours, and, for this
purpose, shall occupy only so much of the outer edge of the sidewalk in front
of a building as will leave an unoccupied space of at least four feet (4') in
width of any such sidewalk for the use of pedestrians. (1950 Code)
3-3-7: USE FOR STORAGE OR DISPLAY:
   (A)   Daily storage and display of wares, merchandise and other material
adjacent to a building shall be allowed on streets, sidewalks, alleys, parkways
or public places; providing, such public display and usage does not exceed
thirty six inches (36") on said sidewalk or said public place.
   (B)   On special occasions, permission may be granted by the mayor to ban
automobile traffic from streets, alleys, parkways and public places, and
approval given to use sidewalk areas for display and sale of wares, merchandise
and other material; providing, adequate pedestrian thoroughfares are allowed
and pedestrian safety is maintained. (Ord. 703, 8-7-1972)
3-3-8: REMOVAL OF TOOLS AND MATERIALS:
Whoever constructs, builds or repairs any street, alley or sidewalk shall
remove all materials, tools, appliances or other articles used in or about said
construction, building or repairing within twenty four (24) hours after the
completion of the construction, building or repairing. (1950 Code)
3-3-9: LOADING MATERIALS ACROSS SIDEWALKS:
(Rep. 2020 Code)
3-3-10: SIDEWALK OPENINGS; SPECIFICATIONS; BOND:
Every opening in any sidewalk over any vault or coal hole shall have a metal or
cement cover flush with the walk; the upper surfaces shall be roughened and all
parts of the sidewalks, including illuminating tile or other structural parts,
shall be capable of sustaining a load at all points simultaneously equal to
four hundred (400) pounds for each superficial foot of the surface thereof. The
construction of all vaults and coal holes shall be subject to the supervision
and direction of the commissioner of streets and public improvements or such
other officer as may be designated by the council. All persons who maintain any
vault or coal hole shall execute and file with the clerk a bond to the city in
such a reasonable sum as may be fixed by the mayor, with good and sufficient
sureties to be approved by him, conditioned that the person will pay all
damages that may be recovered against the city by any person on account of any
injuries to person or property occasioned by or in any manner resulting from
the coal holes or openings and to save and keep the city free from all damages
and costs which may be incurred in defending such claims 1 . (1950 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-80-3, 5/11-80-10, 5/11-80-13.
3-3-11: REFLECTIVE MARKINGS ON DUMPSTERS:
   (A)   No contractor, builder or other person shall allow a dumpster to be
parked on a street in the city, unless that dumpster has reflective devices
permanently attached to all four (4) sides of the dumpster.
   (B)   Any person found guilty of violating this section, upon conviction
thereof, shall be fined an amount not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00)
and not exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day such a violation
is committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and
shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord. 1725, 4-5-1993; amd. 2020 Code)
CHAPTER 4
INJURY TO STREETS, SIDEWALKS OR CITY PROPERTY
SECTION:
3-4-1: Protection Of Sidewalks And Curbs
3-4-2: Repair Work; Liability To City
3-4-3: Repairing Injury To Streets And Public Ways
3-4-4: Damage To Uncompleted Work
3-4-5: Liability For Damage
3-4-6: Removal Of Barriers
3-4-7: Injury To Property
3-4-8: Use Of Public Fountain
3-4-9: Penalties
3-4-1: PROTECTION OF SIDEWALKS AND CURBS:
No person shall drive, draw or propel any truck or other heavy vehicle across
any sidewalk or curb without first protecting the sidewalk or curb from injury
by planking or other adequate protection. No persons shall deface, discolor,
mar, or otherwise damage any sidewalk, curb, any other public way or other area
of pedestrian traffic of whatsoever kind or nature within the City. (Ord. 2760,
10-19-2009)
3-4-2: REPAIR WORK; LIABILITY TO CITY:
Any person who shall injure, deface, discolor, mar, or otherwise damage any
street, alley, sidewalk, curb, gutter, or any other public way whatsoever, or
any part thereof, or dig any hole, trench, ditch, drain, or dig or remove any
sod, stone, curb, earth, sand, or gravel from any street, alley, sidewalk,
parkway or other public way of whatsoever kind or nature shall be responsible
and liable to the City for all costs of repair. In addition, any such person
shall indemnify and hold the City harmless from all damages to persons or
property in consequence of such damage for which the City is adjudged liable to
any other person or entity. (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
3-4-3: REPAIRING INJURY TO STREETS AND PUBLIC WAYS:
If any person shall break, deface, discolor, mar, or otherwise damage any
portion of the pavement of any street, sidewalk, or other public way of
whatsoever kind or nature within the City, he or she shall, within twenty four
(24) hours thereafter, cause the same to be restored to as good a condition as
before the damage. For sidewalks subject to repair under this section, said
repair shall be made in such a manner as to make the sidewalk accessible to
persons with disabilities by complying with all relevant rules and regulations
of the Americans With Disabilities Act of 1990, 42 USC section 12101 et seq. In
the event such person does not repair the damaged property to as good a
condition as before the injury, or in the case of a sidewalk, does not make
said sidewalk accessible to persons with disabilities as contemplated herein,
said person shall be liable to the City for any and all costs of repair,
alteration or remediation incurred by the City in repairing said damage. (Ord.
3140, 5-6-2019)
3-4-4: DAMAGE TO UNCOMPLETED WORK:
No person other than the contractor building the same or his employees shall go
upon, either by walking, riding or driving, any cement, concrete, asphalt,
bitulithic or other type of hard surfaced sidewalk, pavement, curb or gutter
being constructed under employment of the City until the sidewalk, pavement,
curb or gutter has been properly cured or hardened and opened for public use.
(Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
3-4-5: LIABILITY FOR DAMAGE:
Any person injuring any such pavement, sidewalk, curb, or gutter before it has
been properly cured or hardened shall be liable to the City or to the
contractor, as the case may be, for all the costs of repairing the damage.
(Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
3-4-6: REMOVAL OF BARRIERS:
Where, in the course of making any walk, pavement, curb or gutter, any barriers
are placed by a contractor or by the City to prevent the use of the uncured
improvements, no person shall remove them 1 . (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-80-10.
3-4-7: INJURY TO PROPERTY:
No person shall wilfully, maliciously, or negligently cut, break, climb on,
carry away, conceal, transfer, tamper with, mark on, or in any way injure,
damage, or deface any tree, shrub, plant, turf, grass, statue, bust, lamppost,
hydrant, regulating device, transformer, meter, wire, wiring, pole, curbstone,
flagstone, fence, wall, bridge, balustrade, railing, bench, building, or other
structure of any kind or property, or take down, alter, mar, move, injure, or
destroy any sign, trailmarker, placard, notice, post, pile, or buoy posted or
placed by the City or authorized to be posted or placed by the City Engineer or
Chief of Police. (Ord. 2829, 7-5-2011)
3-4-8: USE OF PUBLIC FOUNTAIN:
No person shall bathe, wade in the standing water of, wash clothes or items in,
urinate in, defecate in, enter into, or climb on any structure of, nor throw or
otherwise place or cause to be placed any rubbish, waste debris, garbage,
refuse or other trash, or any toxic substance, in the waters or fixtures of the
fountain located at the south end of Hennepin Avenue, known as "Heritage
Crossing". No person shall allow an animal in their custody or control to
commit any of the above acts. (Ord. 2829, 7-5-2011)
3-4-9: PENALTIES:
Notwithstanding and in addition to the foregoing, any person found guilty of a
violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). (Ord. 2760, 10-19-2009; amd. Ord. 2829, 7-5-2011)
CHAPTER 5
NUMBERING OF LOTS
SECTION:
3-5-1: Decimal System Adopted
3-5-2: Size Of Lot Numbered
3-5-3: Dividing Line, North And South
3-5-4: Dividing Line, East And West
3-5-5: Prefix To Names Of Streets
3-5-6: Odd And Even Numbers
3-5-7: Where Numbering Commences
3-5-8: Numbering By Series Of Hundreds
3-5-9: Numbering Between Rock River And First Street
3-5-10: System Applied In North Dixon
3-5-11: Streets East And West From Galena Avenue
3-5-12: Streets Running East And West Not Intersecting Galena Avenue
3-5-13: Numbering Of Houses Required
3-5-14: Street Naming Committee
3-5-15: Name Changes (Rep. 2020 Code)
3-5-1: DECIMAL SYSTEM ADOPTED:
The numbering of all lots, houses, or buildings fronting upon the public
thoroughfares within the city shall be in conformity with the decimal system
and the regulations following. (Ord. 556, 7-25-1967)
3-5-2: SIZE OF LOT NUMBERED:
Every twenty five feet (25') of street frontage, exclusive of streets and
inclusive of alleys, shall, for the purpose of numbering, be deemed a lot and
each lot is hereby provided with a number according to the following plan.
(Ord. 556, 7-25-1967)
3-5-3: DIVIDING LINE, NORTH AND SOUTH:
Rock River shall be the dividing line between Dixon and North Dixon as the same
are hereinafter designated. (Ord. 556, 7-25-1967)
3-5-4: DIVIDING LINE, EAST AND WEST:
Galena Avenue in Dixon and North Galena Avenue in North Dixon shall be the base
or dividing line east and west. (Ord. 556, 7-25-1967)
3-5-5: PREFIX TO NAMES OF STREETS:
That portions of all avenues running north and south of Rock River shall have
the prefix "North" to the names of all streets, or avenues, that lie north of
Rock River and the prefix "South" to the names of all avenues which lie south
of said Rock River; that portions of all streets running east and west and
lying west of Galena Avenue and North Galena Avenue shall have the prefix
"West" to their names and that all portions of such streets lying east of
Galena Avenue and North Galena Avenue shall have prefixed to their names the
word "East". (Ord. 567, 10-3-1967)
3-5-6: ODD AND EVEN NUMBERS:
On streets running north and south the odd numbers shall be on the west side of
the street and the even numbers on the east side of the street; on all streets
running east and west the odd numbers shall be on the north side of the street
and the even numbers on the south side of the street. (1950 Code)
3-5-7: WHERE NUMBERING COMMENCES:
In Dixon the numbering of lots on streets running south and north shall
commence at 1st Street; in North Dixon the numbering of lots on streets running
north and south shall commence at Rock River. (1950 Code)
3-5-8: NUMBERING BY SERIES OF HUNDREDS:
The numbering of said streets and avenues shall be by series of hundreds as
follows: the first twenty five feet (25') in the northeast corner of block
number sixteen in the original town (now city) of Dixon and abutting Galena
Avenue shall be numbered 101 and the lot directly opposite in block number
seventeen and abutting Galena Avenue shall be numbered 102 and said numbering
shall so continue until all lots abutting Galena Avenue in the blocks have been
numbered; the first twenty five feet (25') in the northeast corner of block
number twenty nine in the original town (now city) of Dixon and abutting Galena
Avenue shall be numbered 201 and the first twenty five feet (25') directly
opposite in block number twenty eight shall be numbered 202 and so on the
entire length of Galena Avenue, each new set of blocks commencing with a new
series of hundreds. On all streets and avenues running parallel or in the same
general direction with Galena Avenue the lots shall be numbered to correspond
with the numbering of the corresponding or opposite lots on Galena Avenue.
(1950 Code)
3-5-9: NUMBERING BETWEEN ROCK RIVER AND FIRST STREET:
All lots abutting Galena Avenue and lying between 1st Street and Rock River
shall be numbered by commencing with the first twenty five feet (25') on the
southeast corner of block number five in the original town (now city) of Dixon,
which shall be numbered 99, and the first twenty five feet (25') directly
opposite, being in the southwest corner of block number four in the original
town (now city) of Dixon shall be numbered 98; the next twenty five feet (25')
lying north of and adjoining number 99 in block number five shall be numbered
97, and so on down until all of the lots abutting Galena Avenue in said block
have been numbered. On all streets and avenues running parallel or in the same
general direction with Galena Avenue and lying between 1st Street and Rock
River the lots shall be numbered to correspond with the numbering of the
corresponding or opposite lots on Galena Avenue. (1950 Code)
3-5-10: SYSTEM APPLIED IN NORTH DIXON:
In North Dixon the lot at the northeast corner of North Galena Avenue and Water
Street shall be numbered 102 and the lot at the northwest corner of North
Galena Avenue and Water Street shall be numbered 101. All lots in North Dixon
on streets and avenues running parallel with or in the same general direction
as North Galena Avenue shall have numbers corresponding with the opposite lots
on North Galena Avenue. (1950 Code)
3-5-11: STREETS EAST AND WEST FROM GALENA AVENUE:
Lots on streets running east and west from Galena Avenue and North Galena
Avenue shall be numbered easterly and westerly from said avenue, starting with
numbers 100 and 101 and proceeding in the same manner as is hereinbefore
provided for the numbering of Galena Avenue. (1950 Code)
3-5-12: STREETS RUNNING EAST AND WEST NOT INTERSECTING GALENA AVENUE:
Lots on all streets running east and west that do not intersect with Galena
Avenue or North Galena Avenue shall be numbered to correspond with the lots
directly opposite on parallel streets. (1950 Code)
3-5-13: NUMBERING OF HOUSES REQUIRED:
All owners of houses shall number their houses in conformity with the foregoing
provisions 1 . (1950 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-80-18.
3-5-14: STREET NAMING COMMITTEE:
All developers of subdivisions or annexed territory to the city be and they are
hereby required to submit street names to the council as part of their
presentations of the plats of their subdivisions to the city for its approval.
(Ord. 556, 7-25-1967; amd. 2020 Code)
