Improvement    Gallon $0.00000 $0.00035  $0.00035  $0.00035  $0.00036  $0.00037
Charge
Total Usage    $/     $0.00297 $0.00307  $0.00314  $0.00323  $0.00331  $0.00339
Charge         Gallon
 
         (c)   Sewer Users Outside City Limits: Rates for sewer users outside
the city limits shall be an additional fifteen percent (15%).
      6.   Residential Non-Metered Users: All non-metered single-family
residential users of the wastewater facilities who are not supplied with water
by the city shall pay a charge based on an estimated average consumption of
five thousand nine hundred eighty-four (5,984) gallons per month. In the event
the user of the wastewater facilities is determined by the Manager to be in
excess of five thousand nine hundred eighty-four (5,984) gallons per month, the
Manager may require the user to install metering devices on the water supply or
sewer lateral to measure the amount of service supplied.
      All non-metered single-family residential users of the wastewater
facilities who are located outside the city corporate limits and are not
supplied with water by the city shall pay a charge based on an estimated
average consumption of five thousand nine hundred eighty-four (5,984) gallons
per month. In the event the user of the wastewater facilities is determined by
the Manager to be in excess of five thousand nine hundred eighty-four (5,984)
gallons per month, the Manager may require the user to install metering devices
on the water supply or sewer lateral to measure the amount of service supplied.
      7.   Other Than Residential Non-Metered Users: All non-metered users
other than single-family residential users of the wastewater treatment
facilities who are not supplied with city water shall pay a charge based on an
estimated consumption of thirty eight thousand eight hundred ninety-six
(38,896) gallons per month. In the event the user of the wastewater facilities
is determined by the Manager to be in excess of thirty eight thousand eight
hundred ninety-six (38,896) gallons per month, the Manager may require the user
to install metering devices on the water supply or sewer lateral to measure the
amount of service supplied.
      All non-metered other than single-family residential users of the
wastewater facilities who are located outside the city corporate limits and are
not supplied with water by the city shall pay a charge based on an estimated
average consumption of thirty eight thousand eight hundred ninety-six (38,896)
gallons. In the event the user of the wastewater facilities is determined by
the Manager to be in excess of thirty eight thousand eight hundred ninety-six
(38,896) gallons, the Manager may require the user to install metering devices
on the water supply or sewer lateral to measure the amount of service supplied.
      8.   Surcharge Rates: The unit rates for wastewater surcharge shall be:
         (a)   For biochemical oxygen demand (BOD): Twenty five cents ($0.25)
per pound;
         (b)   For suspended solids (SS): Twenty cents ($0.20) per pound, with
exception to Large Users.
      The unit rates for wastewater surcharge for Large Users shall be:
         (a)   For biochemical oxygen demand (BOD): Fourteen cents ($0.14) per
pound;
         (b)   For suspended solids (SS): Ten cents ($0.10) per pound.
      9.   Computation Of Wastewater Service Charge: The wastewater service
charge shall be computed by the following formula:
   CW = CM + Vu (Cu + CD + CR) + CS
   Where:
 CW = Amount of wastewater service charge in dollars per billing period
 CM = Fixed administrative expenses in dollars per billing period
 Vu = Wastewater volume in gallons per billing period
 Cu = Basic user rate in dollars per gallon
 CD = Debt service rate in dollars per gallon
 CR = Capital improvement charge in dollars per gallon for users located
       outside of the city corporate limits
 CS = Surcharge if applicable, as determined by the following formula:
    CS = Vu (0.00000834) [A (BOD5 - 200) + B (SS - 320)]
    Where:
     CS = Amount of surcharge in dollars per billing period
     Vu = Wastewater volume in gallons per billing period
     0.00000834 = Unit of weight of water x 10-6 per gallon
     A = Unit charge for BOD5 per pound
     BOD5 = 5 day biochemical oxygen demand of wastewater in mg/l
     200 = Allowable average strength in mg/l
     B = Unit charge for suspended solids per pound
     SS = Suspended solids concentration of wastewater in mg/l
     320 = Allowable average suspended solids strength in mg/l
 
      10.   Exceptions To Charge: Provided the residential user complies with
the provisions of this section, the following usages of the wastewater
facilities shall be exempt from the wastewater service charges established in
this chapter:
         (a)   Swimming Pools:
            (1)   Any property owner intending to fill a swimming pool located
on the owner's property may make a request to the city to pay only the water
usage charges incurred in said filling by submitting a written request to city
hall. The request must be submitted prior to the filling of the swimming pool
along with a ten dollar ($10.00) fee. Upon approval of the request by the
Manager, the wastewater service charge shall not be charged for the filling of
said swimming pool, but the property owner shall be charged the normal water
rate in accordance with the provisions of chapter 8 section
3-8-15. The meter shall be read by the water division immediately before
filling the swimming pool and again three (3) days later. Discharging of any
swimming pool water into the city's sanitary sewer system is prohibited.
            (2)   The exemption provided under this subsection (A)10(a) shall
be granted only once per calendar year. Any other water added to a residential
pool shall be charged as provided in this code.
            (3)   Filling of a swimming pool from a metered fire hydrant is
prohibited.
         (b)   Newly Sodded Or Seeded Lawn:
            (1)   The wastewater service charge shall not be charged for the
watering of a newly seeded or sodded lawn only if the owner or the occupant of
the residence notifies the wastewater treatment plant in writing at least five
(5) days prior to the installation of the new seeding or sod.
            (2)   The determination of whether a lawn is newly seeded or sodded
shall be made by and at the sole discretion of the Manager of the wastewater
treatment plant.
            (3)   The exemption granted under this subsection (A)10(b) shall:
               A.   Only apply to lawns where the sod is installed or the seed
is planted either in the entire front yard and/or back yard;
               B.   Not exceed thirty (30) days from the date said lawn is
newly seeded or sodded; and
               C.   Not be applicable to any other watering or outside use.
            (4)   The method of computing the amount of the exempt fee shall be
determined by the Manager of the wastewater treatment plant. Provided, however,
the amount of the wastewater service charge shall first be paid by the owner or
user and the amount of the charge determined to be exempt shall thereafter be
rebated by the city.
      11.   Miscellaneous Wastes Rates; Conditions:
         (a)   The unit rates for miscellaneous wastes shall be: 1) for holding
tank waste: eleven dollars forty-two cents ($11.42) per one thousand (1,000)
gallons; 2) for septage: ten cents ($ 0.10) per one (1) gallons; 3) for
leachate: six cents ($0.06) per one (1) gallon unless established by special
agreement between both parties.
      The unit rates for miscellaneous wastes were established based on typical
strength holding tank waste (600 mg/l BOD and 1,800 mg/l SS) and typical
strength septage (5,000 mg/l BOD and 15,000 mg/l SS). If analytical testing
determines the strength of the holding tank waste or septage to be higher than
the typical values as indicated above, an additional charge may be levied. This
additional charge shall be based upon the unit charges as indicated in
subsection (A)8 of this section, and upon the increased pounds of BOD and/or SS
over and above the typical strengths indicated in this subsection.
         (b)   The city may accept for treatment holding tank wastes, septage
or other miscellaneous wastes subject to the following conditions:
            (1)   Should the city determine that excess capacity exists at the
wastewater treatment plant, and that the conditions of the NPDES permit granted
by the state for operation of the wastewater treatment plant will be met, the
city may accept for treatment septage, holding tank waste or other
miscellaneous wastes.
            (2)   Miscellaneous wastes shall only be accepted by the city if
such wastes are delivered by the hauler to the wastewater treatment plant, and
discharged at a location and under such conditions as approved by the city.
            (3)   All approvals for miscellaneous hauled waste disposal shall
be subject to such conditions as deemed necessary by the city, including the
condition that acceptance of miscellaneous hauled wastes may be restricted or
suspended, should the wastewater treatment plant have operational problems,
maintenance problems, or the threat of NPDES permit violations which are
indirectly or directly related to the acceptance of the miscellaneous hauled
waste.
      12.   Increase In Rates:
         (a)   Each of the rates set forth in subsections (A)5(a), (A)8 and
(A)11(a) of this section shall automatically increase by 2.5% per annum over
the previous year on May 1 of each year commencing May 1, 2026. Each of the
rates set forth in subsection (A)5(b) of this section shall automatically
increase by 2.5% per annum over the previous year on May 1 of each year
commencing May 1, 2028. (Ord. 3110, 9-17-2018; amd. Ord. 3309, 6-6-2022; Ord.
3316, 7-18-2022)
CHAPTER 10
MUNICIPAL BAND
SECTION:
3-10-1: Band Established
3-10-2: Director; Appointment
3-10-3: Director; Term
3-10-4: Compensation
3-10-5: Organization
3-10-6: Purpose, Duties, And Reports
3-10-7: Funds
3-10-1: BAND ESTABLISHED:
The Dixon Municipal Band was established in 1918, and was approved for funding
by levy per the citizens of the city starting in 1931. The Dixon Municipal Band
has served the citizens, and visitors, to the city continuously since then
(except the 2020/2021 season when performances were not viable due to COVID).
The city desires to facilitate the continuation of the mission of the Dixon
Municipal Band as it serves the citizens by delivering free community concerts
and performances within the city each year. (1950 Code; amd. Ord. 3367, 8-7-
2023)
3-10-2: DIRECTOR; APPOINTMENT:
The mayor shall recommend to the council the appointment of a director of the
Dixon Municipal Band, who shall be appointed by a majority vote of the council.
The director shall be a part-time employee of the city. (1950 Code; amd. Ord.
3367, 8-7-2023)
3-10-3: DIRECTOR; TERM:
The director shall hold office until the end of the third (3rd) fiscal year
from the date on which the director is appointed or until a successor is
appointed and approved; provided, that the council may remove the director at
any time for any reason. (1950 Code; amd. Ord. 3367, 8-7-2023)
3-10-4: COMPENSATION:
   (A)   The director shall be paid a monthly salary in such amount as shall be
determined from time to time by the council. As a part-time employee, the
director shall not be eligible for other fringe benefits made available to
full-time employees of the city.
   (B)   Other members of the Dixon Municipal Band shall be considered to be
independent contractors and shall be compensated in amounts as determined from
time to time by the board of the Dixon Municipal Band with the approval of the
council. Any member receiving compensation shall be required to acknowledge in
writing that he or she is an independent contractor and not an employee of the
Dixon Municipal Band or the city. (1950 Code; amd. Ord. 3367, 8-7-2023)
3-10-5: REPORTS:
   (A)   The Dixon Municipal Band shall be organized and managed by a board
comprised of five (5) persons, including the director, two (2) at large
residents of the City, and two (2) active participants of the Dixon Municipal
Band other than the director.
   (B)   The two (2) members of the board who are at large residents of the
city shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the council. One of
the appointed members shall serve for one (1) year or until his or her
successor is appointed, with the initial term beginning on May 1, 2024. The
other appointed member shall serve for two (2) years or until his or her
successor is appointed, with the initial term beginning on May 1, 2024.
Thereafter, all appointed members shall serve two (2) year terms or until their
successors are appointed. Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of
any of the appointed members, his or her successor shall be appointed by the
mayor with the consent of the council for the unexpired term.
   (C)   The two (2) members of the board who are active participants in the
Dixon Municipal Band shall be elected by the active participants of the Dixon
Municipal Band. The term of the elected members shall be two (2) years or until
their successors are elected, with the initial term beginning on May 1, 2024.
The election for such members shall be held biennially in March or April, but
not later than the third (3rd) Monday of April, at such place within the city,
and in such manner, as shall be prescribed by the director and the two (2)
appointed members of the board. The initial election shall be held in 2024.
Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any elected board member,
his or her successor shall be elected for the unexpired term at a special
election to be called by the board and conducted in the same manner as the
regular biennial election.
   (D)   At the first meeting after it is established, and annually thereafter,
the board shall set a regular meeting schedule as it may deem appropriate, but
not less frequently than three (3) times per year.
   (E)   Annually, the members of the board shall select from among its members
a vice-chairperson and secretary, with each selected member serving in their
respective office for a one year term. The director shall serve as chairperson
of the board.
   (F)   Members of the board and the officers thereof shall neither receive
nor have any right to receive any salary for services performed in those
offices. (Ord. 3367, 8-7-2023)
3-10-6: PURPOSE, DUTIES, AND REPORTS:
   (A)   The board shall oversee selection of persons to serve as members of
the Dixon Municipal Band and prepare such rules as may to it deem expedient and
not inconsistent with the best interests of the band and the city and not in
conflict with any of the provisions of this code or any law. Such rules must be
submitted to the council for approval before becoming effective. The board
shall have general supervision of all details pertaining to the Dixon Municipal
Band except as otherwise directed by the council. The board shall appoint or
designate such assistants and positions as may be authorized by the council and
fix their compensation, subject to the approval of the council, and it may, by
and with the consent of the council, remove such appointees.
   (B)   The board shall keep a correct record of its proceedings and provide
copies of same to the council.
   (C)   The board shall oversee the promotion of music through free live band
concerts and furnish equivalent musical service upon occasions of importance,
for the benefit of the citizens of Dixon, all of which shall be as nearly as
possible in conformity with the practice adhered within the city in the past
for holding such band concerts or performances.
   (D)   The board shall communicate with the council to apprise them of the
dates and locations of all concerts or performances to be held throughout the
year. All the dates and locations of concerts or performances by the Dixon
Municipal Band shall be posted on the website maintained by the city and
whenever possible not less than (14) days prior to any concert or performance.
   (E)   The board shall prepare and submit to the council each fiscal year a
copy of its budget for operations of the Dixon Municipal Band showing
anticipated revenues and expenses. The board shall annually, not more than
forty-five (45) days after the end of the fiscal year, make a report to the
council of the actual revenues and expenses of the operations, the condition,
and activities of the Dixon Municipal Band during the preceding fiscal year.
   (F)   The Dixon Municipal Band may accept revenue from sources other than
the city and perform other concerts or performances (in addition to the free
concerts and performances provided for the benefit of the residents of the
city), so long as such additional revenues and expenses are disclosed to the
council by the aforesaid reports. (1950 Code; amd. Ord. 3367, 8-7-2023)
3-10-7: FUNDS:
The council shall have the exclusive control of the expenditures of all monies
collected, levied or donated to the credit of the Dixon Municipal Band fund by
way of annual budget approval. All monies received, either by levy or
otherwise, shall be deposited in the city treasury to the credit of the Dixon
Municipal Band fund and the treasurer or financial director shall keep the
funds separate and apart from other monies of the city. The director (or his/
her designee) shall approve all accounts charged against the Dixon Municipal
Band fund and submit same to the treasurer or financial director before any
payment is made. (1950 Code; amd. Ord. 3367, 8-7-2023)
CHAPTER 11
SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS
SECTION:
3-11-1: Jurisdiction
3-11-2: Approvals; Interpretations; Exceptions
3-11-3: Definitions
3-11-4: Design Standards
3-11-5: Procedure And Requirements
3-11-6: Agreements
3-11-7: Required Land Improvements
3-11-8: Variances And Exceptions
3-11-9: Occupancy Permit
3-11-10: Enforcement
3-11-11: Record Of Plats
3-11-1: JURISDICTION:
Wherever any subdivision of land shall hereafter be laid out within the city or
within contiguous territory and not more than one and one-half (11/2) miles
beyond the incorporated boundary of the city, the subdivider thereof or his
agent shall submit both a preliminary and a final subdivision plan to the city.
The plans, proposed improvements, and all procedures relating thereto, shall in
all respects be in full compliance with the regulations hereinafter contained
in this chapter.
All lands offered to the city for use as streets, highways, alleys, parks and
other public use, shall be referred to the plan commission for review and
recommendation before being accepted by the council or by any other governing
authority. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-2: APPROVALS; INTERPRETATIONS; EXCEPTIONS:
   (A)   No land lying within the corporate limits, after the adoption of these
regulations, shall be subdivided or filed for record, nor any street laid out,
nor any improvements made to the land, until the plan of the subdivision or
plan of the street improvements has been certified to and approved by action of
the council. This approval must be in writing and placed on the original
tracing of the final plans, according to the procedure outlined in section
3-11-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
   (B)   No lot, tract or parcel of land within any subdivision lying within
the corporate limits, shall be offered for sale nor shall any sale, contract
for sale, or option be made or given until such subdivision plans have been
properly reviewed by the plan commission and officially approved by the
council.
   (C)   No improvements, such as sidewalks, water supply, stormwater drainage,
sewerage facilities, gas service, electric service or lighting, or grading,
paving or surfacing the streets, shall hereafter be made within any such
subdivision of the city, by any owner or his agent, or by any public service
corporation at the request of the owner or his agent until the plans for the
subdivision and also the plans for improvements thereto have been formally
recommended by the plan commission and approved by the council.
   (D)   Subdivision of land lying outside of the city and within one and one-
half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits, shall also be required to conform
with the requirements of this chapter, in accordance with the provisions of the
Illinois municipal code. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-3: DEFINITIONS:
ALLEY: A strip of land, not less than twenty feet (20') in width and not more
than forty feet (40') along the side of or in the rear of properties, intended
to provide access to these properties.
BUILDING LINE: A line within a lot or other parcel of land, so designated on
the plat of the proposed subdivision, between which, and the adjacent boundary
of the street upon which the lot abuts, the erection of an enclosed structure
or portion thereof is to be prohibited.
CROSSWALK WAY: A strip of land dedicated to public use, which is reserved
across a block to provide pedestrian access to adjacent areas.
CUL-DE-SAC: A street having one open end and being permanently terminated by a
vehicular turnaround.
EASEMENT: A grant by a property owner for the use of a strip of land by the
general public, a corporation, or a certain person for a specific purpose.
LOT: A portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended for transfer
of ownership or for building development.
MARGINAL ACCESS STREET: A minor street which is parallel to and adjacent to
primary streets and highways, and which provides access to abutting properties
and protection to local traffic from fast through moving traffic on the primary
streets.
MINOR STREET: A street intended primarily as access to abutting properties.
PRIMARY STREET: A principal street which collects traffic from minor and
secondary streets serving large areas, and connecting with state and U.S.
highways or extending to principal points of destination.
PUBLIC STREET: All primary and minor streets which are shown on the subdivision
plat and are to be dedicated for public use.
SECONDARY STREET: A street which collects traffic from minor streets and
connecting with primary streets or state and U.S. highways or extending to
points of destination.
STREET: An area which serves or is intended to serve as a vehicular and
pedestrian access to abutting lands or other streets.
STREET WIDTH: The shortest distance between lines of lots delineating the
public street.
SUBDIVISION: The division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two (2) or
more lots, parcels or other divisions of land, for the purpose, whether
immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or building development,
including all changes in street or lot lines; provided, however, that the
following divisions of land shall be exempted from the definition of
"subdivision":
   (A)   A division of land for agricultural purposes in parcels of more than
five (5) acres not involving any new street or public utility easement or
easement of access; or
   (B)   The transfer of less than ten feet (10') of property in a recorded
subdivision to an adjoining property owner where each lot, tract or parcel,
after said transfer, contains the minimum square footage required under this
code; or
   (C)   The division of a lot, tract or parcel of land of less than one acre
in a recorded subdivision into two (2) or more lots, parcels or other divisions
of land not involving any new streets, public utility easements or easements of
access where each lot, tract, or parcel of land resulting from such
subdivision: 1) contains the minimum square footage required under this code,
and 2) complies in all other respects with the provisions of this code.
Each owner of a lot, tract or parcel of land asserting an exemption under
subsection (B) or (C) of this definition shall file a plat of survey, prepared
by an Illinois registered land surveyor with the city's building official,
showing the resulting lots or tracts and giving the legal descriptions
therefor. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972; amd. Ord. 2093, 6-15-1998)
3-11-4: DESIGN STANDARDS:
   (A)   Street Plan: The subdivision of land, including the arrangement,
character, extent, width, grade and location of all streets, alleys, or other
land to be dedicated for public use, shall conform to the general development
plan of the city as approved and adopted by the council and other responsible
governmental bodies; and shall be considered in their relation to existing and
planned streets, to topographical conditions, to public convenience and safety,
and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of the land to be served
by such streets.
   (B)   Minimum Street Standards:
      1.   All rights of way shall conform to the following minimum dimensions:
         (a)   Primary streets shall conform to the major street plan and in no
instance shall be less than one hundred feet (100').
         (b)   Secondary or collector streets shall be sixty six feet (66').
         (c)   Minor streets shall be sixty feet (60').
         (d)   Cul-de-sac shall be sixty feet (60').
         (e)   Crosswalks shall be ten feet (10').
         (f)   Utility easements shall be ten feet (10').
      2.   Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic
will be discouraged.
      3.   Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty
five feet (125') shall be avoided.
      4.   Clear visibility, measured along the centerline of the street, shall
be provided for at least three hundred feet (300') on all primary streets, two
hundred feet (200') on minor streets, and at least one hundred feet (100') on
all other streets.
      5.   It must be evidenced that all street intersections and confluences
encourage safe traffic flow.
      6.   Alleys are not permitted, except where deemed necessary, and at the
discretion of the plan commission or the council.
      7.   The maximum length cul-de-sac shall be five hundred feet (500')
measured along the centerline from the intersection at origin through center of
circle to end of right of way. Each cul-de-sac shall have a terminus of nearly
circular shape with a minimum diameter of one hundred feet (100').
      8.   Half streets shall be prohibited, except where essential to the
reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other
requirements of these regulations; and where the plan commission or the council
finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other one-half
(1/2) when the adjoining property is subdivided. Wherever a half street is
adjacent to a tract to be subdivided, the other one-half (1/2) of the street
shall be planned within such tract.
      9.   No street names may be used which will duplicate, or be confused
with, the names of existing streets. Existing street names must be projected
wherever possible.
   (C)   Easements:
      1.   Easements across lots or centered on rear or side lot lines shall be
provided for utilities where necessary and shall be at least ten feet (10')
wide.
      2.   Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway,
channel, or stream, there shall be provided a stormwater easement or drainage
right of way conforming substantially with the lines of the watercourse, and
such further width or construction, or both, as will be adequate for the
purpose. Parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith.
(Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
   (D)   Block Standards:
      1.   The maximum lengths of blocks shall be one thousand eight hundred
feet (1,800'). All blocks over eight hundred feet (800') will ordinarily
require crosswalks at the approximate centers. The use of additional crosswalk
ways in any instance to provide safe and convenient access to schools, parks or
other similar destinations will be approved by the city council and city
engineer. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
      2.   No specific rule concerning the shape of blocks is made, but blocks
must fit easily into the overall plan of the subdivision and their design must
evidence consideration of lot planning, traffic flow, and public areas.
      3.   Blocks intended for commercial and industrial use must be designated
as such, and the plan must show adequate off street areas to provide for
parking, loading docks and such other facilities that may be required to
accommodate motor vehicles.
   (E)   Lot Standards:
      1.   The minimum lot dimensions for residential development shall be
sixty feet (60') wide at the established building line and not less than one
hundred feet (100') in average depth, and containing not less than six thousand
(6,000) square feet in area, except that a corner lot may be of less depth;
provided, that neither the width nor depth is less than eighty five feet (85'),
where permitted under the provisions of the zoning title. This minimum
requirement shall not apply to land subdivided for nonresidential development.
      2.   Corner lots shall be sufficiently larger than interior lots to allow
maintenance of building lines on both streets.
      3.   All lots shall abut on a publicly dedicated street.
      4.   Side lines of lots shall be approximately at right angles or radial
to the street line.
      5.   Double frontage lots are forbidden except where lots back upon a
primary street (major thoroughfare) and in such instances, vehicular access
between the lots and the thoroughfare is prohibited. Such lots shall have an
additional depth of at least ten feet (10') in order to allow for a protective
screen planting.
      6.   Lots abutting a watercourse, drainageway, channel or stream shall
have additional minimum width or depth as required to provide an adequate
building site and afford the minimum usable area required in the zoning title
for front, rear and side yards.
   (F)   Parks, Schools, And Public Areas:
      1.   Where a proposed park, playground, school or other public use area,
shown in the general development plan for the city and adjacent unincorporated
areas, is located in whole or in part in a subdivision, the plan commission may
recommend and the governing body may require the dedication or reservation of
such area, in whole or in part, within the subdivision in those cases in which
the plan commission or the proper governing body deem such requirements to be
reasonable. However, in no case shall the total amount of required public areas
to be dedicated or reserved, in addition to public streets, exceed ten percent
(10%) of the total gross acreage owned or controlled by one developer. The
acquisition of the additional area needed for parks, playgrounds, schools or
other public uses, other than streets and alleys, shall be secured by the
proper governing body, or arrangements made for securing the area from the
owner within a period not to exceed ninety (90) days.
      2.   In the subdividing of any land within the city, or within one and
one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits, due regard shall be shown for
all natural features, such as tree growth, watercourses, historic spots, or
similar conditions which, if preserved, will add attractiveness and value to
the proposed development. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972; amd. 2020 Code)
3-11-5: PROCEDURE AND REQUIREMENTS:
   (A)   Procedure For Filing Of Preliminary Plans:
      1.   Filing:
         (a)   Any owner of land which is within the corporate limits of the
city or within one and one-half (11/2) miles of the corporate limits on
unincorporated land, wishing to divide the same into building lots for purposes
of sale or assessment or both, or wishing to dedicate streets, alleys or other
lands for public use, shall first submit to the city a preliminary plan in
triplicate.
         (b)   The council shall, by motion, refer the preliminary plan to the
plan commission and shall at the time instruct the engineer to collaborate with
the subdivider and the plan commission in assembling plans for the design and
construction of streets and such other public improvements as are required by
this chapter or any other provisions of this code. The plan commission shall,
within thirty (30) days from referral, submit its written recommendations for
approval or disapproval to the council.
         (c)   The preliminary plans shall be referred to the plan commission
at least ten (10) days prior to the regular meeting of the commission to
receive action thereon at the meeting.
      2.   Preliminary Plat; Contents:
         (a)   Proposed name of the subdivision.
         (b)   Location by township, section, town and range, or by other legal
description.
         (c)   Names and addresses of developer and designer who made plat.
         (d)   Scale of plat, one inch to one hundred feet (1" = 100') or
larger.
         (e)   Date.
         (f)   North point.
         (g)   Boundary lines of proposed subdivision indicated by solid heavy
line and the total approximate acreage encompassed thereby.
         (h)   Location, widths and names of all existing or prior platted
streets or other public ways, railroad and utility rights of way, parks and
other public open spaces, permanent buildings and structures, houses or
permanent easements, and section and corporation lines, within or adjacent to
the street.
         (i)   Existing sewers, water mains, culverts or other underground
facilities within the tract indicating pipe sizes, grades, manholes, and exact
location.
         (j)   Boundary lines of adjacent tracts of unsubdivided or subdivided
land, showing ownership where possible.
         (k)   Existing zoning of proposed subdivision and adjacent tracts, in
zoned areas.
         (l)   Contours at two foot (2') intervals except where topography of
the tract demands one foot (1') contour intervals.
         (m)   Layout of streets, widths of rights of way and also the widths
of crosswalks and easements.
         (n)   Layout, numbers and dimensions of lots.
         (o)   Parcels of land intended to be dedicated or temporarily reserved
for public use or set aside for use of property owners in the subdivision.
         (p)   Building setback lines, showing dimensions.
         (q)   Easements shall be provided for any and all public utilities
where alleys are not provided. Proper continuity for the utilities from block
to block shall be maintained.
      3.   Qualifications For Approval Of Preliminary Plat:
         (a)   The approval of a preliminary plan by the plan commission and
the council is tentative only, involving merely the general acceptability of
the layout.
         (b)   The plan commission or the council may require such changes or
revisions as are deemed necessary in the interest and needs of the community.
         (c)   Subsequent approval will be required of the engineering
proposals pertaining to water supply, storm drainage, sewerage and sewage
disposal, gas and electric service, street lighting, fire hydrants, grading,
gradients and roadway widths, and the surfacing of streets by the engineer, and
the county officials, where concerned, prior to the approval of the final plat
by the city.
         (d)   Tentative approval shall be effective for a maximum period of
twelve (12) months unless, upon application of the developer, the council
grants an extension. If the final plat has not been recorded within this time
limit, the preliminary plat must again be submitted for approval. (Ord. 680, 1-
17-1972)
   (B)   Approval Of Final Plat:
      1.   Filing:
         (a)   After approval of the preliminary plat by the city council and
the fulfillment of the requirements of these regulations, at least two (2)
tracings of the final plat of the subdivision, printed on drafting mylar not to
exceed thirty six inches by forty eight inches (36" x 48") in size, shall be
submitted to the council for approval. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
         (b)   Action must be taken by the council within sixty (60) days after
the final plat has been submitted for approval. (Ord. 1622, 9-16-1991)
         (c)   Upon approval by the council, the developer shall record the
plat with the recorder of Lee County within three (3) months. If not recorded
within this time, the approval shall be null and void.
         (d)   A print of the final plat, after the plat is recorded, will be
filed and retained in the offices of the city.
      2.   Final Plat; Contents:
         (a)   Name of subdivision.
         (b)   Location by township, section, town and range, or by other legal
description.
         (c)   Names of owners and certification by a licensed surveyor.
         (d)   Scale one inch to one hundred feet (1" = 100') or larger, shown
graphically.
         (e)   Date.
         (f)   North point.
         (g)   Boundary of plat, based on an accurate traverse, with angular
and linear dimensions.
         (h)   Exact location, width and name of all streets within and
adjoining the plat, and the exact location and widths of all crosswalk ways.
Proposed street names shall be checked with the proper city officials.
         (i)   True angles and distances to the nearest established street
lines or official monuments (not less than 3), which shall be accurately
described in the plat.
         (j)   Municipal, township, county or section lines accurately tied to
the lines of the subdivision by distances and angles.
         (k)   Radii, internal angles, points and curvatures, tangent bearings
and lengths of all arcs.
         (l)   All easements for rights of way provided for public services and
utilities.
         (m)   All lot numbers and lines, with accurate dimensions in feet and
hundredths.
         (n)   Accurate location of all monuments, which shall be concrete six
inches by six inches by thirty inches (6" x 6" x 30") with iron pipe case in
center. Permanent stone or concrete monuments shall be set at each corner or
angle of the outside boundary. Steel pipes or steel pins shall be set on each
lot corner, other than those for permanent stone or concrete monuments. All
U.S., state, county, or other official bench marks, monuments or triangular
stations in or adjacent to the property shall be preserved in precise position.
         (o)   Accurate outlines and legal descriptions of any areas to be
dedicated or reserved for public use, with the purposes indicated thereon, and
of any area to be reserved by deed covenant for common uses of all property
owners.
         (p)   Building setback lines accurately shown by dimensions.
         (q)   Protective covenants which meet with the approval of the plan
commission shall be lettered or typed on the final plat.
         (r)   Certification by a registered surveyor to the effect that the
plat represents a survey made by him and that monuments and markers shown
thereon exist as located and that all dimensional and geodetic details are
correct.
         (s)   Notarized certification by the owner, or by any mortgage holder
on record, of the adoption of the plat and the dedication of streets and other
public areas.
         (t)   Certifications showing that all taxes and special assessments
due on the property to be subdivided have been paid in full.
         (u)   Proper form for the approval of the council with space for
signature.
         (v)   Approval by signature of city, county and state officials
concerned with the specification of utility installations.
         (w)   Approval by signature of the plan commission. This approval of
the final plat shall not be deemed to constitute or effect an acceptance by the
public of the dedication of any street or other proposed public way or space
shown on the plat. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-6: AGREEMENTS:
The final plat to be filed on record shall be accompanied by a statement signed
by the owner and subdivider, setting forth the following:
   (A)   Plans and specifications for such improvements previously approved by
the engineer clearly describing the same.
   (B)   Agreement executed by the owner and the subdivider wherein they agree
to make and install the improvements provided for in section
3-11-7 of this chapter, in accordance with the plans and specifications
accompanying the final plat. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
   (C)   Bond or a letter of credit in the amount of the estimate of the
engineer of the cost of the installation of such improvements with good and
sufficient surety thereon to be approved by the council, conditioned upon the
installation of the required improvements within two (2) years of the approval
of the final plat.
   (D)   In lieu of the provisions of subsections (B) and (C) of this section,
in the event that the owner and subdivider shall submit said evidence of the
existence of the binding agreement with a responsible contractor agreeing to
accept all bonds which may be issued under any local improvement proceeding for
the installation of such improvement or a bona fide and subsisting bid by a
responsible person for the purchase for cash of such local improvement bonds at
par value or more, then the requirements of subsections (B) and (C) of this
section may be waived.
   (E)   All improvements proposed (and/or required) to be made under the
provisions of this chapter shall be inspected, during the course of
construction, by the city engineer or a duly designated deputy. Fees and costs
shall be paid according to the following schedule:
      1.   Prior to the approval of a final plat by the city council, the
subdivider or developer shall pay to the city a fee for the engineering costs
of reviewing the construction plans for improvements; said fee to be computed
in accordance with the following table:
Estimated Cost Of Construction Of Improvements Plan Review Fee

3-11-7: REQUIRED LAND IMPROVEMENTS:
No subdivision of land shall be approved without receiving a statement signed
by the engineer certifying that the improvement described in the subdivider's
plans and specifications, together with agreements, meet the minimum
requirements of all the provisions of this code and that they comply with the
following:
   (A)   Sewers:
      1.   Sanitary sewers with laterals extending to lot lines shall be
installed to comply with specifications established by the engineer and shall
be connected to the sanitary disposal system of the city if reasonably
accessible; otherwise, to a specially constructed sanitary sewage disposal
plant in accordance with plans acceptable to the city. The sanitary sewers
shall be designed to carry all of the sewage flow within the drainage basin
within the limits of one and one- half (11/2) miles from the corporate limits
of the city. The sanitary sewer shall be sized to carry a peak flow of two and
one-half (21/2) times the average flow of one hundred (100) gallons per capita
per day. Unless there is supporting data to the contrary, the sewers shall be
designed for sixteen (16) people per acre. A subdivision plat shall in no case
be approved, which shall be dependent upon individual septic tanks, except
where lots therein contain not less than ten thousand (10,000) square feet
each, and the installation meets the requirements of the state and county
health department specifications for the construction and installation of
individual septic systems.
      2.   Storm sewers shall be constructed throughout the entire subdivision
which shall be separate and independent of the sanitary sewer system and which
shall provide an adequate outlet, or connection with the storm sewer system of
the city. The storm sewers shall be extended to the extremities of the
subdivision for easy access by future upstream developments. The storm sewers
shall be sized to carry the runoff from the entire drainage area according to
the rational runoff formula Q = CiA where Q is the volume of stormwater in
cubic feet per second; C is the runoff coefficient, which is that part of the
rainfall rate which will contribute to the runoff rate; i is the average
intensity of the rainfall in inches per hour during the time required for all
parts of the watershed to contribute to runoff; and A is the area of the
drainage basin in acres. Where the major portion of the drainage basin is or
will be a residential area, a factor of eight-tenths (0.8) shall be used for
the product of C and i. When commercial, industrial or other large runoff areas
are within the drainage area, the values used for C and i shall be approved by
the city engineer. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
      3.   After all sewer and water lines installed in city streets have been
fully tested and approved by the city, and paid for by the subdivider, the
subdivider shall be required to execute a bill of sale transferring ownership
of said sewer and water lines to the city. (Ord. 1061, 12-1-1980)
   (B)   Street Improvements:
      1.   Grades of streets shall not be in excess of five percent (5%) on
primary streets, nor in excess of eight percent (8%) on other streets except in
cases of necessity and with the permission of the plan commission.
      2.   All streets within the corporate limits shall be improved with
roadways, bounded by integral concrete curbs and gutters, to an overall width
in accordance with the following minimum dimensions:
 
Type Of Street         Dedicated Street Width       Roadway Width
                       Conform to major street plan 2 24-foot roadways, divided
Primary streets        and in no instance less than by a median strip
                       100 feet
Secondary or collector 66 feet                      45 feet BC-BC
streets
Minor streets          60 feet                      37 feet BC-BC
 
      3.   Roadways shall be constructed of such base material and surfacing as
to be suitable for the volume and character of traffic expected to use the
street, and as approved by the city officials and the city engineer. The
surface shall be finished by constructing a minimum three inch (3") combined
hot mix asphalt binder and surface course conforming to section 406 of the
state of Illinois, "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction",
adopted January 1, 2007, or latest revision thereof.
      4.   Curbs and gutters on minor residential streets shall be type B6.18
combination concrete curb and gutter in accordance with IDOT standards, not
less than twenty five inches (25") in overall width.
      5.   Stormwater inlets shall be provided within the roadway improvement
at points approved by the city engineer.
      6.   All curb corners shall have a radii of not less than fifteen feet
(15') and at important intersections not less than twenty five feet (25'). All
curb corners shall be designed for the appropriate design vehicle for that
location.
      7.   Roadway improvements in subdivisions lying outside the corporate
city area, but within the one and one-half (11/2) mile area, shall conform to
standards of improvements suitable for the character of the proposed
subdivision development, recommended by the plan commission and approved by the
governing authorities.
      8.   All curbs and gutters shall conform to the design standard of the
Illinois department of transportation.
   (C)   Public Utilities:
      1.   All utility pole lines for telephone and electric service shall be
placed in rear line easements where practicable. Electric distribution centers
and gas regulating centers shall be placed where necessary to serve the
immediate area, with the definite location being approved by the city engineer.
Underground utilities are desired. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
      2.   Where telephone and electric service lines are placed underground
entirely throughout a subdivided area, the conduits or cables shall be placed
within easements or dedicated public ways, in a manner which will not conflict
with other underground services. Further, all transformer boxes shall be
located so as not to be unsightly or hazardous to the public. (Ord. 680, 1-17-
1972)
   (D)   Sidewalks:
      1.   Concrete sidewalks to a width of not less than five feet (5') shall
be required by the plan commission or governing authorities as a part of the
dedicated street improvements. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
   (E)   Landscaping: All parkways within the dedicated street area or other
public use areas shall be graded and seeded in an approved manner. (Ord. 680,
1-17-1972)
   (F)   Street Lighting: Provisions shall be made by the subdivision developer
or his agent for the adequate lighting of public streets within the proposed
subdivision, in accordance with the standard requirements established by the
governing authorities. If the street lighting system will be turned over to the
city, the underground cables shall be placed in conduits. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-
2010)
   (G)   Water Mains: Water mains shall be installed as specified in section
3-8-12 of this title. (Ord. 1249, 12-3-1984)
   (H)   Backfilling: All trenches within the limits of the proposed curbs,
sidewalks and street surfaces shall be backfilled using trench backfill
conforming to section 208 of the state of Illinois "Standard Specifications For
Road And Bridge Construction", adopted January 7, 2007, or latest revision
thereof. Trenches may be backfilled without the use of trench backfill
providing the trenches are thoroughly jetted with water and allowed to settle
for a period of twelve (12) months prior to the construction of sidewalks,
curbs and street surfaces. If trench backfill is not used, the subdivider shall
provide the city a satisfactory bond insuring the repair of all damages caused
by the settlement of trenches for a period of five (5) years.
   (I)   Private Streets: "Private streets" defined herein as a private
thoroughfare permanently reserved or otherwise intended to provide access to
more than one zoning lot or to more than one principal building on a zoning
lot, shall be improved as follows: (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
      1.   Pavement Width: A minimum pavement width of twenty six feet (26')
(exclusive of shoulders or curb) shall be provided.
      2.   On Street Parking: On street parking along a private street shall be
permitted only when the following minimum pavement width (exclusive of
shoulders or curb) is provided:
Parallel parking permitted on one side: Twenty eight feet (28').
Parallel parking permitted on both sides: Thirty six feet (36').
      3.   Fire Lanes: All private streets shall be designed as fire lanes, and
signs prohibiting on street parking shall be installed and maintained on both
sides of private streets with a pavement width of less than twenty seven feet
(27'); and on one side of any private street with a pavement width of more than
twenty seven feet (27') but less than thirty six feet (36').
      4.   Cul-De-Sacs: The pavement of any cul-de-sac or vehicle turnaround
area at the terminus of a private street shall have a minimum diameter of
ninety feet (90'). (Ord. 1544, 7-16-1990)
      5.   Construction: Roadways shall be constructed of base materials
consisting of crushed stone or gravel not less than eight inches (8") after
compaction, suitable for the volume and character of traffic expected to use
the street, and as approved by the city officials and the city engineer. The
surface shall be finished by constructing a three inch (3") combined hot mix
asphalt binder and surface course conforming to section 406 of the state of
Illinois "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", adopted
January 1, 2007, or latest revision thereof.
      6.   Grade: Grades of streets shall not be in excess of five percent (5%)
on primary streets, nor in excess of eight percent (8%) on other streets except
in cases of necessity and with the permission of the plan commission.
      7.   Drainage: All private streets shall be drained by means of ditches
and/or a piped stormwater drainage system as follows: (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
         (a)   Where drainage is by ditches, the ditches shall be placed on
both sides of the road outside any shoulders (shoulders shall have a minimum
width of 2 feet), and shall have a minimum depth of two feet (2') below the
edge of the roadway with maximum back slope of three to one (3:1), the fore
slope to be three to one (3:1). Maximum ditch gradient without erosion
protection shall be two percent (2%). All culverts shall be designed to
accommodate a 20-year storm frequency for the total watershed area tributary to
the culvert. Minimum culvert sizes shall be twelve inches (12") for driveways
and fifteen inches (15") for road crossings. At locations where culverts cross
roadways, a minimum of twelve inches (12") will be maintained between the top
of the pipe and the pavement surface. Pavement edge radii shall be a minimum of
twenty five feet (25') at connecting side street locations. (Ord. 1544, 7-16-
1990)
         (b)   Where roadway drainage is by a pipe storm sewer system, the
system shall be designed to accommodate a 20-year storm frequency of one hour
duration for a total tributary area. Curbs and gutters shall be type B6.18
combination concrete curb and gutter in accordance with IDOT standards, not
less than twenty five inches (25") in overall width, not less than nine inches
(9") thick where curb abuts the street pavement and shall conform to the
standard cross section established by the city. The type and location of
stormwater inlets shall be provided within the roadway improvement at points
approved by the city engineer. Back of curb radii shall be a minimum of fifteen
feet (15') at connecting side street locations or larger as appropriate for the
design vehicle at that location.
      8.   Sidewalks: Where sidewalks are planned, they shall be constructed of
concrete to a width of not less than five feet (5'), and on each side of a
private street, unless a variance is approved. (Ord. 2784, 5-17-2010)
      9.   Street Lighting: Provisions shall be made by the subdivision
developer or his agent for the adequate lighting of public streets within the
proposed subdivision, in accordance with the standard requirements established
by the Illinois department of transportation guidelines in effect from time to
time, unless a variance is approved.
      10.   Snow Removal, Plowing: The city shall not be responsible for snow
removal or plowing of any private street. Nor shall the city be responsible for
any cleaning, repairing, maintenance, resurfacing or any other improvement to
any private street. Nor shall the city enforce any parking regulations or other
traffic regulations on a private street. (Ord. 1544, 7-16-1990)
3-11-8: VARIANCES AND EXCEPTIONS:
   (A)   Variances: The plan commission may recommend variances from the
requirements of this chapter in specific cases which in its opinion do not
affect the general plan or the spirit of this chapter or where a strict
application of the terms of this chapter would impose a practical difficulty or
particular hardship. Such recommendations shall be communicated to the council
in writing and the reasons therefor. The council may approve variances from
these requirements in specific cases which in its opinion do not affect the
general plan or the spirit of this chapter. (Ord. 1544, 7-16-1990; amd. Ord.
2093, 6-15-1998)
   (B)   Exceptions: (Rep. by Ord. 2093, 6-15-1998)
   (C)   Hearing: No variance permitted by this section shall be granted until
the plan commission has conducted a hearing and filed a written report of its
finding and recommendations to the council.
   (D)   Plat: Each application for a variance under this section shall include
a plat of survey, prepared by an Illinois registered land surveyor, showing the
resulting lots or tracts, and giving the legal descriptions therefor. (Ord.
1524, 3-19-1990)
3-11-9: OCCUPANCY PERMIT:
No occupancy permit shall be granted by any governing official for the use of
any structure within a subdivision approved for platting until required utility
facilities have been installed and made ready to service the property, and
until roadways providing access to the subject lot have been constructed, or
are in the course of construction. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-10: ENFORCEMENT:
No plat of any subdivision shall be entitled to record in the county recorder's
office or have any validity until it shall have been approved in the manner
prescribed by this chapter. (Ord. 680, 1-17-1972)
3-11-11: RECORD OF PLATS:
All such plats of subdivision, after the same have been submitted and approved
as in this chapter provided, shall be copied upon a book of plats of the city
and shall be filed and kept by the city among the records of the city 1 . (Ord.
680, 1-17-1972)
