CHAPTER 3
SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL
SECTION:
4-3-1: Definitions
4-3-2: Administration
4-3-3: Residential Solid Waste Collection And Disposal
4-3-4: Nonresidential Waste Collection And Disposal
4-3-5: Residential Solid Waste Collection Fees
4-3-6: Disposal Of Solid Waste Other Than By Collection
4-3-7: Failure Of Owner To Remove Waste
4-3-8: Theft Of Recyclables
4-3-9: Deposits In Streets
4-3-10: Deposits Of Waste
4-3-11: Scavenger's License Required
4-3-12: Transportation Of Loose Materials
4-3-13: Burning
4-3-14: Fines
4-3-15: Landfill Fees (Rep. 2020 Code)
4-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
Terms used in this chapter shall have the meanings assigned to them in the
current written contract for residential solid waste collection and disposal
between the city and the entity performing solid waste disposal and collection.
(2020 Code)
4-3-2: ADMINISTRATION:
All matters relating to or affecting the accumulation, collection, removal or
disposal of solid waste shall be under the supervision of the Director of
Public Works or his or her designee. (2020 Code)
4-3-3: RESIDENTIAL SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL:
   (A)   Residential Service Required: Every person in possession of a
residential unit in the city shall, except as otherwise herein provided, be
required to have accumulations of solid waste collected and disposed of
regularly and systematically at least once each seven (7) days by the
contractor. A residential unit shall be deemed occupied when either water or
domestic light and power services are being supplied thereto. The city shall
have the authority to inspect the premises of any residential unit and cause to
be removed therefrom any and all solid waste found. The owner of the property
upon which the residential unit is located and the producer shall be jointly
and severally responsible for the collection and removal of the solid waste and
liable for payment of the fee described hereunder. The collection and disposal
service is furnished to the residential unit only upon the condition that the
owner of the residential unit and the producer are jointly and severally liable
for said service to the city and the contractor.
   (B)   Authorization: At any residential unit all solid waste shall be
collected and disposed of by the contractor and, except as otherwise may be
provided herein, shall not be collected or disposed of in any other manner.
   (C)   Exclusive Contract:
      1.   All solid waste shall be collected from all residential units within
the city by the contractor under exclusive contract with the city. No persons
shall use the services of any other scavenger for the collection of any waste,
unless specifically provided for in said exclusive contract or this chapter.
      2.   Residents may employ any licensed scavenger to collect and dispose
of construction debris, bulky waste and such other waste materials as may be
specifically permitted under the terms of said exclusive contract; provided,
that such scavenger must be licensed to do business by the city pursuant to
section
4-3-11 of this chapter.
      3.   The terms of said exclusive contract are incorporated by reference
into this section and shall be binding upon residents as if fully set forth
herein. A true and correct copy of the contract is filed at City Hall, 121 West
2nd Street, Dixon, Illinois, and is available for viewing by the public. The
terms of the contract shall be binding in the event of any conflict with any
other terms of this chapter.
   (D)   Collection: The contractor shall provide collection services to each
residential unit as more particularly set forth in the exclusive contract. No
collections by the contractor or any other scavenger licensed to do business in
the city shall begin prior to six o’clock (6:00) A.M., nor continue after six
thirty o’clock (6:30) P.M. on the same day.
   (E)   Containers:
      1.   Except as may otherwise be provided for herein, no person shall
permit any waste material to accumulate on his/her premises except in
containers. Each person in possession of any premises in the city where persons
reside shall provide and at all times properly maintain sufficient containers
for the weekly collection of such waste. Each person in possession of such
premises shall cause to be deposited in such container all waste material
produced in or on, or brought into or on such premises, as soon as practicable
after the same is produced in or on, or brought therein and shall be done so in
such manner as may be necessary to prevent scattering.
      2.   Contractor may decline to collect any container not placed as
provided herein. Containers which are other than as specified in the exclusive
contract shall not be disposed of by the contractor.
      3.   All waste material shall be placed in an orderly fashion by the
resident of the dwelling unit at or prior to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the day
scheduled for pick up but in no event prior to four thirty o'clock (4:30) P.M.
on the evening preceding a scheduled pick up.
      4.   All containers and waste material shall be removed from the curb, so
as to be hidden from the street and adjacent property owners within twenty four
(24) hours after the contractor has been present for the purpose of collection.
The contractor's refusal to collect such waste does not limit the requirements
provided for herein.
   (F)   Disposal Of Rubbish By Permit:
      1.   The owner or resident of a residential unit shall be allowed to
utilize a commercial container provided by any licensed scavenger at that
residential unit as a container for the disposal of "rubbish" (as that term is
defined in the exclusive contract with the contractor) in accordance with this
subsection (F). Such scavenger need not be the contractor employed by the city
but must be licensed to do business by the city pursuant to section
4-3-11 of this chapter. No commercial container shall be allowed or utilized
unless a permit therefor shall have been issued by the city building department
prior to placement of the commercial container at the residential unit.
      2.   Upon application of the owner or resident of a residential unit and
payment of the permit fee established from time to time by the city, a
commercial container permit shall be issued to such owner or occupant for the
disposal of rubbish generated at the designated residential unit. Such permit
shall be issued for a period of thirty (30) days. No commercial container
permit shall be issued for the same residential unit more than two (2) times in
any one calendar year. The permit, when issued, shall be displayed prominently
in a front window of the residential unit so as to be visible from the street
upon which the residential unit fronts with the date of expiration facing the
street.
      3.   The application for commercial container permit shall be upon forms
as prescribed from time to time by the city building department and shall
include at least the following information: the name, address and phone number
of the applicant; the address of the residential unit for which the permit is
sought; and the name of the licensed scavenger providing the commercial
container. No permit shall be granted to an applicant or for a residential unit
whose city water or sewer account is in arrears or whose account with the
city's contractor for residential solid waste collection and disposal is in
arrears.
      4.   Commercial containers placed in accordance with this subsection (F)
shall be utilized only for the disposal of rubbish, and no other materials or
wastes shall be placed therein nor disposed of using the commercial container.
The commercial container shall be "tipped" or dumped at least one time during
the thirty (30) day period for which a permit is issued and shall be maintained
in such manner, including covering, as may be necessary to prevent scattering
of rubbish. Any other materials or waste generated at the residential unit for
which the commercial container permit is issued shall be disposed of in
otherwise approved containers and in accordance with the requirements of this
chapter.
      5.   Each application for a commercial container permit shall be
accompanied by the payment of a fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00). The
permit fees and copies of the application shall be deposited with the city
building department. The city building department shall maintain a record of
each application and permit granted, the date when granted, the date of
expiration, and copies of each application. (2020 Code)
4-3-4: NONRESIDENTIAL WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL:
   (A)   Service Required:
      1.   Other than owners of residential units, it shall be the duty of
every property owner, including multi-family dwelling units not qualifying as
residential units, commercial, business and industrial establishments, to
provide for the collection and removal of all waste of any quantity whatsoever
generated on such property at least once every seven (7) day period, or more
frequently if required, so as to avoid health hazards or unreasonable
accumulations of waste.
      2.   It shall be the duty of every property owner who provides for the
collection and removal of waste generated by such property, to effect proper
placement of containers so as to not be visible from the street or adjacent
properties if reasonably possible.
   (B)   Containers: Containers for such waste shall be watertight, equipped
with tightfitting covers and be so designed as to prevent waste deposited
therein from being blown or scattered about the premises.
   (C)   Location: All areas set aside for the collection of waste shall be so
located as to not be unsightly in appearance and offensive in odor and shall be
so maintained as to prevent waste from scattering and becoming windblown.
   (D)   Licensing Requirements: It shall be the duty of every property owner
who provides for the collection and removal of waste, in any quantity
whatsoever generated by that property, to see that such collection is effected
by the contractor or a scavenger duly licensed to do business in the city
pursuant to section
4-3-11 of this chapter.
   (E)   Hours Of Operation By Scavengers: The hours of operation specified in
subsection
4-3-3(D) of this chapter shall also apply to nonresidential collection and
disposal.
   (F)   Hazardous Waste: The applicable state regulations shall govern the
removal and disposal of hazardous waste. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
   (G)   Property Owner: No owner of any "nonresidential property" (hereinafter
defined as any real property exclusive of a residential unit) shall allow waste
generated at any dwelling unit to be placed in any container belonging to or
used by said nonresidential property owner. No resident of a dwelling unit
shall deposit waste generated at any dwelling unit in a container belonging to
or used by a nonresidential property owner. (Ord. 1769, 10-4-1993; amd. 2020
Code)
4-3-5: RESIDENTIAL SOLID WASTE COLLECTION FEES:
   (A)   Residential Collections: Fees for residential solid waste collection
and disposal shall be as set forth in the exclusive contract between the city
and the contractor.
   (B)   Billing: Fees for residential solid waste collection and disposal
shall be billed and collected as set forth in the exclusive contract between
the city and the contractor.
   (C)   Waste Collections Not Covered By Exclusive Contract: Waste collection
and disposal service not covered by the exclusive contract between the city and
the contractor shall be performed by a scavenger duly licensed to do business
in the city in accordance with section
4-3-11 of this chapter at such schedules and rates as may be mutually agreed
upon between the licensed scavenger and the owner or resident. (2020 Code)
4-3-6: DISPOSAL OF SOLID WASTE OTHER THAN BY COLLECTION:
   (A)   Burning Restricted; Burying Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any
person to burn waste within the city except in accordance with section
8-3-5-1 of this code. Properly designed and installed kitchen garbage disposal
units may be used for the disposal of garbage into the city's sanitary sewer
system. It shall be unlawful for any person to bury waste anywhere within the
city or to permit the same to be placed or accumulated at any place or manner
other than in a proper container.
   (B)   Accumulation Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for the occupant and/or
owner of any premises in the city to accumulate thereon any waste except in
compliance with the provisions hereof.
   (C)   Depositing Containers On Another's Premises: It shall be unlawful for
any person to deposit his refuse or other waste upon the property of another
for the purpose of having such waste picked up by a scavenger or the
contractor. Any person committing this prohibited act shall, in addition to
violating this chapter, be deemed to have committed the offense of littering.
(Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-7: FAILURE OF OWNER TO REMOVE WASTE:
   (A)   If the owner of private property in the city upon which there is
deposited any waste in violation of this chapter refuses or neglects to remove
such waste or to have the same removed as herein provided, within seven (7)
days after written notice shall have been given to the property owner by
personal delivery or by certified mail, the city or its designee may remove
such waste and may collect from such owner the cost thereof. (Ord. 2121, 11-2-
1998)
   (B)   Such cost shall be a lien upon the real estate affected if within
sixty (60) days after such cost and expenses incurred by the city or the person
performing the removal service by authority of the city in his or its own name
files notice of lien in the office of the recorder of deeds. Such notice shall
consist of a sworn statement setting out: 1) a description of the real estate
sufficient for identification thereof, 2) the amount of money representing the
cost and expense incurred or payable for the removal service, 3) the date, or
dates, when such costs and expense was incurred by the city, and 4) the date
when notice was served.
   (C)   Upon payment of the cost and expense of the owner or persons
interested in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall
be released by the city or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the
release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The
lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in the case of mortgages or
mechanics' liens. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-8: THEFT OF RECYCLABLES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to collect, obtain, possess or pick up any
recyclable material or other waste placed for collection at the curb as part of
the city's residential solid waste collection and disposal services contract
intended for collection and disposal by the contractor as provided for in
subsection
4-3-3(C) of this chapter. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-9: DEPOSITS IN STREETS:
No person shall deposit any waste in any street, alley, or upon the portion of
the banks of Rock River or any public place except as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-10: DEPOSITS OF WASTE:
No person shall cast or leave exposed in or about any private premises or on
any lot, street, or alley or about any sewer, gutter or sluiceway in the city
any waste. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
4-3-11: SCAVENGER'S LICENSE REQUIRED:
   (A)   No person, either as principal or agent, shall engage in the business
of collection and hauling waste in the city without having first obtained a
license as a scavenger. As a condition to obtaining a scavenger's license, each
applicant must offer recycling collection services. Provided, however, no
license shall be required for any charitable or religious organization which
solicits donations of junk when such organization is operating not for profit
to any individual member thereof and the proceeds are applied to the object for
which it exists.
   (B)   The licenses provided in this section shall be limited to eight (8)
persons and in no event shall scavenger licenses be issued during any one year
to more than eight (8) collectors, operating either as an individual or as a
firm of individuals. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993)
   (C)   Upon notification by the city that any licensee's equipment is being
employed or services are being provided in violation of this chapter,
including, but not limited to, subsection
4-3-3(C) of this chapter, any licensee under this section shall be obliged,
upon such notice, to promptly secure compliance or otherwise to remove any of
licensee's equipment used in violation of this chapter from any site within the
city. Failure to comply with the requirements of this section shall be grounds
for suspension, revocation, or nonrenewal of the license issued under this
section upon notice and opportunity for a hearing to contest any alleged
failure to comply. (Ord. 2878, 6-18-2012)
4-3-12: TRANSPORTATION OF LOOSE MATERIALS:
No person shall transport any sand, gravel, earth, ashes, stone, coal,
wastepaper, filth, waste or other loose or offensive materials or liquids in
any vehicle upon the streets or alleys of the city unless the box or container
of such materials upon the vehicle shall be sufficiently firm and tight so as
to prevent the falling or spilling of any such material from the vehicle upon
the streets or alleys and the vehicles containing such material shall have a
cover of canvas or other suitable covering so as to prevent the blowing,
falling and spilling of such material upon the streets or alleys. (Ord. 1758,
8-16-1993)
4-3-13: BURNING:
It shall be unlawful to burn any waste in the city limits except as provided in
Section
8-3-5-1 of this code. (2020 Code)
4-3-14: FINES:
   (A)   Any person who shall violate any provisions of this chapter shall,
upon conviction, be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such violation. (Ord. 2913,
6-3-2013)
   (B)   The Director of Public Works or his or her designee shall have the
authority to direct payment of twenty five percent (25%) of any fine revenue
received by the city from a violation of this chapter to the person or persons
other than the violator who provided information that led to the conviction or
plea of guilty. It is at the sole discretion of the Director of Public Works or
his or her designee to determine whether the information provided led to a
conviction of a violation of this chapter, and the commissioner of streets or
his designee and the city shall not be subject to any suit, judgment, claim or
appeal of this determination. (Ord. 1758, 8-16-1993; amd. 2020 Code)
4-3-15: LANDFILL FEES:
(Rep. 2020 Code)
CHAPTER 4
SMOKE AND DUST
(Rep. 2020 Code)
CHAPTER 5
MOBILE HOMES AND MOBILE HOME PARKS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Adoption Of Certain Statutes
4-5-2: Definitions
4-5-3: License Required For Mobile Home Parks
4-5-4: General Standards For Mobile Home Parks
4-5-5: Permit Required For Mobile Home Parks
4-5-6: General Standards For Mobile Homes
4-5-7: Mobile Homes Outside Of Mobile Home Parks
4-5-8: Permanent Affixation Of Mobile Home
4-5-1: ADOPTION OF CERTAIN STATUTES:
Mobile homes and mobile home parks shall be operated and maintained in
accordance with the National Manufactured Housing Construction and Safety Act,
42 USC 5401 et seq., and the Illinois Mobile Home Park Act, 210 ILCS 115/1 et
seq., each as amended from time to time, and the rules and regulations
promulgated thereunder, which are hereby adopted by reference. Except as
otherwise expressly defined in section
4-5-1, and unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and phrases
set forth in this chapter shall have the meanings set forth in the Mobile Home
Park Act. (2020 Code)
4-5-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings herein
ascribed to them:
 
                          The National Manufactured Housing Construction and
MANUFACTURED HOUSING ACT: Safety Act, 42 USC 5401 et seq., as amended from time
                          to time, and the regulations promulgated thereunder.
                          Any structure placed in accordance with this chapter
                          that meets the definition of a "manufactured home" as
MOBILE HOME:              set forth in the Manufactured Housing Act. The term
                          "mobile home" shall not include modular homes and
                          their support systems.
                          The Illinois Mobile Home Park Act, 210 ILCS 115/1 et
MOBILE HOME PARK ACT:     seq., as amended from time to time, and the
                          regulations promulgated thereunder. (2020 Code)
 
4-5-3: LICENSE REQUIRED FOR MOBILE HOME PARKS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a mobile
home park within the corporate limits of the city unless such person shall
first obtain a license from the city therefor.
   (B)   An application for license shall be made at the office of the city
clerk, shall state the name and address of the owner and manager of the mobile
home park, the location of the park, and the maximum number of mobile homes at
the park, and shall be accompanied by plans of the park showing all buildings,
toilets, baths, washbasin facilities, sinks, water faucets, sewer connections,
streets, driveways and other improvements and utilities. In the case of a
partnership, corporation, limited liability company or other business, it shall
include the date of its formation, the objects for which it was formed, and the
names and addresses of its officers, directors, members, partners or other
persons authorized to act for and on behalf of the business. A certified copy
of the organizational documents filed with the Illinois Secretary of State and
a current Certificate of Good Standing or Certificate of Existence, as
applicable, shall be provided. The application shall also include a statement
whether the applicant has made any applications for a similar license other
than as described in the application, and the disposition of such application,
and whether a previous license by any state, or subdivision thereof, or by the
federal government, has been revoked and the reasons therefor.
   (C)   No license shall be issued or renewed until the mobile home park has
been inspected by the city building official for compliance with this chapter
and all applicable codes and regulations of the city.
   (D)   The city clerk shall issue a license to the applicant upon
demonstration of compliance with all requirements of this chapter and the
Mobile Home Park Act. The annual license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00).
Licenses shall expire on December 31 of each year. There shall be no proration
of partial years.
   (E)   The license shall be conspicuously posted on the premises of the
mobile home park at all times. (2020 Code)
4-5-4: GENERAL STANDARDS FOR MOBILE HOME PARKS:
   (A)   Every mobile home park shall be managed by a responsible individual
whose name, address and telephone number shall be on file at all times with the
city. The manager shall be responsible, along with the licensee, for violations
of any provisions of this Chapter or the Mobile Home Park Act.
   (B)   An adequate supply of drinking water from the city's water supply
facilities shall be available to meet the requirements of the mobile home park.
All connections shall comply with applicable city ordinances relating to the
water supply for homes.
   (C)   Every mobile home park shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary
condition and shall provide for the collection or removal of garbage and other
waste material on at least a weekly basis.
   (D)   Each individual lot within the mobile home park shall abut or face a
private or public street. All streets shall have unobstructed access to a
public street.
   (E)   Mobile home parks shall be kept adequately lighted at all times with
lighting fixtures that are in good working order and of sufficient wattage for
the safety of occupants and visitors.
   (F)   An accurate record shall be kept of all mobile homes, including the
name of the owner, the date of arrival, make, model and registration
information regarding the mobile home and towing vehicle, the license number,
and the square footage of floor space. (2020 Code)
4-5-5: PERMIT REQUIRED FOR MOBILE HOMES:
Every mobile home to be moved on or off a lot shall be required to secure a
building permit and a permit for moving buildings and shall pay all applicable
fees associated therewith. A building permit and payment of the applicable fee
shall be required for any additions constructed to the mobile home. (2020 Code)
4-5-6: GENERAL STANDARDS FOR MOBILE HOMES:
All mobile homes placed upon any lot within the corporate limits of the city
after August 1, 2018, must have been manufactured not more than ten (10) years
prior to the date of the application for a building permit allowing placement
of the mobile home upon said lot and must comply with the construction
standards set forth in the Manufactured Housing Act, which compliance shall be
verified by the presence of the permanently attached HUD seal/emblem on the
mobile home. If the mobile home is a multi-wide unit, each unit must have such
a HUD seal/emblem. In addition to the foregoing, no mobile home shall be placed
or remain upon any lot unless said mobile home shall meet the following
requirements.
   (A)   No mobile home shall be located closer than five feet (5') to the side
or rear lot lines or closer than ten feet (10') to any public street or alley
or to another building structure.
   (B)   Each mobile home shall have all wheels, tongue and hitch mechanisms
removed or retracted.
   (C)   The base of the mobile home shall be completely enclosed commercial
skirting. All skirting shall be weather resistance, shall be uniform in
construction, style and color, and shall be compatible with the siding of the
mobile home.
   (D)   The minimum size of the mobile home shall be eight hundred (800)
square feet, exclusive of any porch, garage or other non-dwelling space.
   (E)   Each mobile home shall have smoke detectors, carbon monoxide
detectors, and fire extinguishers installed and in good working condition in
accordance with manufacturer specifications and in accordance with all
applicable codes, regulations and ordinances.
   (F)   A mobile home shall be used only as a residential dwelling unit. No
mobile home shall be used as a storage building or for any other commercial or
business use. The area underneath a mobile home shall not be used for storage.
   (G)   All mobile homes shall be securely anchored in accordance with the
requirements of the Illinois Mobile Home Tiedown Act, 210 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
   (H)   All mobile homes shall be maintained so as to be structurally sound,
waterproof and with all features and systems properly installed, in good
working condition, and in compliance with all applicable codes, regulations and
ordinances.
A mobile home lawfully placed, in full compliance with all applicable codes,
regulations and ordinances, and existing on August 1, 2018, may be continued in
use even though such mobile home does not conform to the construction and
installation requirements of this chapter; provided, that there shall be no
physical change, alteration or improvement to the mobile home other than
routine maintenance and repair. If there is a physical change, alteration or
improvement to the mobile home other than routine maintenance and repair, then
the mobile home shall comply with the requirements of this chapter. (2020 Code)
4-5-7: MOBILE HOMES OUTSIDE OF MOBILE HOME PARKS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to locate or maintain a mobile home upon
any lot within the city except for lots located within a mobile home park
licensed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. (2020 Code)
4-5-8: PERMANENT AFFIXATION OF MOBILE HOME:
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove the wheels or other transporting
devices from any mobile home or to otherwise affix the mobile home permanently
to the ground or place the same on a foundation so as to prevent ready removal
of such mobile home, unless a permit to do so is first obtained from the city
as is required for the construction of a new building. Any such alteration
shall be construed as converting the mobile home into a building and will
subject the building to the requirements of the zoning and building ordinances
of the city for single-family dwellings and any other applicable codes,
regulations and ordinances. (2020 Code)
CHAPTER 6
MILK
(Rep. 2020 Code)
CHAPTER 7
NUISANCES
SECTION:
4-7-1: Definition; Prohibition
4-7-2: Nonsummary Abatement; Notice
4-7-3: Nonsummary Abatement
4-7-4: Summary Abatement
4-7-4-1: Penalty
4-7-5: Plants, Weeds And Grass
4-7-6: Chronic Nuisance Property
4-7-7: Noise Control
4-7-1: DEFINITION; PROHIBITION:
The following acts, conduct and conditions are hereby declared and defined to
be nuisances, and when committed, performed or permitted to exist by any
individual within the territorial limits of the city, are hereby declared to be
unlawful and prohibited:
   (A)   Any act of offense which is a nuisance according to the common law of
the state of Illinois, or declared or defined to be a nuisance by the
ordinances of the city. In addition, the officials of the municipality shall be
authorized to abate any nuisance which, while not specifically defined within
this chapter, shall constitute the unreasonable, unwarrantable, or unlawful use
by a person of property real or personal or from his own improper, indecent or
unlawful personal conduct which works an obstruction or injury to a right of
another, or of the public, and produces such material annoyance, inconvenience,
discomfort, or hurt that the law will presume an actionable nuisance. Nuisances
may be abated which are public or which are both public and private in nature.
   (B)   To cause or suffer the carcass of any animal or any offal, filth or
noisome substance to be collected, deposited or to remain in any place under
his ownership or control to the prejudice of others.
   (C)   To throw or deposit any offal or other offensive matter, or the
carcass of any dead animal in any watercourse, lake, pond, spring, well or
common sewer, street or public highway.
   (D)   To corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water of any spring,
river, stream, pond or lake, to the injury or prejudice of others.
   (E)   To obstruct or encroach upon public highways, private ways, streets,
alleys, commons, landing places and ways to burying places.
   (F)   To erect, continue to use any building or other place for the exercise
of any trade, employment or manufacture, which, by occasioning noxious
exhalations, offensive smells or otherwise, is offensive or dangerous to the
health of individuals, or of the public.
   (G)   To advertise wares or occupation by painting notices of the same on,
or affixing them to fences, walls, windows, building exteriors, utility poles,
or on hydrants, other public or private property, or on rocks or other natural
objects, without the consent of the owner, or if in the highway or other public
place, without the permission of the proper authorities.
   (H)   To harass, intimidate or threaten any person who is about to sell or
lease or has sold or leased a residence or other real property or is about to
buy or lease or has bought or leased a residence or other real property, when
the harassment, intimidation or threat relates to a person's attempt to sell,
buy or lease a residence, or other real property, or refers to a person's sale,
purchase or lease of a residence or other real property.
   (I)   To dump, abandon, deposit, dismantle or burn upon any public property
or right of way, highway, park, street or parkway anywhere in the city any
trash, garbage, ashes, junk, junked or wrecked motor vehicles or parts thereof,
or miscellaneous waste. (Ord. 1063, 1-5-1981)
   (J)   To store, keep or maintain outside of a closed building, any junk,
parts, machinery or equipment not in an operable condition; provided, however,
that this provision shall not apply to a properly licensed junkyard or other
permitted outdoor storage use which is in full compliance with all of the
ordinances of the city governing the same. (Ord. 1420, 4-4-1988)
   (K)   To own, maintain or keep a dwelling unit unfit for human habitation or
dangerous or detrimental to life, safety or health because of lack of repair,
defects in the plumbing system, lighting or ventilation, the existence of
contagious diseases or unsanitary conditions likely to cause sickness among
persons residing in said premises or residing in proximity thereof.
   (L)   To store or place any materials in a manner which may harbor rats.
(Ord. 1063, 1-5-1981)
   (M)   (Rep. by Ord. 3011, 5-16-2016)
   (N)   To keep an inoperable motor vehicle on public or private property and
in view of the general public. As used in this section, "inoperable motor
vehicle" means any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at least seven (7)
days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or on which the
engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so
treated that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor
power. "Inoperable motor vehicle" shall not include a motor vehicle which has
been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power
in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations. (Ord. 1420, 4-4-
1988)
Nothing in this subsection shall apply to any motor vehicle that is kept within
an enclosed building when not in use, to operable historic vehicles over twenty
five (25) years of age, or to a motor vehicle on the premises of a place of
business engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles. (Ord. 2050, 12-
15-1997)
   (O)   To disrupt, disturb, or interfere with any ditches or natural drains
across public or private property in such a manner that such ditches or natural
drains shall fill or become obstructed with any matter which materially impedes
or interferes, or which creates a reasonable likelihood of materially impeding
or interfering with the flow of water, or which redirects water onto another's
property except as otherwise authorized by law, or to otherwise create or
permit the existence of a condition of standing water where the standing water
may facilitate or encourage the breeding of mosquitoes. For purposes of this
subsection, "ditch" shall mean any artificially constructed open drain or
natural drain that has been artificially improved, and "drain" shall mean any
ditch, watercourse or conduit, whether open, covered or enclosed, natural or
artificial, or partially natural and partially artificial, by which surface
waters coming upon or falling upon lands are carried away in the normal course
of drainage. (Ord. 2971, 8-3-2015)
4-7-2: NONSUMMARY ABATEMENT; NOTICE:
   (A)   Except where otherwise prohibited by the ordinances of the city, any
officer of the city possessing police powers may serve or cause to be served a
notice, in writing, upon the owner, agent, occupant or person in possession,
charge or control of any lot, building or premises or item of personalty in or
upon which any nuisance exists, requiring them or either or both of them, to
abate the same within a specified reasonable time, which shall be not less than
seven (7) days in the case of inoperable motor vehicles, in such manner as the
notice shall direct. (Ord. 1420, 4-4-1988)
   (B)   Any person may contest the determination that the vehicle is a
nuisance as defined in this chapter, by filing written request for a hearing
with the chief of police within seven (7) days of receipt of notice provided
under this section. Upon such request, a hearing will be conducted by the mayor
of the city, at which time such person will have the opportunity to present
evidence that the vehicle does not constitute a nuisance. The decision of the
mayor shall be final. Failure to request a hearing within seven (7) days of
receipt of the notice shall constitute a waiver of the right to a hearing. If a
hearing is requested in the manner set forth herein, no action will be taken
with respect to the vehicle until the hearing is completed and the mayor's
decision is final. (Ord. 1459, 11-21-1988)
4-7-3: NONSUMMARY ABATEMENT:
If the person so served and notified does not abate the nuisance within the
specified reasonable time, the corporate authorities may proceed to abate the
nuisance in any or all manner allowable by law, including, without limiting the
generality thereof, the following:
   (A)   Seeking to impose a monetary penalty as defined by section
4-7-4-1 of this chapter by instituting an ordinance enforcement action.
   (B)   Seeking to enjoin the continuation of the nuisance by the filing of a
lawsuit in a court of competent jurisdiction.
   (C)   In the case of an inoperable motor vehicle, authorizing a law
enforcement agency, with applicable jurisdiction, to remove any inoperable
motor vehicle or part thereof. (Ord. 1420, 4-4-1988)
4-7-4: SUMMARY ABATEMENT:
Whenever, in the opinion of an officer of the city possessing police powers,
the maintenance or continuation of a nuisance creates an imminent threat of
serious injury to persons or serious damage to persons or real property, or if
the nuisance can be abated summarily without or with only minor damage to the
items or premises which are creating the nuisance, and the continuation of the
nuisance poses a substantial threat of injury to persons or property or a
substantial interference with the quiet enjoyment of life normally present in
the community, such officer shall proceed to abate such nuisance; provided,
further, that whenever the owner, occupant, agent or person in possession,
charge or control of the real or personal property which has become a nuisance
is unknown or cannot readily be found, the municipal officer with police power
may proceed to abate such nuisance without notice. Where the abatement of the
nuisance requires continuing acts by the corporate authorities beyond the
initial summary abatement and any other additional emergency abatements, it
shall seek abatement of such nuisance on a permanent basis through judicial
process as soon as readily possible. (Ord. 1063, 1-5-1981)
4-7-4-1: PENALTY:
Any individual violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be subject to the provisions of title 1, chapter 4 of this code.
Each day that a violation is allowed to exist shall constitute a separate
offense. (Ord. 2258, 6-19-2000)
4-7-5: PLANTS, WEEDS AND GRASS:
   (A)   Declaration Of Nuisance: No owner of or other person occupying any
lot, place, or area within the city, including the parkway located between the
sidewalk or property line and the improved and traveled portion of the public
way adjacent to such lot, place, or area located within the city, shall permit
any weeds, grass, unhealthful or other noxious growth (all hereinafter referred
to as "weeds") other than trees, bushes, flowers, or other ornamental plants to
grow to a height exceeding eight inches (8") on such lot, place, area, or
parkway. Any weeds exceeding eight inches (8") in height are hereby declared to
be a nuisance. (Ord. 2005, 8-4-1997)
   (B)   Notice To Destroy: The building official is hereby authorized and
empowered to notify, or cause to be notified, in writing, or by personal
service, the owner of any such parcel of real estate within the city limits to
cut and destroy said weeds located upon said owner's real estate. Said notice
shall be by registered mail addressed to said owner at his last known address
or by personal service. (Ord. 1050, 9-15-1980)
   (C)   Refusal To Remove: Upon the refusal or neglect of any owners so
notified to cut and destroy said weeds growing or located upon said owner's
real estate within five (5) days after receipt of the written notice provided
for in subsection (B) of this section or within five (5) days after the date of
said notice in the event the same is returned to the city because of the
inability to make delivery thereof, the building official is hereby authorized
and empowered to provide for the cutting and destroying of said weeds either by
employees of the city or by persons performing this service by authority of the
building official. The city shall be entitled to collect the costs incurred in
the cutting and destroying of said weeds from the owner or owners of said real
estate. In the event employees of the city cut and destroy said weeds, the
minimum charge for said action shall be forty dollars ($40.00). (Ord. 1675, 7-
20-1992)
   (D)   Lien: The cost incurred in cutting and destroying said weeds shall be
a lien upon the real estate affected and may be perfected and enforced in
accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-20-15 or other applicable law.
The notice shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth: 1) a description
of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 2) the amount of
money representing the costs and expenses incurred or payable for the service;
and 3) the date or dates when such costs and expenses were incurred by the
city. The person to whom the tax bill was sent for the general taxes on the
property for the last preceding year shall be served a copy of the notice of
lien; service is to be made personally or by certified mail. (Ord. 2005, 8-4-
1997)
   (E)   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this section, in
addition to the provisions for lien contained herein, shall, on conviction, be
fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. In any case in which an offense is
of a continuing nature, each day such violation continues shall be deemed a
separate violation and shall subject the person so violating said provisions of
this section to a separate fine for each such day. (Ord. 1050, 9-15-1980; amd.
2020 Code)
4-7-6: CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTY:
   (A)   General Definitions: For purposes of this section, the following
definitions shall apply:
   DWELLING: A house, duplex, condominium unit, apartment building, mobile
home, manufactured home, trailer or any other structure or place used or
intended to be used for human habitation, including common areas within the
structure when buildings or structures are used for more than one dwelling, and
accessory buildings such as garages located on the same premises.
   IN OR ON THE PREMISES OF ANY DWELLING: Either within a dwelling or the area
within the boundary lines of any real property of the same ownership on which
such dwelling is located.
   OCCUPANT: Any person who lives in or has possession of, or holds an
occupancy interest in a dwelling; or any person residing in or frequenting the
premises of the dwelling with the actual or implied permission of the owner or
lessee.
   OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, firm or corporation having a legal or
equitable ownership interest in the dwelling, as recorded in the official
records of the state, county, or municipality as holding title to the dwelling;
or otherwise having control of the dwelling, including the guardian of an
estate of any such person, the executor or administrator of an estate or
trustee lawfully entitled to possession or control of such property.
   (B)   Chronic Nuisance Property Defined: "Chronic nuisance property" is a
dwelling within which, or on the premises of which, any three (3) of the
following, arising out of separate and distinct facts and circumstances, have
occurred within a ninety (90) day consecutive period:
      1.   Any felony or misdemeanor involving or constituting a breach of the
peace as defined by statutes of the state of Illinois and/or the ordinances of
the city of Dixon; or
      2.   Any violation of title 5 of this code, 1963, as amended, relating to
alcoholic beverages arising out of separate and distinct facts and
circumstances, so long as such violation involves or constitutes a breach of
the peace;
      3.   Disorderly conduct, as defined under 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/26-1;
      4.   Unlawful discharge of a firearm, as defined under 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/24-1, 5/24-1.2, 5/24-1.2-5, or 5/24-1.5;
      5.   Loud or disturbing noise in violation of section
4-7-7 of this chapter.
   (C)   Violation:
      1.   No owner or occupant of any dwelling shall allow or permit such
dwelling to be, or become, a chronic nuisance property.
      2.   An owner and/or occupant shall be deemed to have allowed or
permitted a dwelling to be, or become, a chronic nuisance property if:
         (a)   The owner or occupant has personally committed the acts set
forth above;
         (b)   Such acts were committed by invitees of the occupant or owner;
or
         (c)   Such acts were committed by persons attending events or
functions sponsored, permitted, or allowed by the occupant or owner;
         (d)   Such acts were committed by a combination of subsection (C)2(a),
(C)2(b) or (C)2(c) of this section.
   (D)   Notice Of Chronic Nuisance Property:
      1.   When the chief of police, or his or her designee, determines that
property within the city has become "chronic nuisance property" as defined in
subsection (B) of this section, the chief of police shall notify the owner and/
or occupant of the property that the property has been determined to be chronic
nuisance property and may be subject to closure.
      2.   The notice shall contain the following information:
         (a)   The street address and a legal description sufficient for
identification of the property;
         (b)   A statement that the Chief of Police, or his or her designee,
has found the property to constitute chronic nuisance property with a concise
and detailed description of the actions, dates, times and persons committing
the actions leading to that finding;
         (c)   A statement that the owner and/or occupant has the opportunity
to respond in writing to the notice within fifteen (15) days from the date of
the notice, describing what steps the owner and/or occupant has or will take to
remedy the chronic nuisance conditions on the property, or the property may be
subject to closure and/or penalties assessed;
         (d)   Such notice shall be deemed to be properly delivered if
personally served or if sent via certified mail, to the owner's or occupant's
last known address with a copy of the notice posted conspicuously at the
property in question;
         (e)   If the owner's and/or occupant's response to the notice is not
satisfactory to the Chief of Police, or if the owner and/or occupant fails to
respond to the notice, then the Council of the City of Dixon may authorize the
City Attorney to initiate proceedings in a court of competent jurisdiction
seeking closure of the chronic nuisance property or any part thereof, and/or
the imposition of civil penalties against any or all of the owners and/or
occupants of the property or any other appropriate relief allowed by law.
   (E)   Action To Abate: In addition to prosecution of any offense defined
under law or in pursuit of any other remedies available, the City Council may
authorize the City Attorney to prosecute an action for equitable relief, in the
name of the City, to abate the chronic nuisance property and to enjoin any
person who owns, rents, or occupies the dwelling in question from using or
permitting its use in violation of the provisions of this section. In any such
prosecution, the City shall bear the burden to show by a preponderance of the
evidence that the property is "chronic nuisance property" as defined in
subsection (B) of this section. No judgment or finding of violation of this
section shall be entered against an owner and/or occupant who has, in good
faith, endeavored to prevent or abate the nuisance. The burden of establishing
good faith shall be that of the owner and/or occupant to show by a
preponderance of the evidence.
   (F)   Penalties:
      1.   Any property to be found "chronic nuisance property", as defined in
this section, shall be closed and secured against all use and occupancy for a
period of not less than thirty (30) days nor more than one hundred eighty (180)
days. If requested by the City, the court may authorize the City to physically
close the property against use or occupancy if the owner and/or occupant fails
to do so within the time specified in the court's order, and the owner and/or
occupant shall be responsible for the cost thereof. In any such action seeking
closure of the property, all persons with an interest of record in the property
including purchasers, beneficial owners of any Illinois land trust having title
to the property, and lawful occupants shall be named as defendants and served
with process.
      2.   In addition to the remedies provided in subsection (F)1 of this
section, the court may impose a civil penalty in an amount not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) per day nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day,
for each day that the owner and/or occupant had actual knowledge that the
property was chronic nuisance property. The owner and/or occupant is presumed
to have actual knowledge if notice was provided to the owner and/or occupant in
accordance with subsection (D) of this section. (Ord. 2585, 5-15-2006)
   (G)   Exceptions: This section shall not apply to the following situations,
and the same shall not constitute chronic nuisance property hereunder, all as
more fully described and defined in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2-1.5:
      1.   Contact made to police or other emergency services, if: a) the
contact was made with the intent to prevent or respond to domestic violence or
sexual violence; b) the intervention or emergency assistance was needed to
respond to or prevent domestic violence or sexual violence; or c) the contact
was made by, or on behalf of, or otherwise concerns an individual with a
disability and the purpose of the contact was related to that individual's
disability;
      2.   An incident or incidents of actual or threatened domestic violence
or sexual violence against a tenant, household member, or guest occurring in
the dwelling unit or on the premises; or
      3.   Criminal activity or a local ordinance violation occurring in the
dwelling unit or on the premises that is directly relating to domestic violence
or sexual violence, engaged in by a tenant, member of a tenant's household,
guest, or other party, and against a tenant, household member, guest, or other
party. (Ord. 3042, 6-5-2017)
4-7-7: NOISE CONTROL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue, or cause to be made or
continued any excessive or unusually loud noise which either annoys, disturbs,
injures, or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of others
within the jurisdictional limits of the City.
   (A)   Application: This section applies to the control of all sound
originating within the jurisdictional limits of the City.
   (B)   Definitions: As used in this section, the following terms shall have
the meanings indicated:
   EMERGENCY: An occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or
imminent physical trauma or property damage demanding immediate attention.
   EMERGENCY WORK: Any work performed for the purpose of preventing or
alleviating physical trauma or property damage, whether actually caused or
threatened by an emergency, or work by private or public utilities when
restoring utility service.
   PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, joint venture,
corporation, or limited liability company.
   (C)   General Prohibition: No person shall make, continue, or cause to be
made or continued:
      1.   Any unreasonably loud or raucous noise;
      2.   Any noise which unreasonably disturbs, injures, or endangers the
comfort, repose, health, peace, or safety of reasonable persons of ordinary
sensitivity within the jurisdictional limits of the City; or
      3.   Any noise which is so harsh, prolonged, unnatural, or unusual in
time or place as to occasion unreasonable discomfort to any persons within the
neighborhood from which said noise emanates, or as to unreasonably interfere
with the peace and comfort of neighbors or their guests, or operators or
customers in places of business, or as to detrimentally or adversely affect
such residences or places of business.
   (D)   Determination Of Violation: The factors for determination of whether a
sound violates the general prohibition set forth in subsection (C) of this
section include, but are not limited to, the following:
      1.   The proximity of the sound to residences;
      2.   The land use, nature, and zoning of the area from which the sound
emanates and the area where it is received or perceived;
      3.   The time of night or day the sound occurs and the duration of the
sound;
      4.   Whether the sound is recurrent, intermittent, or constant.
   (E)   Exemptions: Sounds caused by the following are exempt from the
prohibitions of this section:
      1.   Repairs of utility structures which pose a clear and immediate
threat to the life, health, or well being of the residents of the City or loss
of property;
      2.   Sirens, whistles, or bells lawfully used by emergency vehicles or
other alarm systems used in case of fire, collision, civil defense, police
activity, or imminent danger;
      3.   The emission of sound for the purpose of alerting persons to the
existence of an emergency or the emission of sound in the performance of
emergency work;
      4.   Repairs or excavations of bridges, streets or highways by or on
behalf of the City, the State of Illinois, or the Federal government, between
the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M., when
public welfare and convenience renders it impractical to perform the work
between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) P.M.;
      5.   Outdoor gatherings, public dances, shows, and other similar outdoor
events, provided that a permit has been obtained from the City.
   (F)   Enforcement: The Police Chief or duly acting members of the Police
Department will have primary responsibility for the enforcement of the noise
regulations contained in this section. Nothing in this section shall prevent
the Police Chief or duly acting members of the Police Department from obtaining
voluntary compliance by way of warning, notice, or education.
   (G)   Penalty: A person who violates the provision of this section is
subject to a fine as set forth in section
1-4-1 et seq., of this Code. (Ord. 3011, 5-16-2016)
CHAPTER 8
EMERGENCY VEHICLE AMBULANCE SERVICE
SECTION:
4-8-1: Charges For Emergency Vehicle Ambulance Services
4-8-2: Limitation Of Service (Rep. by Ord. 2938, 4-21-2014)
4-8-3: Payment Of Charges
4-8-1: CHARGES FOR EMERGENCY VEHICLE AMBULANCE SERVICES:
   (A)   The city shall bill Medicare, Medicaid or insurance, as applicable,
the charges set forth below for emergency vehicle ambulance services provided
to any resident or nonresident of the city. The city shall write off any
portion of a resident's bill that is not paid by Medicare, Medicaid or
insurance. Nonresidents shall be required to pay the city any portion of the
bill that is not paid by Medicare, Medicaid or insurance.
      1.   One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for basic life support; plus
      2.   Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per loaded mile for each mile the
ambulance travels; plus
      3.   One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for advance life support 1; or
      4.   One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for advance life support 2.
"Advance life support 2" shall mean a situation which requires administration
of three (3) medications administered, or defibrillation or intubation; plus
      5.   Thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for oxygen.
   (B)   For advance life support intercepts, the city shall charge the
requesting agency a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 2975, 9-8-2015;
amd. Ord. 3163, 9-16-2019; Ord. 3383, 11-20-2023)
4-8-2: LIMITATION OF SERVICE:
(Rep. by Ord. 2938, 4-21-2014)
4-8-3: PAYMENT OF CHARGES:
   (A)   All bills for emergency vehicle ambulance service charges shall be
paid on or before the due date as noted on the bill. Bills and notices shall be
mailed or delivered to the patient's last known address, but the failure to
receive a bill will not relieve the patient from the obligation to pay the
bill. Unpaid bills become delinquent thirty (30) days after the due date noted
thereon.
   (B)   The Dixon Fire Department shall adjust the charge for emergency
vehicle ambulance services to the current Medicaid rate if the patient and/or
any other person legally obligated to pay provides the Dixon Fire Department
with reliable information that:
      1. The patient and/or any other persons legally obligated to pay has
insufficient annual income to pay the bill without undue hardship. The Dixon
Fire Department shall define "insufficient annual income" from time to time;
provided, that it shall in no event be defined as being more than three hundred
percent (300%) of the then-current Federal Poverty Level as set forth in the
Federal Register; and
      2. The patient is not covered by any insurance that would pay for the
services and cannot obtain Medicare or Medicaid.
   (C)   The Dixon Fire Department has the sole authority to determine whether
the information provided supports an adjustment of the charge. (Ord. 1049, 9-
15-1980; amd. Ord. 1639, 12-2-1991; amd. Ord. 3163, 9-16-2019)
CHAPTER 9
NO SMOKING ORDINANCE
