CHAPTER 11
BODY ART ESTABLISHMENTS AND TECHNICIANS
SECTION:
4-11-1: Definitions
4-11-2: License Required
4-11-3: Application For License
4-11-4: Establishment Standards
4-11-5: Prohibitions
4-11-6: Patron's Medical History
4-11-7: Performance Of Procedures
4-11-8: Patron Instructions
4-11-9: Records
4-11-10: Equipment, Instruments And Supplies
4-11-11: Inspection
4-11-12: Suspension Or Revocation Of Licenses; Penalties
4-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in this chapter, they shall have
the following meanings ascribed to them:
ANTISEPTIC: An agent that destroys disease causing microorganisms on human skin
or mucosa.
BIOMEDICAL WASTE: Any solid or liquid waste which may present a threat of
infection to humans. Biomedical waste includes, but is not limited to, the
following: a) nonliquid tissue, body parts, blood, blood products and body
fluids, b) absorbent materials saturated with blood, blood products, body
fluids or excretions or secretions contaminated with visible blood and
absorbent materials saturated with blood or blood products that have dried, c)
nonabsorbent, disposable devices that have been contaminated with blood, but
have not been treated by an approved method, and d) discarded sharps.
BODY ART ESTABLISHMENT: Any permanent place or premises where body art
procedures are performed.
BODY ART PROCEDURE: The practice of applying physical body adornment to an
individual using such invasive methods as body piercing, tattooing, cosmetic
tattooing, branding, scarification, or similar procedures. This term does not
include ear piercing or any procedure performed by a person licensed to
practice medicine pursuant to Illinois law.
BODY ART TECHNICIAN: A person who performs body art procedures.
BODY PIERCING: To make a hole in the body in order to insert or allow the
insertion of any ring, hoop, stud, or other object for the purpose of
ornamentation of the body.
DISINFECT: The destruction of disease causing microorganisms on inanimate
objects or surfaces, thereby rendering these objects or surfaces safe for use
or handling.
EQUIPMENT: All machinery, including fixtures, containers, vessels, tools,
devices, implements, furniture, display and storage areas, sinks, and all other
apparatus and appurtenances used in connection with the operation of a body art
establishment.
GLOVES: Latex, disposable medical gloves.
HAND SINK: A sink equipped with hot and cold water running under pressure and
with wrist or foot operated controls, used solely for washing hands, arms, or
other portions of the body.
INSTRUMENT: Hand pieces, needles, needle bars, and other instruments that can
come into contact with a patron's body or may be exposed to bodily fluids
during a body art procedure.
LICENSEE: A person who has been issued a license by the mayor to operate a body
art establishment or to perform body art procedures.
LIQUID CHEMICAL GERMICIDE: A disinfectant or sanitizer registered with the
environmental protection agency, or an approximate one to one hundred (1:100)
dilution of household chlorine bleach made fresh daily and dispensed from a
spray bottle (500 ppm; 1/4 cup/gallon or 2 tablespoons/quart of tap water).
PERSON: Any person, individual, firm, corporation, association, partnership, or
any other form of association or organization.
PROCEDURE SURFACE: The skin area adjacent to and including the area where a
body art procedure is applied, any surface of an inanimate object that contacts
the patron's unclothed body during a body art procedure, or any associated work
area which may require sanitizing.
SANITIZE OR SANITIZING PROCEDURE: A process of reducing the number of disease
causing microorganisms on instruments, equipment or procedure surfaces to a
safe level in accordance with public health standards by a method approved by
the department of public health.
SHARPS: Objects capable of puncturing, lacerating or otherwise penetrating the
skin.
SHARPS CONTAINER: A rigid, leak and puncture resistant container designed
primarily for the containment of sharps. Sharps containers shall be clearly
labeled with the international biological hazard symbol.
STERILIZATION: A very powerful process resulting in the destruction of all
forms of microbial life, including highly resistant bacterial spores.
SUPPLIES: Products, other than equipment and instruments, used in the
preparation, performance, aftercare and cleanup of body art procedures.
TATTOO OR TATTOOING: Any method of placing ink or other pigment into or under
the skin or mucosa by the aid of needles or any other instruments used to
puncture the skin which results in permanent coloration of the skin or mucosa,
including all forms of cosmetic tattooing. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to perform body art procedures
without first obtaining a body art technician license from the city as provided
herein.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a body art
establishment without first obtaining a body art establishment license from the
city as provided herein.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to perform body art procedures
except within a licensed body art establishment. Body art procedures shall not
be performed in mobile or temporary vehicles or structures.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a body art establishment
to permit body art procedures to be performed by anyone who does not have a
valid body art technician license.
   (E)   Licenses shall not be transferable and must be renewed as provided in
section
4-11-3 of this chapter.
   (F)   Licensees shall comply at all times with the requirements of this
chapter and shall notify the city clerk within ten (10) days of any change of
the information required to be provided in accordance with section
4-11-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   (A)   Every applicant for a license as a body art technician shall submit an
application providing the applicant's name, date of birth, gender, residence
address, mailing address, home and work telephone numbers, place(s) of
employment as a body art technician, and training and experience in body art
procedures.
   (B)   Every applicant for a license as a body art establishment shall submit
an application providing the applicant's name (if a partnership or corporation,
the names and resident addresses of all partners, officers, directors and the
registered agent shall be included); proposed name of the body art
establishment and its street address, mailing address and hours of operation;
the names of all body art technicians and their duties; a description of all
body art procedures to be performed; an inventory of all equipment, instruments
and supplies to be utilized; the names and addresses of manufacturers and
suppliers of all equipment, instruments and supplies to be utilized; and the
name, local address and telephone number of the individual who shall be
responsible for operation of the body art establishment.
   (C)   Application forms may be obtained from, and returned to, the City
Clerk during normal business hours.
   (D)   The fee for a body art establishment license shall be four hundred
twenty dollars ($420.00) per year. The fee for a body art technician license
shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per year. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
   (E)   Upon determination that an applicant for a license meets the
requirements set forth herein and has paid the required license fee, the Mayor
shall issue the appropriate license to the applicant. All licenses shall be
issued with an effective date of May 1 and, unless earlier suspended or
revoked, shall expire on April 30 of the following year. Licenses may be
renewed by submitting a new application and paying the license fees required by
this section. The fees subject to this section shall be prorated for any
license issued after May 1 on a per diem basis. (Ord. 3078, 1-16-2018)
   (F)   Prior to the issuance or renewal of a body art establishment license,
the City building official and the Fire Chief shall inspect and determine that
the premises for which the license is sought complies with the City's building
and fire regulations. The Mayor shall not issue or renew a license until the
City building official and the Fire Chief have certified that the premises are
in compliance with said regulations. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-4: ESTABLISHMENT STANDARDS:
   (A)   All licenses shall be posted within the body art establishment in a
prominent and conspicuous area where they may be readily observed by patrons.
   (B)   Body art establishments shall be well ventilated and shall have an
artificial light source equivalent to at least twenty (20) foot-candles at
three feet (3') above floor level, and at least one hundred (100) foot-candles
at the level where body art procedures are performed and where instruments and
sharps are assembled.
   (C)   All surfaces where body art procedures are performed, including patron
chairs and benches, shall be of such construction as to be easily cleaned and
sanitized after each use. Liquid chemical germicide shall be used for cleaning
and sanitizing such surfaces.
   (D)   A separate hand sink supplied with liquid soap and disposable paper
towels shall be located within or immediately adjacent to all areas where body
art procedures are performed. Each hand sink shall serve no more than three (3)
body art technicians. In the absence of a separate washing sink, hand sinks may
be used for initial cleaning of instruments and equipment prior to sanitation
or sterilization procedures. In addition, the body art establishment shall
contain at least one bathroom with a sink and a toilet for use by patrons.
   (E)   A covered refuse receptacle shall be provided in each area where body
art procedures are performed and in each bathroom. These receptacles shall be
emptied daily. Refuse shall be removed from the premises at least weekly. All
refuse receptacles shall be covered and kept clean.
   (F)   Sharps shall be disposed of in sharps containers.
   (G)   All products used to check the flow of blood or to absorb blood shall
be disposed of immediately after use in appropriate covered containers, unless
the disposable product meets the definition of "biomedical waste". All
biomedical waste shall be disposed of as required by law.
   (H)   No animals of any kind shall be allowed in a body art establishment,
except service animals used by persons with disabilities (e.g., seeing eye
dogs). Fish aquariums are allowed in waiting rooms and nonprocedural areas.
   (I)   No insects, vermin or rodents shall be present in any part of a body
art establishment. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-5: PROHIBITIONS:
   (A)   No person, other than a person licensed to practice medicine under
Illinois law, shall tattoo or offer to tattoo a person under twenty one (21)
years of age.
   (B)   Except as provided in subsection (A) of this section with respect to
tattoos, no person, other than a person licensed to practice medicine under
Illinois law, shall perform or permit the performance of body art procedures
upon a person under eighteen (18) years of age without the presence, photo
identification and written consent of the minor's parent or legal guardian. A
licensee may refuse to perform a body art procedure on a person under eighteen
(18) years of age regardless of the parent's or guardian's consent.
   (C)   No person shall perform or permit the performance of body art
procedures on any person who appears to be under the influence of alcohol or
drugs or is incoherent for any reason.
   (D)   No person shall perform or permit the performance of body art
procedures on any skin or mucosa surface where a rash or any visible infection
is present.
   (E)   No person affected with boils, infected wounds, open sores, abrasions,
keloids, weeping dermatological lesions or acute respiratory infection shall
work in a body art establishment in any capacity in which the person could
contaminate equipment, instruments, supplies or procedure surfaces with body
substances or pathogenic organisms.
   (F)   No person shall perform or permit the performance of any procedure
implanting any objects under the skin, such as ball bearings or beads.
   (G)   No person shall perform any body art procedure while under the
influence of alcohol or drugs. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-6: PATRON'S MEDICAL HISTORY:
   (A)   Prior to performing any body art procedure, in order to evaluate the
patron's medical condition for receiving a body art procedure, the body art
technician shall specifically request from the patron verbally and in writing
the following information:
      1.   History of diabetes;
      2.   History of hemophilia;
      3.   History of skin disease, skin lesions or skin sensitivities to
soaps, disinfectants, etc.;
      4.   History of allergies or adverse reactions to pigments, dyes, or
other skin sensitivities;
      5.   History of epilepsy, seizures, fainting, or narcolepsy;
      6.   Current or recent medications which thin the blood or interfere with
healing expectations; and
      7.   Any other information that would aid in evaluating the patron's
healing expectations.
   (B)   Prior to performing any body art procedure, the body art technician
shall obtain a release form signed by the patron confirming that the body art
technician obtained the information required by subsection (A) of this section.
   (C)   The body art technician shall refuse to perform a body art procedure
if the patron refuses to disclose the information requested. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-
2007)
4-11-7: PERFORMANCE OF PROCEDURES:
   (A)   The body art technician shall at all times maintain a high degree of
personal cleanliness, conform to hygienic practices, wear clean clothes, and
keep his or her skin free of rash or infection.
   (B)   Before performing a body art procedure, the procedure surface shall be
washed with antiseptic liquid soap and water or an approved surgical skin
preparation. If shaving is necessary, a single use disposable razor shall be
used and then discarded. The reusable holder for the shaver, if any, shall be
sterilized. After shaving, the procedure surface shall be washed with
antiseptic liquid soap and water, and the washing pad shall be discarded.
   (C)   Immediately before performing a body art procedure on an individual,
the body art technician shall thoroughly wash his hands in hot running water
with antiseptic liquid soap or other sanitizing agent. The body art technician
shall then rinse his hands and dry them with disposable paper towels. This
process shall be done as many times as necessary to remove all contaminants
from the body art technician's hands. The body art technician shall also wash
his hands according to the method set forth herein at the conclusion of each
body art procedure.
   (D)   Body art technicians shall wear gloves on each hand during all body
art procedures. The body art technician shall wash his hands as provided in
subsection (C) of this section prior to putting on gloves. The gloves shall be
discarded after the completion of each body art procedure on an individual
patron. Under no circumstances shall the same gloves be used on more than one
person or for more than one body art procedure.
   (E)   If, prior to or while performing a body art procedure, the body art
technician's glove or gloves are pierced, torn or contaminated by contact with
any contaminated surface or object or by contact with a third person, the body
art technician shall immediately discard the gloves, repeat the hand washing
procedures described in subsection (C) of this section and put on a new pair of
gloves as described in subsection (D) of this section to complete the
procedure.
   (F)   If any equipment or instrument becomes contaminated during a body art
procedure, the body art procedure shall immediately be halted. The contaminated
instrument shall be replaced immediately with a sterilized instrument and the
contaminated equipment sanitized before the procedure may resume.
   (G)   After completing the body art procedure, the skin surface shall be
cleaned with an antiseptic liquid soap and allowed to dry. Sterile gauze
dressing shall then be fastened to the affected skin surface. The surface where
the body art procedure was performed, including any chairs or benches, shall be
cleaned and sanitized with liquid chemical germicide.
   (H)   Licensees shall comply at all times with the regulations of the
department of labor's occupational safety and health administration (29 CFR
1910.1030), as presently existing or hereafter amended, with respect to
occupational exposure to blood, bloodborne pathogens or other potentially
infectious materials. Said regulations are hereby incorporated into this
chapter by this reference. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-8: PATRON INSTRUCTIONS:
   (A)   Every person receiving a body art procedure shall be provided with
verbal and written instructions for aftercare of the body art procedure. The
instructions shall advise the patron of proper care for the healing of the body
specific to the body art procedure performed and to consult a physician at the
first sign of infection or swelling. The instructions shall include the name,
address and telephone number of the body art establishment and the name of the
body art technician who performed the body art procedure.
   (B)   The written instructions shall be signed and dated by both the patron
and the body art technician. The body art establishment shall retain a signed
original of the instructions and shall give a copy to the patron. (Ord. 2669,
12-3-2007)
4-11-9: RECORDS:
   (A)   The body art establishment shall keep a record of all body art
procedures performed. The record shall include: 1) the patron's name, date of
birth and address, 2) the date of the body art procedure, 3) the type and
location of each body art procedure performed and 4) the name of the body art
technician who performed each body art procedure. Signed copies of the release
form required by subsection
4-11-6(B) of this chapter and the instructions required by section
4-11-8 of this chapter shall also be kept. All records shall be available for
inspection by the city upon request.
   (B)   Records containing a patron's personal medical information shall be
kept confidential, except to the extent disclosure is necessary and authorized
by Illinois law in the administration and enforcement of this chapter.
   (C)   All records shall be retained by the body art establishment for at
least three (3) years. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-10: EQUIPMENT, INSTRUMENTS AND SUPPLIES:
   (A)   All equipment and instruments directly used in the performance of body
art procedures shall be specifically manufactured for this purpose and used
according to the manufacturer's instructions.
   (B)   Sterilized equipment, instruments and supplies shall be stored in
clean, dry, covered containers. No equipment, instruments or supplies that are
required to be sterilized shall be used if the package has been breached or the
expiration date has expired, without first repackaging and resterilizing the
equipment, instruments or supplies.
   (C)   All products used to check the flow of blood or to absorb blood shall
be disposable and discarded after a single use.
   (D)   All products applied to the skin, including body art stencils, shall
be disposable and discarded after a single use, except that acetate stencils
shall be allowed for multiple use if disinfecting procedures are performed
between each use. Petroleum jellies, soaps and other products used in the
application of stencils shall be dispensed and applied on the area to be
tattooed with sterile gauze or in a manner to prevent contamination of the
original container and its contents. The gauze shall be used only once and then
discarded.
   (E)   All inks, dyes, and pigments shall be specifically manufactured for
the performance of body art procedures and used according to the manufacturer's
instructions. The mixing of approved inks, dyes or pigments, or their dilution
with potable water, is acceptable. Immediately before applying a tattoo, the
quantity of the dye to be used shall be transferred from the dye bottle into
single use paper or plastic cups or caps. Upon completion of the tattoo, these
single use cups or caps and their contents shall be discarded.
   (F)   When assembling instruments, the body art technician shall wear gloves
and shall use medically recognized techniques to ensure that the instruments
and gloves are not contaminated.
   (G)   Single use items shall be discarded immediately after each use and
shall not be used with more than one patron for any reason.
   (H)   Reusable cloth items shall be mechanically washed with detergent and
dried after each use.
   (I)   The following process shall be followed after each use for all
instruments used for body art procedures that are not single use instruments:
      1.   The instrument shall be cleaned by following the manufacturer's
cleaning instructions. If there are no cleaning instructions, the instrument
shall be cleaned by scrubbing with an appropriate disinfectant and hot water to
remove blood and tissue residue.
      2.   The instrument shall be placed in an ultrasonic sterilizing unit,
which shall be operated in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions.
      3.   The instrument shall be packed individually in a peel pack
containing either a sterilizer indicator or internal temperature indicator and
sterilizer.
      4.   Peel packs shall be dated with an expiration date not to exceed six
(6) months. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-11: INSPECTION:
   (A)   Licensees shall be inspected as often as the city deems necessary to
ensure compliance with this chapter. At a minimum, inspections shall be made at
least every three (3) months. The costs of inspection shall be paid by the body
art establishment.
   (B)   Inspections shall be made by persons chosen and paid for by the body
art establishment. Inspections shall be made by either: 1) a licensed
environmental health practitioner, 2) a registered nurse, or 3) a person with a
bachelor of science degree in nursing, none of whom may be an employee of the
body art establishment. Additionally, the persons conducting the inspections
shall have knowledge of the following:
      1.   Anatomy, skin diseases, disorders and conditions, including
diabetes.
      2.   Infectious disease control, including waste disposal and hand
washing.
      3.   Sanitizing, disinfecting and sterilization methods.
      4.   Operation of equipment and instruments.
   (C)   Immediately following an inspection, the person conducting the
inspection shall furnish the inspection report to the city clerk. The
inspection report shall state that the licensee is in compliance with this
chapter or, if not in compliance, the nature of any violations with reference
to specific section numbers. The person conducting the inspection shall also
furnish a copy to the licensee.
   (D)   The city may conduct inspections of any licensee at any time to ensure
compliance with this chapter. The person conducting an inspection on behalf of
the city shall be chosen and paid for by the city. In the event a licensee
fails to satisfy an inspection paid for by the city, the licensee shall be
required to reimburse the city for the costs of the inspection in addition to
any other penalties or fines set forth in this chapter.
   (E)   The person conducting an inspection shall identify himself upon
entering a body art establishment. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
4-11-12: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES; PENALTIES:
   (A)   The mayor may suspend or revoke any license issued under this chapter
for any of the following reasons:
      1.   The licensee has violated any of the laws of the United States or
the state of Illinois relating in any way to the performance of body art
procedures, or any ordinance enacted by the city council.
      2.   The licensee has made a false statement as to any material fact on
its application for a license.
      3.   The licensee has permitted an unlawful, disorderly or immoral
practice within the body art establishment.
      4.   An agent or employee of the licensee has been found to have
committed any of the acts specified in subsections (A)1 through (A)3 of this
section.
   (B)   All hearings to determine whether a license shall be suspended or
revoked shall be conducted by the mayor. A notice of hearing shall be delivered
to the licensee by certified mail at the address listed in the licensee's
application at least seven (7) days prior to the hearing. The notice shall
specifically set forth the nature of the violation and the time and place of
the hearing. A certified court reporter shall be present and shall prepare an
official record of the proceedings. Within a reasonable time after the
conclusion of the hearing, but not later than ten (10) days after such
conclusion, the mayor shall file his written decision.
   (C)   If the conduct of a licensee constitutes a clear and present danger to
the public health, safety or general welfare, the mayor shall be authorized to
summarily suspend any license issued under this chapter until such time as a
hearing may be conducted. The mayor shall conduct a hearing within ten (10)
days of the suspension of a license pursuant to this subsection.
   (D)   All appeals from any decision of the mayor shall be reviewed pursuant
to the Illinois administrative review law.
   (E)   Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter
shall be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. Each day that a
violation occurs or is permitted to continue shall be deemed a separate
violation. (Ord. 2669, 12-3-2007)
CHAPTER 12
WATER WELLS
SECTION:
4-12-1: Purpose
4-12-2: Acts Prohibited, Permits Required
4-12-3: Definitions
4-12-4: Permits
4-12-5: Inspection
4-12-6: Standard
4-12-7: Penalty For Violation
4-12-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter provides for the issuance of permits for well drilling,
construction, repair and modification of water wells for the reason that the
groundwater of the city will not be contaminated or polluted and that water
obtained from wells will not jeopardize the health, safety or welfare of the
people, and preserve the present water table level. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
4-12-2: ACTS PROHIBITED, PERMITS REQUIRED:
No person shall, within the city limits, be permitted to drill their own well
when said person's land is within two hundred feet (200') of the public water
supply. All well applications must be reviewed and approved by the city council
before a permit can be issued for same. (Ord. 2053, 12-15-1997; amd. Ord. 2549,
10-3-2005)
4-12-3: DEFINITIONS:
CONSTRUCTION: Shall include, but not be limited to, the digging or excavating
of any water well.
MODIFICATION OR REPAIR: Shall include, but not be limited to, the deepening of
a well or the reperforation or replacement of a well casing.
WELL OR WATER WELL: Any artificial excavation constructed by any method for the
purpose of extracting water from, or injecting water into, the underground.
(Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
4-12-4: PERMITS:
   (A)   Applications: Applications for permits to construct, repair or modify
any water well shall be made to the building official of the city and shall
include the following:
      1.   A plot plan indicating the exact location of the well with respect
to the following items within a radius of two hundred feet (200') of the well:
         (a)   Public water lines.
         (b)   Public sewer lines.
         (c)   Property lines.
         (d)   Existing wells.
         (e)   Septic systems.
         (f)   Existing or proposed buildings.
         (g)   Access roads or streets.
      2.   Location of the property.
      3.   Owner of the property.
      4.   Name of the person who will construct, repair and/or modify the
well.
      5.   Depth of the well.
      6.   Use of the well.
      7.   Other information as may be necessary to determine if underground
waters will be protected.
   (B)   Fees:
      1.   Permit Application Fee:
         (a)   Every permit application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable
fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), none of which shall be refundable.
      2.   Permit Fee:
         (a)   Same fee schedule as listed in subsection
7-1-9(B)3 of this code. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
         (b)   Prior to issuance of a permit the person applying for a permit
shall appear before the Dixon city council for a review of the appropriate
ordinances of the city concerning public water supplies and for a review of the
information provided in the application for permit. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997; amd.
Ord. 2549, 10-3-2005)
   (C)   Expiration: Permits shall expire six (6) months from the issuance
date. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997; amd. 2020 Code)
4-12-5: INSPECTION:
The building official of the city and any water department employee may at any
and all reasonable times enter any and all places, property enclosures and
structures for the purpose of making examinations and investigations to
determine whether any provision of the codes of the city relating to the
drilling of wells and the public water supply are being violated. (Ord. 2006,
8-4-1997)
4-12-6: STANDARD:
Standards for the construction, repair and modification of water wells shall be
as provided for under appropriate state agencies, county agencies and state
law. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997)
4-12-7: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
Any person, firm or corporation who does any work for which a permit is
required by this chapter and who fails to apply for and pay the fee for a
permit, or who otherwise violates any other provision of this chapter, shall
upon conviction be fined an amount not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense in
accordance with the provisions of this code. (Ord. 2006, 8-4-1997; amd. 2020
Code)
CHAPTER 13
PUBLIC CAMPING
SECTION:
4-13-1: Public Camping Declared A Nuisance
4-13-2: Regulation Of Public Camping Necessary To Promote Public Health
4-13-3: Public Camping Not Intended Use Of Public Property
4-13-4: Definitions
4-13-5: Public Camping Prohibited
4-13-6: Exceptions To Prohibition
4-13-7: Removal Of Campsite
4-13-8: Disposition And Release Of Personal Property
4-13-9: Penalty; Mitigation
4-13-1: PUBLIC CAMPING A NUISANCE:
Public Camping, as the term is defined in this chapter, is hereby declared to
be a nuisance within the city for the reasons identified in Ordinance No. 3422
adopted November, 2024.
(Ord. 3422, 11-18-20224)
4-13-2: REGULATION OF PUBLIC CAMPING NECESSARY TO PROMOTE PUBLIC HEALTH:
In an effort to address the public health concerns identified in Ordinance No.
3422 adopted November, 2024, the city declares it necessary or expedient for
the promotion of health or the suppression of diseases to regulate Public
Camping, as that term is defined in this chapter, within the corporate limits
of the city.
(Ord. 3422, 11-18-20224)
4-13-3: PUBLIC CAMPING NOT INTENDED USE OF PUBLIC PROPERTY:
Except for those parcels of property specifically designated by the city in any
subsequent ordinance, the city hereby declares that none of its property is
permitted nor intended to be used for Public Camping, as the term is defined in
this chapter.
(Ord. 3422, 11-18-20224)
4-13-4: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions apply to this chapter:
 
BEDDING:                  A sleeping bag, or any other material, used for
                          bedding purposes.
                          Any physical space that is not within an established
                          structure, where Bedding or any stove or fire is
                          placed, established or maintained for the purpose of
CAMPSITE:                 maintaining a temporary place to live, whether or not
                          such place incorporates the use of any tent, lean-to,
                          shack or any other structure, or any vehicle or part
                          thereof.
                          Items which would otherwise constitute Personal
                          Property under the terms of this chapter, but which
                          (i) has no apparent utility or monetary value; (ii)
                          Personal Property which is unsanitary to store or
                          otherwise maintain; (iii) any weapon possessed
EXEMPT PERSONAL PROPERTY: illegally; (iv) drug paraphernalia; (v) items
                          appearing to be stolen or otherwise appearing to be
                          evidence of a crime; (vi) items which the person
                          cannot demonstrate the requisite lawful authority to
                          possess; and, (vii) any items of food which can
                          reasonably be expected to spoil or otherwise perish
                          within the next thirty (30) days.
                          Any item reasonably recognizable as belonging to a
PERSONAL PROPERTY:        person and having apparent utility or monetary value,
                          except for Exempt Personal Property.
PUBLIC CAMPING:           To cause or participate in the establishment of, or
                          the act of remaining in or at, a Campsite.
 
(Ord. 3422, 11-18-20224)
4-13-5: PUBLIC CAMPING PROHIBITED:
   (A)   No person may sleep, nor otherwise engage in Public Camping, on a
public sidewalk, street, alley, lane, other public right-of-way, park, bench,
or any other publicly-owned property, nor on or under any bridge or viaduct, at
any time.
   (B)   No person may sleep, nor otherwise engage in Public Camping, in any
pedestrian or vehicular entrance to public or private property abutting a
public right-of-way.
   (C)   No person may sleep, nor otherwise engage in Public Camping, on any
real property owned or otherwise maintained by the City.
   (D)   No person may park a vehicle overnight within the City for the purpose
of sleeping or otherwise engaging in Public Camping in said vehicle.
   (E)   For the purposes of this section, the act of parking or leaving a
vehicle parked for two (2) consecutive hours, and/or remaining within a public
vehicle on any property under the jurisdiction of the City for the purpose of
Public Camping, for two (2) consecutive hours without permission from the city
council of the city, between the hours of midnight and 6:00 a.m., shall be
considered a violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 3422, 11-18-20224)
4-13-6: EXCEPTIONS TO PROHIBITION:
   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth in this chapter, it shall
not be a violation to engage in Public Camping when done (i) in a manner
specifically authorized by this code; (ii) after a formal declaration of the
city in emergency circumstances; or, (iii) upon resolution of the city council,
the same may exempt a special event from the prohibitions of this chapter, if
the city council finds such exemption to be in the public interest and
consistent with the goals and objectives of the city council, and with such
conditions imposed as the city council deems necessary. Any conditions imposed
will include a condition requiring that the applicant provide evidence of
adequate insurance coverage and agree to indemnify the city for any liability,
damage or expense incurred by the city as a result of the activities of the
applicant. Any findings by the city council shall specify the exact dates and
location covered by the exemption.
(Ord. 3422, 11-18-20224)
4-13-7: REMOVAL OF CAMPSITE:
   Removal of a Campsite in violation of this chapter may occur under the
following circumstances:
   (A)   Prior to removing a Campsite, the city shall post a notice, 24-hours
in advance of the removal, unless immediate removal of the Campsite is deemed
to be necessary for one of the reasons in subsection 1-4, below. If such
immediate removal is undertaken, the basis for causing the immediate removal of
such Campsite should be adequately documented by the appropriate person(s).
      1.   Immediate removal of the Campsite is necessary to maintain access to
a property;
      2.   Immediate removal of the Campsite is necessary to maintain the
sanitary condition of a property;
      3.   Immediate removal of the Campsite is necessary because the Campsite
is an obstruction to any public right-of-way; or,
      4.   Immediate removal of the Campsite is necessary because the Campsite
poses a risk to the health and safety of the city and its residents.
   (B)   Upon any action pursuant to this section, the person(s) causing such
action to be taken shall inform an appropriate agency delivering social
services to homeless individuals in the city of the location of the Campsite
and the persons found to be in violation of this chapter, so said agency may
determine whether or not it would be appropriate to offer its services to those
persons.
   (C)   If a 24-hour notice has been posted, and the 24-hour notice period has
passed, then the Campsite, as well as all Personal Property thereon, shall be
removed by the appropriate person(s) acting on behalf of the city.
   (D)   No portion of this section shall be construed to prohibit any person
found to be engaging in Public Camping from removing their Personal Property
from the Campsite; however, such Personal Property that constitutes Exempt
Personal Property and which a reasonably prudent law enforcement officer,
exercising the applicable constitutional standard, would conclude that said
Exempt Personal Property constitutes items appearing to be stolen or otherwise
appearing to be evidence of a crime, and/or items which the person cannot
demonstrate the requisite lawful authority to possess, may be retained and
stored as evidence.
(Ord. 3422, 11-18-20224)
4-13-8: DISPOSITION AND RELEASE OF PERSONAL PROPERTY:
   (A)   All Personal Property removed from any Campsite which is not Exempt
Personal Property shall be stored by the appropriate law enforcement agency of
the city for a minimum of thirty (30) days, during which time it shall be
reasonably available for and released to an individual confirming ownership.
   (B)   All Exempt Personal Property may be disposed of or retained as
evidence by the appropriate law enforcement agency of the city.
(Ord. 3422, 11-18-20224)
4-13-9: PENALTY; MITIGATION:
   (A)   The penalty for any person’s first violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be $75.
   (B)   The penalty for any person’s second violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be $150.
   (C)   The penalty for any person’s third violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be $350.
   (D)   The penalty for any person’s fourth violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be $500.
   (E)   The penalty for any person’s fifth violation of this chapter within a
rolling twenty-four (24) month period shall be $750.
   (F)   The penalty for any person’s sixth or subsequent violation of this
chapter within a rolling twenty-four (24) month period may be a monetary
penalty of $750 or incarceration for a period not exceeding the maximum time
allowed pursuant to Section 1-2-9 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-
2-9.
   (G)   As a substitute for any monetary penalty assessed pursuant to A-F,
above, and if consented to by the city, the penalty assessed to any person
found in violation of this chapter may be that said person must engage in
public service by cleaning the rights-of-way and other public facilities of the
city for an amount of time that, if the person found to have violated this
chapter was being paid the minimum wage under Illinois law, the amount paid for
that person’s labors would have been equal to the monetary penalty assessed
under this chapter.
   (H)   he city is hereby empowered to exercise all powers afforded to it, at
law or in equity, to collect any fines assessed against a person pursuant to
this chapter, including but not limited to seeking incarceration of said person
for a period of time that conforms with Section 1-2-9 of the Illinois Municipal
Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-9.
   (I)   In the imposition of any penalty pursuant to this section, the penalty
shall be mitigated by whether or not the person immediately removed all
Personal Property and litter, including but not limited to bottles, cans, and
garbage, from the Campsite after the person was informed that the person was in
violation of this chapter.
   (J)   A separate offense of this chapter shall be deemed committed on each
day on which a violation occurs or continues.
   (K)   In addition to any other remedy provided by law or this chapter, any
person found in violation of this chapter may be immediately removed from the
premises where the Campsite is located.
(Ord. 3422, 11-18-20224)
TITLE 5
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL LICENSES
SECTION:
5-1-1: Applications
5-1-2: Forms
5-1-3: Fees
5-1-4: Duration Of Licenses
5-1-5: Approval Of Licenses
5-1-6: Obedience To Regulations
5-1-7: Licenses Not Assignable
5-1-8: Posting And Exhibiting
5-1-9: Exemption
5-1-1: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for licenses and permits required by this code shall be made in
writing to the clerk in the absence of provision to the contrary. Each
application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or license
desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee to be
paid and shall contain such additional information as may be required herein.
If the applicant is a partnership the application shall be signed by all of the
partners. (1950 Code)
5-1-2: FORMS:
Forms for all licenses and permits and applications therefor shall be furnished
by the clerk. (1950 Code)
5-1-3: FEES:
In the absence of provision to the contrary all fees and charges for licenses
and permits shall be paid in advance to the clerk at the time the application
is made, and when an applicant has not engaged in a business for which a
license is sought until after the expiration of a part of the current fiscal
year the license fees shall be prorated by quarters and the fee paid for each
quarter or fraction thereof during which the business has been or will be
conducted. Except as otherwise provided all license fees shall become a part of
the general corporate fund. No licensee shall be entitled to a refund of any
portion of any license fee paid to the city by reason of the fact that he
ceases to conduct the business for which the license was granted prior to the
end of the term of the license. (1950 Code)
5-1-4: DURATION OF LICENSES:
No license shall be granted for a longer period than one year and all licenses
shall terminate on the last day of the fiscal year of the city. (1950 Code)
5-1-5: APPROVAL OF LICENSES:
All applications for licenses shall be referred to the mayor, council or local
liquor control commissioner for approval or disapproval where required by the
provisions of this code. Upon the approval of the application for any license,
where required, and the payment of the required license fee, the clerk shall
issue a license. Where the approval of the mayor, council or local liquor
commissioner is required, licenses shall be executed by the mayor in the name
of the city and attested by the clerk under the corporate seal and shall state
the name of the licensee, the time for which granted and any other information
that may be required. Where such approval is not required, the clerk shall
execute and issue licenses in the name of the city and under the corporate seal
thereof, and each license shall state the name of the licensee, the time for
which granted, and any other information that may be required. (1950 Code)
5-1-6: OBEDIENCE TO REGULATIONS:
All licenses which may be issued under any provision of this code shall be
subject to the regulations which may be in force at the time of the issuing
thereof, or which may subsequently be established by the council. If any person
so licensed shall violate any of the provisions thereof, he shall be liable to
be proceeded against for any fine or penalty imposed thereby, and his license
shall be subject to be revoked by the council, unless otherwise provided in
this chapter. (1950 Code)
5-1-7: LICENSES NOT ASSIGNABLE:
Except as otherwise provided, no license granted under this chapter or any
other provision of this code shall be assignable or transferable without
permission of the council, nor shall any such license authorize any person to
do business or act under it but the person named therein. (1950 Code)
5-1-8: POSTING AND EXHIBITING:
Any person having obtained a license shall, when demanded by any officer of the
city, forthwith exhibit the same to such officer and if the business of the
licensee be local he shall immediately upon the receipt of his license cause
the same to be and remain posted in some conspicuous place in his business
establishment and if any such licensee shall fail or refuse to exhibit his
license when demanded as aforesaid, or neglect or refuse to post the same as
herein required, he shall be subject to the general penalty regulation of this
code. (1950 Code)
5-1-9: EXEMPTION:
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to licenses required for
animals. (1950 Code)
CHAPTER 2
OCCUPATION TAXES
SECTION:
5-2-1: Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax
5-2-2: Municipal Service Occupation Tax
5-2-3: Municipal Utility Tax
5-2-1: MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
Commencing July 1, 2005, a nonhome rule municipal retailers' occupation tax of
one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged
in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail in the city of
Dixon. Such tax shall not apply to the sale of an item of tangible personal
property which is titled and registered by an agency of the state of Illinois;
the sale of prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, and medical
appliances; the sale of insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles
used by diabetics; or the sale of food for human consumption that is to be
consumed off the premises where it is sold, other than alcoholic beverages,
soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption. (Ord.
2507, 11-15-2004)
5-2-2: MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
Commencing July 1, 2005, a nonhome rule municipal service occupation tax of
one-half (1/2) of one percent (1%) is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged
within the city of Dixon in the business of making sales of service on the
selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such servicemen
or servicewomen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form
of real estate as an incident to a sale of service. Such tax shall not apply to
the sale of prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, and medical
appliances; the sale of insulin, urine testing materials, syringes, and needles
used by diabetics; or the sale of food for human consumption that is to be
consumed off the premises where it is sold, other than alcoholic beverages,
soft drinks, and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption. (Ord.
2507, 11-15-2004)
5-2-3: MUNICIPAL UTILITY TAX:
   (A)   Tax Imposed: A tax is imposed on all persons engaged in the following
occupations or privileges:
      1.   Persons engaged in the business of transmitting messages by means of
electricity, at the rate of three and one-half percent (31/2%) of the gross
receipts from such business originating within the corporate limits of the
city.
      2.   Persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying,
furnishing, or selling gas for use or consumption within the corporate limits
of the city, and not for resale, at the rate of three and one-half percent (31/
2%) of the gross receipts therefrom.
      3.   Persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying,
furnishing, or selling electricity for use or consumption within the corporate
limits of the city and not for resale, at the rate of three and one-half
percent (31/2%) of the gross receipts therefrom.
   (B)   Exemptions: No tax is imposed by this chapter with respect to any
transaction in interstate commerce or otherwise to the extent to which such
business may not, under the constitution and statutes of the United States, be
made subject to taxation by this state or any political subdivision thereof;
nor shall any person engaged in the business of distributing, supplying,
furnishing or selling gas or electricity, or engaged in the business of
transmitting messages be subject to taxation under the provisions of this
chapter for such transactions as are or may become subject to taxation under
the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1 of the "municipal
retailers' occupation tax act" of the Illinois municipal code, as amended.
   (C)   Tax Additional Payment: Such tax shall be in addition to the payment
of money, or value of products or services furnished to this municipality by
the taxpayer as compensation for the use of its streets, alleys or other public
places, or installation and maintenance therein, thereon or thereunder of
poles, wires, pipes or other equipment used in the operation of the taxpayer's
business. (Ord. 1383, 10-5-1987)
   (D)   Definitions: For the purposes of this section the following
definitions shall apply:
   GROSS RECEIPTS: The consideration received for the transmission of messages,
or for distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas or electricity, for
use or consumption and not for resale, as the case may be; and for all services
rendered in connection therewith valued in money, whether received in money or
otherwise, including cash, credit, services, and property of every kind and
material and for all services rendered therewith; and shall be determined
without any deduction on account of the cost of transmitting said messages
without any deduction on account of the cost of the service, product or
commodity supplied, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, or any
other expenses whatsoever. "Gross receipts" shall not include receipts received
from the city of Dixon for the sale to said municipality of any of the utility
products or services mentioned above.
Gross receipts shall not include charges added to customers' bills to recover
the surcharge imposed under the emergency telephone system act. For utility
bills issued on or after May 1, 1996, but before May 1, 1997, and for receipts
from those utility bills, "gross receipts" shall not include one-third (1/3)
of: 1) amounts added to customers' bills under section 9-222 of the public
utilities act, or 2) amounts added to customers' bills by taxpayers who are not
subject to rate regulation by the Illinois commerce commission for the purpose
of recovering any of the tax liabilities described in section 9-222 of the
public utilities act. For utility bills issued on or after May 1, 1997, but
before May 1, 1998, and for receipts from those utility bills, "gross receipts"
shall not include two-thirds (2/3) of: 3) amounts added to customers' bills
under section 9-222 of the public utilities act, or 4) amount added to
customers' bills by taxpayers who are not subject to rate regulation by the
Illinois commerce commission for the purpose of recovering any of the tax
liabilities described in section 9-222 of the public utilities act. For utility
bills issued on or after May 1, 1998, and for receipts from those utility
bills, "gross receipts" shall not include: 5) amounts added to customers' bills
under section 9-222 of the public utilities act, or 6) amounts added to
customers' bills by taxpayers who are not subject to rate regulation by the
Illinois commerce commission for the purpose of recovering any of the tax
liabilities described in section 9-222 of the public utilities act.
   PERSONS: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership,
association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, municipal
corporation or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver, trustee,
conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court.
   TRANSMITTING MESSAGES: In addition to the usual and popular meaning of
person to person communication, shall include the furnishing, for a
consideration, of services or facilities (whether owned or leased), or both, to
persons in connection with the transmission of messages where such persons do
not, in turn, receive any consideration in connection therewith, but shall not
include such furnishing of services or facilities to persons for the
transmission of messages to the extent that any such services or facilities for
the transmission of messages are furnished for a consideration, by such persons
to other persons, for the transmission of messages. (Ord. 1383, 10-5-1987; amd.
Ord. 1954, 9-3-1996)
   (E)   Effective Date: This chapter shall take effect after publication and
the tax provided for herein shall be based on the gross receipts, as herein
defined, actually paid to the taxpayer for services billed on or after December
1, 1987. (Ord. 1383, 10-5-1987)
   (F)   Filing Tax Return: On or before the last day of January, 1988, the
taxpayers described in subsection (A) of this section shall make a return of
the city treasurer for the month of December, 1987. Said returns shall state:
      1.   Taxpayer's name;
      2.   Taxpayer's principal place of business;
      3.   Taxpayer's gross receipts during those months upon which the basis
of the tax is imposed;
      4.   Amount of tax;
      5.   Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate
authorities may require.
On or before the last day of every month thereafter, each taxpayer shall make a
like return to the city treasurer for a corresponding one month period.
The taxpayer making the return herein provided for shall, at the time of making
such return, pay to the city treasurer, the amount of tax herein imposed;
provided that in connection with any return the taxpayer may, if he so elects,
report and pay an amount based upon his total billings of business subject to
the tax during the period for which the return is made (exclusive of any
amounts previously billed) with prompt adjustments of later payments based upon
any differences between such billings and the taxable gross receipts. (Ord.
1385, 10-13-1987)
   (G)   Erroneous Payment: If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been
paid which was not due under the provisions of this chapter, whether as the
result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be
credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this chapter from the
taxpayer who made the erroneous payment; provided that no amounts erroneously
paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a claim therefor shall be
so credited.
   (H)   Recover Tax Due: No action to recover any amount of tax due under the
provisions of this chapter shall be commenced more than three (3) years after
the due date of such amount.
   (I)   Failure To Pay Tax; Penalty: Any taxpayer who fails to make a return,
or who makes a fraudulent return, or who wilfully violates any other provision
of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) and, in addition, shall be liable in a civil action for the
amount of tax due.
   (J)   Copy Sent To Utilities; Publication: The clerk shall send a certified
copy of this chapter to the utilities involved, and is directed to publish this
chapter in pamphlet form. (Ord. 1383, 10-5-1987)
CHAPTER 3

No property shall be sold or exposed for sale at auction in any public street
or alley in the city, and all auctions shall be so conducted that no portion of
the bidders or bystanders will be compelled to stand or remain on the street or
sidewalk so as to obstruct the free travel thereon. (1950 Code)

Any auctioneer who shall exhibit or offer for sale at auction any article of
personal property, and sell it to any bidder, and who shall afterwards
substitute any article in lieu of that offered and sold to the bidder, shall
forfeit his license and be subject to the general penalty provisions of this
code 1 . (1950 Code)

CHAPTER 4
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES
SECTION:
5-4-1: Tax Or License Fee
5-4-2: Annual Payment
5-4-3: Agent To Report
5-4-4: Nonpayment
5-4-5: Expenditure Of Funds
5-4-1: TAX OR LICENSE FEE:
All companies not incorporated under the laws of this state and which are
engaged in effecting fire insurance in the city shall pay to the treasurer of
the foreign fire insurance board for the maintenance, use and benefit of the
fire department thereof, a sum equal to two percent (2%) of the gross receipts
received by the companies or their agency or agents as premiums for fire
insurance on property located within the city. (1950 Code; amd. 2020 Code)
5-4-2: ANNUAL PAYMENT:
The companies shall pay to the treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board on
July 15 of each year a sum equal to the foregoing rate specified in section
5-4-1 of this chapter. The sum herein named shall be a license fee upon all
such companies transacting business within the city and shall be paid to the
treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board for the maintenance, use and
benefit of the fire department of the city. (1950 Code; amd. 2020 Code)
5-4-3: AGENT TO REPORT:
Each person who shall act in the city as agent or otherwise, for or on behalf
of any such company shall, on or before July 15 of each year, render to the
treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board, a full, true and just account,
verified by his oath, of all the premiums which, during the year ending on each
July 1 preceding such report, shall have been received by him, or any other
person for him in behalf of any such company and shall specify in the report
the amounts received for fire insurance. (1950 Code; amd. 2020 Code)
5-4-4: NONPAYMENT:
If such account be not rendered on or before the day herein designated for that
purpose, or if the rates shall remain unpaid after that day, it shall be
unlawful for any company so in default to transact any business of insurance in
the city until the requisitions shall have been fully complied with; but this
provision shall not relieve any company from the payment of any risk that may
be taken in violation hereof. (1950 Code)
5-4-5: EXPENDITURE OF FUNDS:
All monies received by the treasurer of the foreign fire insurance board under
the provisions of this chapter shall be appropriated to be used for the
maintenance, use and benefit of the department 1 . (1950 Code; amd. 2020 Code)
