5-13-8: RESTRICTIONS ON LOCATION:
   (A)   General Restrictions On Location: Except in locations where licenses
have been previously granted, no license shall be issued for the sale at retail
of any alcoholic liquor within one hundred (100) feet of any church, school
other than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home for aged or
indigent persons or for veterans, their spouses or children or any military or
naval station, provided, that this prohibition shall not apply to hotels
offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to restaurants, food
shops or other places where sale of alcoholic liquors is not the principal
business carried on.
   (B)   Zoning: No license shall be issued to any premises unless the sale or
distribution of alcoholic liquor at such premises complies with the applicable
Zoning Ordinance for the City.
   (C)   Restriction On Premises Of Class F Or F-1 Licenses: No Class F or F-
1 license shall be issued unless a separate area is established for the display
of alcoholic liquors, exclusive of wine and beer.
   (D)   Restriction On Premises Of Class G-1 And Class G-2 Licenses: No Class
G-1 or Class G-2 license shall be granted to any premises where gasoline is
sold except the license may be granted where the sale of gasoline is in
conjunction with a convenience store having actual retail space of one thousand
five hundred (1,500) square feet or more.
   (E)   Consumption Of Alcohol Or Possession Of Open Container In A Public
Place: No person shall consume any alcoholic liquor or have in his or her
possession any open container of any alcoholic liquor in any public place
within the City except: 1) on premises licensed for the retail sale and
consumption of alcoholic liquors, or 2) as otherwise provided in this chapter,
or 3) as permitted by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner. The Local Liquor
Control Commissioner may grant such written permission only to not for profit
corporations incorporated for a period of not less than three (3) years and
organized and operating under the laws of the State of Illinois for
educational, charitable or civic purposes. The grant of permission may contain
such further terms, conditions and restrictions regarding the number of days,
the location, hours and time as the Local Liquor Control Commissioner deems
necessary and in the best interests of the City. For purposes of this section,
"public place" means any street, sidewalk, park, alley, dedicated public right-
of-way or area of a business where the public is invited, but shall not include
residential property.
   F.   Restriction On Premises Of Class F-2 Licenses: No Class F-2 license
shall be issued unless a separate area is established for the on premises sale
and consumption of beer and wine. No beer and wine may be consumed outside of
such separate area.
(Ord. 715, 8-21-1972, eff. 11-1-1972; amd. Ord. 2256, 6-19-2000; Ord. 2643, 6-
4-2007; Ord. 3031, 3-20-2017; Ord. 3186, 2-18-2020; 2020 Code)
5-13-9: RESTRICTIONS ON TIME OF SALE 1 :
No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, delivered, transferred, distributed or given
away upon or about any licensed premises by anyone at any time except those
times permitted by this section.
   (A)   General Restrictions On Time Of Sale: No alcoholic liquor shall be
sold, delivered, transferred, distributed or given away upon or about any
licensed premises by anyone except during the following periods of time on the
following days:
      1.   On the days of Monday through Saturday from six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
to one o'clock (1:00) A.M. of the following day.
      2.   For those licenses only which permit the sale of alcoholic liquor on
Sundays: On Sundays from eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00)
P.M. Notwithstanding the foregoing, a licensee having a Class A-1, B-1, E-1, F-
1, G-1 or O license may remain open to the public to sell, deliver, transfer or
distribute alcoholic liquor on Sundays from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. to eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. A licensee having a temporary license as defined in
subsection
5-13-5(M), and sections
5-13-19 and
5-13-19-5 of this chapter may apply for written permission from the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner, which permission may be given in his or her sole
discretion, to sell, deliver, transfer or distribute alcoholic liquor on
Sundays from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. to eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
      3.   A licensee having a Class F, F-1, F-2, G-1, I, or I-1 license may
remain open to the public to sell, deliver, transfer, distribute or give away
alcoholic liquor only: a) during regular retail store hours, b) during times
specified in this section, and c) on the days specified for that license.
   (B)   New Year's Eve Exception: On the evening of December 31 of one year to
January 1 of the following year (which period is commonly known as New Year's
Eve), licensed premises may sell alcoholic beverages from six o'clock (6:00)
A.M. of December 31 of one year until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. on January 1 of
the following year. If December 31 of any year is a Sunday, alcoholic liquor
may be sold between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on December 31 to
one o'clock (1:00) A.M. of January 1 of the following year.
   (C)   Holiday Exception: On the Sunday evening of any Sunday which precedes
a legal holiday as affirmed by the Mayor of the City of Dixon, licensed
premises may sell alcoholic beverages until one o'clock (1:00) A.M. of the
following day. This exception shall only apply in those instances where the
Mayor of the City of Dixon has affirmed that the Monday following the Sunday in
question is a legal holiday.
   (D)   Rules For Class O License: Alcoholic liquor may be sold, delivered,
transferred, distributed or given away on the premises during no more than
thirty (30) hours per calendar month. The holder of a Class O license shall, at
least five (5) days before the commencement of each month, provide the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner with a written schedule of anticipated hours for
the following month, including closing times. The schedule may be amended only
upon the prior approval of the Local Liquor Control Commissioner. Nothing in
this subsection shall limit the ability of the holder of Class O license to
apply for a temporary license under subsection
5-13-5(M) of this chapter.
   (E)   Rules For Class N: No beer or wine brought onto the premises of a
Class N license may be consumed after ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. on days the
licensee is open. All beer and wine shall be removed from the licensed premises
at that time. Opened beer and wine shall be disposed of pursuant to section
5-13-5(S) of this chapter. Patrons with unopened beer or wine shall be required
to leave the licensed premises or dispose of the same pursuant to section
5-13-5(S) of this chapter.
   (F)   Rules for Class P License: Alcoholic liquor may be sold only in strict
conformance with the requirements set forth in section
5-13-5(V) of this chapter.
   (G)   Rules For Class T License: Alcoholic liquor may be sold only in strict
conformance with the requirements set forth in subsection 5-13-5(W) of this
chapter. (Ord. 1610, 8-19-1991; amd. Ord. 2356, 2-18-2020; Ord. 2498, 9-7-2004;
Ord. 3081, 2-20-2018; Ord. 3129, 3-18-2019; Ord. 3186, 2-18-2020; Ord. 3211, 9-
21-2020; Ord. 3231, 5-3-2021; Ord. 3324, 9-19-2022)
 
Notes
1 1. It is the intention of the City Council that this section control the
  times that alcoholic liquor may be sold or dispensed.
5-13-10: CLOSING HOURS; EXCEPTION 1 :
   (A)   General Closing Hours:
      1.   No person other than a licensee or an employee of a licensee shall
remain upon any licensed premises for any period of time longer than one-half
(1/2) hour following the time specified in section
5-13-9 of this chapter as the time when the sale, distribution, transfer or
gift of alcoholic liquor must terminate.
      2.   No person including a licensee or an employee of a licensee shall
remain upon any licensed premises for any period of time longer than eighty
(80) minutes following the time specified in section
5-13-9 of this chapter as the time when the sale, distribution, transfer or
gift of alcoholic liquor must terminate. At no time while the licensee, or his
employees or agents, are upon the premises for the purpose of operating,
controlling, maintaining or cleaning the premises, shall the licensee or
employee or agent consume, sell, deliver, transfer, distribute or give away any
alcoholic beverage on said premises; and during said times the doors of the
licensed premises shall be secured to the general public.
      3.   No licensee, employee or agent of a licensee shall permit any other
person to remain on the licensed premises beyond the closing hours specified in
subsection (A)1 of this section and in section
5-13-9 of this chapter.
   (B)   Exception: Persons and premises having a Class A, A-1, B, B-1, C or C-
1 license may remain open after the time designated in subsection (A) of this
section but only for the sale of food or beverages other than alcoholic liquor.
   (C)   Special Permit Application: A licensee may apply to the Liquor
Commission for a special permit to allow the licensee, its agent or employees,
to be upon the licensed premises at other times for the purpose of remodeling
or redecorating. Such permit shall be issued only if a valid building permit
for such redecorating or remodeling, if necessary, has been issued by the
building official of the City.
   (D)   Exception For Class F, F-1, G-1, I, Or I-1 License: Persons and
premises having a Class F, F-1, G-1, I, or I-1 license may remain open after
the time designated in section
5-13-9 of this chapter but only for the sale of food products, drugs, gasoline
and retail items other than alcoholic liquor.
   (E)   Exception For Class N License: Persons and premises having a Class N
license may remain open after the time designated in section
5-13-9(E) of this chapter; provided, that all beer and wine shall be removed
from the licensed premises at that time. (Ord. 1612, 8-19-1991; amd. Ord. 2205,
1-3-2000; Ord. 2498, 9-7-2004; Ord. 3186, 2-18-2020; Ord. 3211, 9-21-2020)
 
Notes
  1. It is the intention of the City Council that this section control the
  times when patrons must vacate licensed premises and control the times when
  licensees or employees must vacate licensed premises to ensure adequate
1 enforcement of this liquor ordinance and to protect the owners of such
  premises against unauthorized intrusion into their premises by persons
  committing or attempting to commit burglary, theft, criminal damage to
  property or criminal trespass.
5-13-11: UNLAWFUL SALES:
   (A)   No licensee, nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent
or employee of such licensee, shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to
any person under the age of twenty one (21) years or to any intoxicated person,
except as provided in 235 ILCS 5/6-16.1. No person, after purchasing or
otherwise obtaining alcoholic liquor, should sell, give or deliver such
alcoholic liquor to another person under the age of twenty one (21) years,
except in the performance of religious ceremony or service and under the
conditions of subsection (D) of this section.
   (B)   Any licensee, or his agent or employee, may refuse to sell or serve
alcoholic beverages to any person who is unable to produce adequate written
evidence of identity and of the fact that he or she is over the age of twenty
one (21) years. For the purpose of this subsection, adequate written evidence
of age and identity of the person is a document issued by a Federal, state,
county or municipal government, or subdivision or agency thereof, including,
but not limited to, a motor vehicle operator's license, a registration
certificate issued under the Federal Selective Service Act, or an
identification card issued to a member of the armed forces.
   (C)   If a licensee or his agents or employees believes or has reason to
believe that a sale or delivery of any alcoholic liquor is prohibited because
of the nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making such a sale
or delivery demand presentation of some form of positive identification,
containing proof of age, issued by a public officer in the performance of his
official duties.
   (D)   This section does not apply to the possession, dispension or
consumption of alcoholic beverages by persons participating in the performance
of a religious ceremony nor to minors consuming alcoholic beverages under the
direct supervision and approval of a parent of such minor in the privacy of the
minor's home. (Ord. 1023, 12-27-1979, eff. 1-1-1980; amd. 2020 Code)
5-13-12: RESTRICTIONS OF PERSONS OF NONAGE:
   (A)   Purchase or Consume Alcohol: No person under the age of twenty-one
(21) years shall purchase, attempt to purchase, or consume alcoholic liquor in
a licensed premises.
   (B)   Remaining on Property: Except as specifically set forth in this
Section, no person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall enter upon any
licensed premises, and no licensee shall allow any person under the age of
twenty-one (21) years to remain in, on or around the licensed premises.
   (C)   Loitering:
      1.   Persons sixteen (16) years of age or older are authorized to be
present on premises having a Class A, A-1, B, B-1 or N license for the purpose
of purchasing food and nonalcoholic beverages.
      2.   At premises having a Class F, F-1, F-2, G-1, or G-2 license, persons
under twenty-one (21) years of age are permitted for any lawful purpose, but
they shall not loiter on the premises or remain longer than necessary to
accomplish their lawful purpose. Notwithstanding the foregoing, with respect to
premises having a Class F-2 license, no person under the age of twenty-one (21)
years shall remain in or about the separated portion of the licensed premises
that is designated for on premises sale and consumption of beer and wine.
      3.   Persons under twenty-one (21) years of age are authorized to be
present on premises having a Class D or D-1 license for the limited purpose of
attending a private party in accordance with the following:
         a.   With respect to private parties during hours the licensed
premises is open to the public, the private party shall be held in a
segregated, self-contained party room without video gaming terminals and with
access to immediately adjacent bathroom facilities.
         b.   Additionally, if the licensed premises is closed to the public
for the duration of the private party, the private party may be held within the
entirety of the licensed premises and need not be limited to a segregated,
self-contained party room.
         c.   Such persons shall be present with a parent or guardian.
         d.   Such persons shall not be present on the licensed premises after
9:00 P.M.
   (D)   Parent or Guardian Present: Persons below the age of sixteen (16)
years are allowed to be present at premises having a Class A, A-1, B, B-1, C,
C-1, E, E-1, or N license provided they are present with a parent or guardian.
   (E)   Employees:
      1.   No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years may sell,
distribute, or pour alcoholic liquor or be employed by a licensee for the
purposes of tending bar and/or drawing, pouring, mixing, selling, delivering or
distributing any alcoholic liquor or for the purpose of selling alcoholic
liquor as a cashier, clerk or salesperson.
      2.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, for all licensed premises except
those having Class D, D-1 or I licenses, the following shall be permitted: (1)
persons who are at least eighteen (18) years of age may be employed as waiters
or waitresses for the purpose of serving alcoholic liquor in the ordinary
course of such employment; (2) persons who are at least eighteen (18) years of
age may be employed as cashiers in retail stores for the purpose of selling
alcoholic liquor in the ordinary course of such employment; and (3) persons who
are at least sixteen (16) years of age may be employed for the purposes of
cleaning, cooking or bussing provided they may not be employed on the premises
for any other purpose.
   (F)   Sitting at a Bar: Persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years may
not sit at a bar or primary place where alcoholic liquor is dispensed.
   (G)   Persons of Nonage Performing Live Music: Persons under the age of
twenty-one (21) years may be present on a licensed premises for the purpose of
performing live music from thirty (30) minutes in advance of such performance
until thirty (30) minutes after for the set up and removal of any incidental
equipment. At least one-half (1/2) of the participants in the performance must
be of age twenty-one (21) years or older.
   (H)   Class O Licenses: During those times the holder of a Class O License
is selling, delivering, transferring, distributing or giving away alcoholic
liquor pursuant to subsection
5-13-9(D) of this chapter, persons below the age of sixteen (16) years are
allowed to be present on the premises provided they are present with a parent
or guardian. During such times, persons between the ages of sixteen and twenty-
one (21) years are permitted to be present on the premises for any lawful
purpose, but they shall not loiter on the premises or remain longer than
necessary to accomplish their lawful purpose.
   (I)   Class P License: During those times the holder of a Class P License is
selling alcoholic liquor, persons below the age of sixteen (16) years are
allowed to be present on the premises provided they are present with a parent
or guardian. During such times, persons between the ages of sixteen (16) and
twenty-one (21) are permitted to be present on the premises for any lawful
purpose, but they shall not loiter on the premises or remain longer than
necessary to accomplish their lawful purpose.
   (J)   Class T License: During those times the holder of a Class T License is
selling alcoholic liquor, persons below the age of sixteen (16) years are
allowed to be present on the premises provided they are present with a parent
or guardian. During such times, persons between the ages of sixteen (16) and
twenty-one (21) are permitted to be present on the premises for any lawful
purpose, but they shall not loiter on the premises or remain longer than
necessary to accomplish their lawful purpose. (Ord. 1023, 12-27-1979, eff. 1-1-
1980; amd. Ord. 1095, 7-6-1981; Ord. 1211, 1-16-1984; Ord. 1263, 4-1-1985; Ord.
1611, 8-19-1991; Ord. 2207, 1-3-2000; Ord. 2344, 9-4-2001; Ord. 2713, 10-20-
2008; Ord. 3056, 9-5-2017; Ord. 3081, 2-20-2018; Ord. 3186, 2-18-2020; Ord.
3242, 9-7-2021; Ord. 3445, 4-7-2025; Ord. 3459, 6-23-2025)
5-13-13: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
The Mayor, Commissioners, Chief of Police and all members of the police force
may enter and inspect the premises of each licensee hereunder, or any adjacent
premises occupied or controlled by the licensee or his agent, at any time, and
they may take possession of and remove any intoxicating liquors found upon the
premises in violation of any provision of this Code and all licenses now in
force or hereafter issued under this chapter shall be subject to the
reservation of such authority and refusal to permit such action shall
constitute sufficient grounds for the immediate suspension or revocation of the
license by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner. (Ord. 715, 8-21-1972, eff.
11-1-1972)
5-13-14: GAMBLING:
   (A)   No licensee or his agents or employees shall permit any person upon
the licensed premises to play any games or participate in any activities for
money or other article of value or permit any person to bring on the premises
any wheel, machine, video gaming terminal, board, dice, slot machine,
punchboard, or other machine or device used for gambling, except video gaming
terminals licensed under the Illinois Video Gaming Act.
   (B)   No licensee or his agents or employees shall allow in or about the
licensed premises the sale or purchase wherein any part of the article or thing
received or to be received, either as to quantity or value, shall in any manner
depend upon any chance or hazard, whether by means of checks, cards, envelopes,
dice, punchboard or by any means whatever, except at those premises where the
licensee: 1) obtains applicable State license or permit to conduct or allow
others to conduct the game commonly known as "bingo", or 2) is a licensed
establishment permitting it to do so under the Illinois Video Gaming Act.
   (C)   Every clock, machine, slot machine, video gaming terminal, punchboard
or other machine or device for the reception of money on chance or upon the
action of which money is staked, hazarded, bet, won or lost is hereby declared
a gambling device and the same shall be seized, confiscated and destroyed by
the police of the City wherever found upon the licensed premises or place
controlled by the licensee, except video gaming terminals licensed and
registered under the Illinois Video Gaming Act.
   (D)   Any individual, partnership or corporation intending to place a video
gaming terminal in its establishment shall first file an application for a
video gaming licensed establishment permit, which application shall include the
following information:
      1.   The location for which the license is sought;
      2.   A copy of the written, signed lease or rental arrangement or other
written authority for use of the equipment at the location;
      3.   The number of video gaming terminals to be on the location for which
a permit is requested; and
      4.   Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00). The application fee shall be payable to the city by
certified check or money order.
   (E)   All permits issued hereunder shall be issued by the mayor and attested
by the city clerk and no permit shall issue until the application therefor
shall have been approved by the mayor.
   (F)   An annual permit fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each
video gaming terminal shall be paid in advance on or before April 1 of each
year. Each permit shall expire on April 30 of each year. There shall be no
proration of permit fees. The cost of such permit fees shall be shared equally
between the terminal operator and the applicable licensed establishment, as
provided by State law.
   (G)   Each licensee shall comply with all requirements of the Illinois video
gaming act, as amended from time to time.
   (H)   Under no circumstances shall any person under the age of twenty one
(21) years be permitted to use or play a video gaming terminal. Any licensee
who: 1) knowingly permits a person under the age of twenty one (21) years to
use or play a video gaming terminal or 2) fails to fully comply with the
provisions of the Illinois video gaming act or this section, shall have all
permits of the licensee suspended, terminated or revoked. All hearings to
determine whether said permit shall be suspended, terminated or revoked shall
be conducted by the mayor. All appeals from any decision of the mayor shall be
limited to a review of the official record of the proceedings of the mayor.
   (I)   With respect to premises having a Class F-2 license, all video gaming
terminals shall be located in the separated portion of the licensed premises
that is designated for on premises sale and consumption of beer and wine. The
video gaming terminals shall only be operated during the time designed in
section
5-13-9 for on premises sale and consumption of beer and wine. (Ord. 2879, 6-18-
2012; amd. Ord. 3186, 2-18-2020; Ord. 3261, 1-18-2022)
5-13-15: LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
   (A)   The mayor shall be the local liquor control commissioner and shall be
charged with the administration of the appropriate provisions of this chapter
and such other provisions of this code relating to alcoholic liquor as may be
enacted. He may appoint a person to assist him in the exercise of the powers
and the performance of the duties herein provided for the local liquor control
commissioner.
   (B)   The local liquor control commissioner, with the approval of a majority
of the council, may adopt rules and regulations for hearings to determine
whether any license should be suspended, terminated or revoked. (Ord. 715, 8-
21-1972, eff. 11-1-1972)
5-13-16: POWERS OF LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER:
   (A)   The local liquor control commissioner shall have all the powers as
provided by the laws of the state. The local liquor control commissioner may
suspend or revoke any license issued under this chapter and, in addition to a
suspension, may levy a fine not in the amounts set forth in subsection (C)
against the licensee for any of the following reasons:
      1.   The licensee has violated any of the laws of the United States
relating to the sale of alcoholic liquor, or any of the provisions of the
Illinois liquor control act, or any ordinance enacted by the city council.
      2.   The licensee has made a false statement as to any material fact on
its application for a liquor license.
      3.   The licensee has permitted an unlawful, disorderly or immoral
practice upon the licensed premises.
      4.   The licensee has refused to testify on oath as to all relevant and
material questions propounded to him at any hearing conducted by the mayor in
which a violation of any law of the United States, of the state of Illinois or
any ordinances of the city regulating the sale of alcoholic liquor has been
charged.
      5.   The state of Illinois liquor control commission has suspended or
revoked the license of the licensee.
      6.   The licensee has failed during the term for which the license is
issued to conform to any of the requirements for the initial issuance of a
license to sell alcoholic liquors.
      7.   Any agent or employee of the licensee has been found to have
committed any of the acts specified in subsections (A)1 through (A)6 of this
section.
   (B)   All hearings to determine whether any license shall be suspended,
terminated, or revoked, or whether a licensee shall be fined, shall be
conducted by the local liquor control commissioner. A certified court reporter
or certified shorthand reporter shall be present and shall prepare a certified
official record of the proceedings. All appeals from any decision of the local
liquor control commissioner shall be limited to a review of the official record
of the proceedings of the local liquor control commissioner. (Ord. 1920, 2-5-
1996)
   (C)   The fine imposed shall not exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for
a first violation within a twelve (12)-month period, one thousand five hundred
dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation within a twelve (12)-month period,
and two (thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for a third or subsequent
violation within a twelve (12)-month period. Each day that a violation
continues shall constitute a separate violation. Note more than fifteen
thousand dollars ($15,000.00) in fines under this subsection (C) may be imposed
against any licensee during the period of his or her license. (2020 Code)
5-13-17: FILING OF APPLICATION:
   (A)   In addition to any other requirements contained in an application for
liquor license, an application for a liquor license or renewal thereof shall
include the following information:
      1.   The location for which the license is sought;
      2.   A copy of the written, signed lease or rental arrangement or other
written authority for the use of the location if the applicant is not the owner
of said location;
      3.   Certificate of insurance showing evidence of dramshop insurance
coverage;
      4.   Certificate of insurance evidencing public liability insurance in an
amount not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) to any one person or
one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one accident. (Ord. 1341,
10-20-1986)
   (B)   Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of
seventy five dollars ($75.00) for each person applying for the license. The
application fee shall be payable to the city by certified check or money order.
(Ord. 2411, 10-7-2002)
   (C)   All licenses issued hereunder shall be issued by the mayor and
attested by the clerk under the corporate seal and no license shall issue until
the application therefor shall have been approved by the local liquor control
commissioner. All applications for licenses shall remain on file in the office
of the clerk to be listed in a record to be kept for this purpose. (Ord. 1341,
10-20-1986)
   (D)   Prior to the issuance or renewal of a license, the city building
official and the fire chief shall inspect and determine that the premises for
which the license is sought complies with the city's building and fire
regulations. The local liquor commissioner shall not issue or renew a license
until the city building official and the fire chief have certified that the
premises is in compliance with said regulations. (Ord. 2233, 4-3-2000)
5-13-18: TIME OF APPLICATION:
Application for a license or renewal of license shall be made to the mayor on
application blanks furnished to the city clerk. Such applications shall contain
sufficient information to enable the mayor to determine the eligibility of the
applicant for such license. Each application for renewal of a license issued
under this chapter shall be filed with the city clerk by April 1 of each year.
Each application for license or renewal shall be accompanied by the payment of
the annual fee prorated on the monthly basis from the date of filing the
application to May 1 next succeeding the filing of application. (Ord. 1095, 7-
6-1981; amd. Ord. 3208, 8-17-2020)
5-13-19: TEMPORARY LICENSE FOR THE ANNUAL CITY FAIR:
   (A)   Issuance Of License:
      1.   The local liquor control commissioner is hereby authorized to issue
two (2) licenses for the sale of "beer" and "wine" only as defined in this
chapter to a corporation chartered by the state as the corporation having as
its primary purpose the establishment, maintenance and operation of the
celebration commonly referred to as the Petunia Festival which has been
designated as the official city fair or, to the Dixon chamber of commerce for
the maintenance and operation of the celebration referred to in this
subsection.
      2.   Each license issued by this section shall be designated "city fair
license" and shall not exceed two (2) in number per calendar year. (Ord. 1611,
8-19-1991)
   (B)   Restrictions On Locations:
      1.   The licenses issued pursuant to this section may be issued for use
at the following premises:
         (a)   The premises owned by the Dixon park district provided said
premises are within the corporate limits of the city of Dixon and comply with
state statutes and local ordinances concerning location of authorized premises
with the exception of the ordinances on zoning;
         (b)   The premises owned by the city of Dixon and commonly known as
the Dixon Airport; or
         (c)   The parking lot owned by the city of Dixon and commonly known as
the Beanblossom Parking Lot. (Ord. 2788, 6-21-2010)
      2.   If the license authorized by subsection (B)1(a) of this section is
to be issued for the premises owned by the Dixon park district, such license
shall not be issued without the express written approval of the board of
commissioners of the Dixon park district as evidenced by the execution of a
valid lease to said premises by the licensee and the board of commissioners of
the Dixon park district.
      3.   If the license authorized by subsection (B)1(b) of this section is
to be issued for the premises known as the Dixon Airport, such license shall
not be issued without the express written approval of the Dixon airport board
as evidenced by the execution of a valid lease agreement to said premises
between the licensee and the Dixon airport board. (Ord. 1262, 4-1-1985)
      4.   The sale and consumption of beer and wine shall be confined to the
licensed premises.
      5.   All beer and wine sold shall be served only in disposable
containers. (Ord. 1431, 6-20-1988)
   (C)   Restriction On Period Of License For The Dixon Park District Premises:
The license issued for the premises owned by the Dixon park district shall be
issued for the limited period of the duration of the annual city fair as
determined by the liquor control commissioner in the issuance of the license
pursuant to subsection (A) of this section. (Ord. 1262, 4-1-1985)
   (D)   Restrictions On Time Of Sale At The Dixon Park District Premises: For
the days designated as the city fair, the sale of beer and wine shall be
authorized from twelve o'clock (12:00) noon to twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight.
After that time all persons shall vacate the licensed premises with the
exception of those employees and agents of licensee who are delegated to
operate, control, maintain, and clean the premises. All beer and wine shall be
removed from the licensed premises no later than one hour after the closing
time on the days when sale of beer and wine is authorized. (Ord. 2539, 7-1-
2005)
   (E)   Restrictions On City Owned Locations:
      1.   Restrictions On Dixon Airport Premises: The Dixon airport board
shall establish such rules, regulations and restrictions, including the date,
time, place, location and such other limitations as it deems necessary to
govern the use of the premises for which the license to be used at the Dixon
Airport is issued. Such rules, regulations, and restrictions shall be
consistent with all federal, state, and city laws, ordinances, rules and
regulations and shall be incorporated in the lease agreement provided for in
subsection (B)3 of this section.
      2.   Restrictions On Beanblossom Parking Lot: The license issued for the
premises known as the Beanblossom Parking Lot shall be issued for one day only,
shall authorize the sale of beer and wine only, shall not permit the sale of
beer and wine later than six o'clock (6:00) P.M., and shall be limited by such
other rules, regulations and restrictions as the local liquor control
commissioner deems necessary to govern the use of the premises. (Ord. 2788, 6-
21-2010)
   (F)   Restrictions On Persons Of Nonage:
      1.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) years shall purchase,
attempt to purchase, possess, or consume any beer or wine or other alcoholic
beverage upon either licensed premises or other premises controlled by the
licensee during the license period. (Ord. 1431, 6-20-1988)
      2.   Persons of any age are authorized to be present on the licensed
premises issued as a city fair license under subsection (B)1(a) of this
section. Persons under the age of twenty one (21) are authorized to be present
on the premises licensed under subsection (B)1(c) of this section during the
time for which the temporary license has been granted for the purpose of
purchasing food and nonalcoholic beverages only. (Ord. 2788, 6-21-2010)
   (G)   Removal From Premises: Any duly authorized representative of licensee
and any peace officer of the city, county of Lee or Dixon park district are
hereby empowered to remove any person from either licensed premises where such
officer or agent has probable cause to believe that such person may be under
the influence of intoxicating beverages.
   (H)   Fee: The total annual fee for licenses shall be one dollar ($1.00).
(Ord. 1262, 4-1-1985)
   (I)   Construction: It is the intent of the city council that this section
of the liquor code be liberally construed for the express purpose of fulfilling
the intent of allowing the sale of beer and wine only at the city fair under
the restrictive terms provided herein. Unless specifically excepted within this
section all of the terms and provisions of this code remain in full force and
effect. (Ord. 1431, 6-20-1988)
5-13-19-5: TEMPORARY LICENSE FOR SALE AT DIXON RIVERFRONT/HERITAGE CROSSING:
   (A)   Issuance Of License:
      1.   Subject to the terms and conditions of this chapter, the local
liquor control commissioner is hereby authorized to issue a license to any
person or entity for the sale, transfer or giving away of alcoholic liquor in
the public area commonly known as the Dixon Riverfront/Heritage Crossing.
      2.   Each application for a license under this chapter shall include a
certificate of insurance evidencing dramshop insurance and a certificate of
insurance evidencing public liability insurance in an amount not less than
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any one person or one hundred thousand
dollars ($100,000.00) for any one accident. Said certificates of insurance
shall name the city of Dixon, its city council, officers, agents and employees
of the city, and the riverfront commission as an additional insured.
   (B)   Restrictions On Locations:
      1.   The license issued pursuant to this section may be issued for use
only at the public area owned by the city of Dixon and commonly known as the
Dixon Riverfront/Heritage Crossing. (Ord. 2796, 10-4-2010)
      2.   Any license authorized under subsection (A) of this section shall
not be issued without the applicant first having entered into a lease agreement
with the Dixon riverfront commission (or its successor if the city has
authorized any other entity to assume the day to day operations and management
of the Dixon Riverfront/Heritage Crossing). (Ord. 2941, 6-2-2014)
      3.   The sale, transfer and consumption of alcoholic liquor shall be
confined to the area defined in said lease, and the defined area must be
enclosed by fencing. The location, composition, design and construction of the
fence shall be approved by the mayor. No alcoholic liquor may be removed from
the enclosed area.
      4.   If alcoholic liquor is to be sold from the proposed licensed area,
the application must be countersigned by the holder of a valid liquor license
issued under sections
5-13-3 and
5-13-5 of this chapter. In such case, the restrictions on the type of alcoholic
liquor that may be sold under the holder's liquor license shall be applicable.
(Ord. 2796, 10-4-2010)
   (C)   Restriction On Period And Time Of Sale Of License: The license issued
under subsection (A) of this section shall be issued for one day only and for a
length of time as determined by the local liquor control commissioner.
Provided, however, under no circumstances shall alcoholic liquor be sold,
delivered, transferred, distributed or given away in the licensed area at times
other than as provided for in section
5-13-9 of this chapter or on Sundays from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to eleven
o'clock (11:00) P.M. (Ord. 2941, 6-2-2014)
   (D)   Restrictions On Sale Or Transfer:
      1.   No person under the age of twenty one (21) shall purchase, attempt
to purchase, possess or consume any alcoholic liquor upon the licensed area.
      2.   No alcoholic liquor served in an open container may be removed from
the licensed area.
      3.   No sales or dispensing of alcoholic liquor may be made from the
licensed area to any person upon an adjoining property, public street, sidewalk
or alley.
      4.   Any license granted pursuant to this chapter may contain such other
restrictions as the local liquor control commissioner deems warranted to
protect the use and enjoyment of the area and of adjacent properties.
      5.   Adequate security must be provided by applicant. (Ord. 2796, 10-4-
2010)
   (E)   Restriction Of Riverfront Commission: The Dixon riverfront commission
(or its successor if the city has authorized any other entity to assume the day
to day operations and management of the Dixon Riverfront/Heritage Crossing)
shall establish rules, regulations, and restrictions governing use of the area
to be licensed. (Ord. 2941, 6-2-2014)
   (F)   Fee: The total fee for the license shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00).
   (G)   Violation: Any violation of this chapter shall also constitute grounds
for the suspension or revocation of the liquor license if the applicant is also
a license holder under this chapter.
   (H)   Suspension And Termination: The mayor or the chief of police shall
have the authority to immediately terminate or revoke the license granted under
this section if the mayor or the chief of police believes such action is
necessary to prohibit the disturbing the peace of others, to terminate
offensive conduct, or to protect the health, safety and welfare of those
present in the licensed area. (Ord. 2796, 10-4-2010)
5-13-20: CONDUCT IN OR UPON LICENSED PREMISES:
   (A)   Prohibited Conduct:
      1.   The following kinds of conduct on premises in the city of Dixon
licensed to sell alcoholic liquor are prohibited:
         (a)   The performance of acts or simulated acts of sexual intercourse,
masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual
acts which are prohibited by law;
         (b)   The actual or simulated touching, caressing or fondling on the
breast, buttocks, anus, or genitals;
         (c)   The actual or simulated displaying of the breast, pubic hair,
anus, vulva or genitals;
         (d)   The displaying of films or pictures depicting acts, a live
performance of which is prohibited by subsection (A)1(a), (A)1(b), or (A)1(c)
of this section.
         (e)   The permitting by a licensee, his agent or employee of any
person to remain in or upon the licensed premises who exposes to public view
any portion of his or her genitals or anus;
         (f)   The allowance by a licensee, his agent, or employee of any
person to perform, present, participate or direct in or upon the licensed
premises any play or dance or other performance which acts are prohibited by
subsection (A)1(a), (A)1(b) or (A)1(c) of this section. (Ord. 901, 5-16-1977)
   (B)   Tumultuous Conduct: No person shall disturb, tend to disturb, or aid
in disturbing the peace of others by violent, tumultuous, offensive or
obstreperous conduct, and no person shall knowingly permit such conduct upon
any premises owned or possessed by him or under his control and licensed to
sell alcoholic liquor. All liquor licensees shall aid city police to quell the
aforesaid activities by reporting said conduct as soon as possible and shall
cooperate with city police in the investigation and prosecution of violators of
this title. (Ord. 1382, 9-21-1987)
   (C)   Suspension And Revocation Of Liquor License: If, at any time, after
the granting of a liquor license, any licensee shall have violated any of the
provisions of this code (and in particular, but not by way of limitation, any
provision of this chapter) or any statute of the state (and in particular, but
not by way of limitation, the liquor control act) in the conducting of the
licensee's business, the mayor may suspend or revoke the license therefor.
   (D)   Acts Of Agents Or Employees; Liability Of Licensee: Every act or
omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of the provisions
of this code or any of the provisions of the liquor control act by any officer,
director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee, shall be deemed
and held to be the act of such licensee, and said licensee shall be punishable
in the same manner as if said act or omission had been done or omitted by the
licensee. (Ord. 1463, 12-19-1988)
5-13-21: TRANSPORTING IN MOTOR VEHICLES:
   (A)   Except as provided in paragraph (C) and in Sections 6-6.5 and 6-33 of
the Liquor Control Act of 1934, no driver may transport, carry, possess or have
any alcoholic liquor within the passenger area of any motor vehicle upon any
public way within the city except in the original container and with the seal
unbroken and except for the transport and delivery of cocktails and mixed
drinks by employees of a retail licensee in compliance with the provisions of
section
5-13-27.
   (B)   Except as provided in paragraph (C) and in Sections 6-6.5 and 6-33 of
the Liquor Control Act of 1934, no passenger may carry, possess or have any
alcoholic liquor within any passenger area of any motor vehicle upon any public
way within the city except in the original container and with the seal
unbroken.
   (C)   This section shall not apply to the passengers in a limousine when it
is being used for purposes for which a limousine is ordinarily used, the
passengers on a chartered bus when it is being used for purposes for which
chartered buses are ordinarily used or on a motor home or mini motor home as
defined in Section 1-145.01 of the Illinois Vehicle Code. However, the driver
of any such vehicle is prohibited from consuming or having any alcoholic liquor
in or about the driver's area. Any evidence of alcoholic consumption by the
driver shall be prima facie evidence of such driver's failure to obey this
section. (Ord. 1095, 7-6-1981; amd. Ord. 3200, 6-15-2020; 2020 Code)
5-13-22: OUTDOOR SALES AND SEATING:
   (A)   Prohibited Sales: Except as otherwise provided in this section, no
outdoor sales of alcoholic liquor shall be carried on in connection with the
premises for which a license has been granted for the sale of alcoholic liquor
for consumption upon property contiguous to the licensed premises. (Ord. 2545,
8-1-2005)
   (B)   Outdoor Sales And Seating Permit: Each year the holder of a Class A,
A-1, B, B-1, D, or D-1 license may apply for an outdoor sales and seating
permit, or renewal thereof, to sell alcoholic liquor outside of the permanent
structure of the licensed premises for which the applicant's license has been
issued. The granting of an outdoor sales and seating permit is subject to the
following terms and conditions: (Ord. 2883, 7-16-2012)
      1.   The area in which such sales are conducted must be enclosed and
contiguous to and accessible only from the building where the sale of alcoholic
liquor is otherwise permitted.
      2.   Ingress and egress to the outdoor sales area must be from the
permanent structure only and no access shall be permitted from the street,
sidewalk or adjoining property unless approved by the Mayor at the time the
outdoor sales and seating permit is granted. (Ord. 2545, 8-1-2005)
      3.   The outdoor sales area shall be enclosed by fencing not less than
five feet (5') in height. The location, composition, design and construction of
the fence shall be approved by the Mayor and the Building Official. (Ord. 2883,
7-16-2012)
      4.   Except as provided in subsection (B)13 of this section, no music of
any kind may be played or broadcasted from the outdoor sales area after ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M. No music may be played or broadcasted within the adjacent
licensed premises which is of such volume so as to disturb the neighborhood in
any manner. (Ord. 2548, 10-3-2005)
      5.   No sales or dispensing of alcoholic liquor may be made from the
outdoor sales area to any person upon adjoining property, public street,
sidewalk or alley.
      6.   No alcoholic liquor served in an open container may be removed from
the outdoor sales area or the licensed premises.
      7.   Adequate security must be provided by the licensee. (Ord. 2545, 8-1-
2005)
      8.   The outdoor sales and seating permit shall be effective only from
May 1 to April 30 of each year. Applications for renewal of an outdoor sales
and seating permit must be filed on an annual basis. (Ord. 2548, 10-3-2005)
      9.   No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, delivered, transferred,
distributed or given away in the outdoor sales area by anyone except:
         (a)   Monday through Saturday from eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to one
o'clock (1:00) A.M. of the following day.
         (b)   On Sundays from eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:
00) P.M.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, stricter hours of operation may be established
by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner as part of the outdoor sales and
seating permit approval process.
      10.   All patrons of the outdoor area shall vacate the outdoor area no
later than thirty (30) minutes following the time specified in subsection (B)9
of this section.
      11.   No outdoor sales and seating permit shall be granted if the
proposed area is located within one hundred twenty feet (120') of residentially
zoned property, a school, or a church, as measured in a straight line from the
nearest property boundary of the residentially zoned property, school or
church. (Ord. 2545, 8-1-2005)
      12.   No outdoor sales and seating permit shall be granted unless the
Finance Director shall certify that there are no outstanding fines, fees, taxes
or other charges due and owing to the City by the owners of the real property
on which the proposed area is located or by the applicant. (Ord. 2545, 8-1-
2005; amd. Ord. 2887, 8-20-2012)
      13.   Upon approval of the application required by this subsection and
payment of a twenty five dollar ($25.00) fee to the City, a temporary permit
may be issued to a permit holder to extend the time allowed for playing or
broadcasting music in the outdoor sales area from ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. to
either eleven thirty o'clock (11:30) P.M. or twelve thirty o'clock (12:30)
A.M., as may be approved by the Local Liquor Commissioner. Each temporary
permit issued hereunder shall be limited to a single outdoor event.
Applications shall be made with the Local Liquor Commissioner not less than
three (3) days prior to the date of the intended outdoor event. The applicant
shall include in the application the location and the specific time and date
for which the temporary permit is requested. No temporary permit shall issue
until the application therefor shall have been approved by the Local Liquor
Commissioner. All applications shall remain on file in the Office of the Clerk
to be listed in a record to be kept for this purpose. Holders of a temporary
permit shall not allow any unreasonably loud or raucous use or operation of a
loudspeaker, amplifier, public address system or other device, including
musical instruments, for producing or reproducing sound. Sound measured from
any location within five feet (5') of the boundary line of the property for
which the temporary permit is issued with a decibel meter set to A-weight that
exceeds ninety (90) decibels shall be deemed unreasonably loud and raucous and
shall subject the holder of the temporary permit to violation under subsection
(E) of this section. (Ord. 3029, 2-21-2017)
   (C)   Application:
      1.   Application for an outdoor sales and seating permit or renewal
thereof shall be submitted to the Mayor and shall include the following:
         (a)   A detailed drawing or sketch including the dimensions of the
proposed outdoor area where the outdoor sales will occur.
         (b)   The location of the tables and chairs to be used.
         (c)   The type of fencing materials and dimensions.
         (d)   The number of seats that will be in the outdoor area.
         (e)   A one hundred dollar ($100.00) nonrefundable filing fee.
         (f)   Proof of dramshop insurance coverage on the outdoor sales area,
consisting of a certificate of insurance including the outdoor sales area.
      2.   All applications shall be reviewed by the City Building Department
to determine compliance with the requirements of this chapter and with the City
building code. No outdoor sales and seating permit shall be issued or renewed
until the City Building Official has certified that the outdoor sales area is
in compliance with said requirements.
      3.   An outdoor sales and seating permit granted herein may contain such
other conditions as the Local Liquor Control Commissioner deems warranted to
protect the use and enjoyment of adjacent properties.
      4.   The Mayor shall be the approving authority.
   (D)   Display: The outdoor sales and seating permit shall be displayed in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
   (E)   Violation:
      1.   Any outdoor sales and seating permit issued pursuant to this section
may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter or any of the
provisions of this Code.
      2.   Any suspension of violation shall be conducted pursuant to this
chapter.
      3.   Any violation of this section shall also constitute grounds for the
suspension or revocation of the liquor license for the adjacent premises. (Ord.
2545, 8-1-2005)
5-13-23: OUTDOOR SIDEWALK CAFE:
   (A)   Outdoor Sidewalk Cafe Permit:
      1.   An outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be required to operate an
outdoor sidewalk cafe. An "outdoor sidewalk cafe" shall mean a portion of an
immobile retail food establishment located on a public right-of-way directly
adjacent to the retail food establishment. The granting of an outdoor sidewalk
cafe permit shall be subject to the terms and conditions set forth in
subsection (B) of this section.
      2.   The permit area shall be that portion of the public right- of-way as
delineated and approved on the permit application and restricted to a portion
of the right-of-way which is located between the curb line on the lateral line
of the street and the adjacent property line, excluding any area required for
use by pedestrians.
   (B)   Terms And Conditions: The granting of an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit
shall be subject to the following terms and conditions:
      1.   Proof that the applicant holds a valid retail food establishment
license issued to the establishment that will provide food for the outdoor
sidewalk cafe.
      2.   There shall be no live entertainment, amplified music, or
mechanically amplified sound of any nature whatsoever within the permit area.
      3.   The permit shall be effective only from May 1 to October 31 of each
year. Applications for renewal of an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be
filed on an annual basis.
      4.   Stoves, ovens, hot plates, beverage coolers and similar restaurant
equipment shall not be placed within the permit area.
      5.   No privately owned trash cans or electrical outlets shall be placed
within the permit area. The permittee shall be solely responsible for
maintaining the permit area in a clean and sanitary condition. The permittee
shall immediately remove trash or debris resulting from the operation of the
outdoor sidewalk cafe and shall collect and properly dispose of such debris as
may be scattered from the permit area by patrons or weather conditions.
      6.   The permit area and adjoining sidewalks shall remain clear of
litter, food scraps and soiled dishes at all times. Sidewalks and flooring
areas must be cleaned daily, including adjacent sidewalk areas.
      7.   The outdoor sidewalk cafe shall not open before eleven o'clock (11:
00) A.M. All patrons of the outdoor sidewalk cafe shall vacate the permit area
no later than ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
      8.   No alcoholic beverages may be served unless the outdoor sidewalk
cafe permit was issued under subsection (D) of this section. (Ord. 2644, 6-18-
2007)
      9.   No permit shall be granted unless the Finance Director certifies
that there are no outstanding fines, fees, taxes or other charges due and owing
to the City by the applicant or by the owners of the real property on which the
proposed area is located. (Ord. 2644, 6-18-2007; amd. Ord. 2887, 8-20-2012)
   (C)   Prohibited Sales: Except as otherwise provided in subsection (D) of
this section, the outdoor sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption upon public
sidewalks contiguous to a licensed premises is prohibited. (Ord. 2644, 6-18-
2007)
   (D)   Outdoor Sidewalk Cafe Permit Allowing The Sale Or Permitting The
Consumption Of Alcoholic Liquor: Each holder of a Class A, A-1, B, B-1, D, or
D-1 license may apply for an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit, or renewal thereof,
to sell alcoholic liquor outside on the public sidewalk immediately adjacent to
the permanent structure of the licensed premises for which the applicant's
license has been issued, and each holder of a Class N license may apply for an
outdoor sidewalk cafe permit, or renewal thereof, to permit consumption of beer
or wine only brought onto the premises by a patron for personal consumption
while being served a meal in the establishment. In addition to the terms and
conditions contained in subsection (B) of this section, the granting of an
outdoor sidewalk cafe permit to the holder of a liquor license is also subject
to the following terms and conditions: (Ord. 2713, 10-20-2008)
      1.   The applicant must have a valid liquor license issued under this
Code and must provide food service in the licensed area.
      2.   All ingress and egress to the outdoor sales area from the sidewalk
must be approved by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner at the time the
outdoor sidewalk cafe permit is granted.
      3.   The area in which such sales are conducted must be enclosed and
contiguous to the building where the sale of alcoholic liquor is otherwise
permitted. The sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages in the permit area
shall be restricted by the liquor license governing the applicant.
      4.   The outdoor sales area shall be enclosed by a rope, fence or other
similar barrier at least thirty six inches (36") in height and have an access
opening within the barrier of not less than forty four inches (44") in width.
The location, composition, design and construction of the fence shall be
approved by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner and the Building Official.
      5.   No sales or dispensing of alcoholic liquor may be made from the
permit area to any person upon adjoining property, public street, sidewalk or
alley.
      6.   No alcoholic liquor served in an open container may be removed from
the permit area or the licensed premises. (Ord. 2644, 6-18-2007)
      7.   Beer, wine, or other alcoholic beverages may be served or consumed
at an outdoor sidewalk cafe provided that the alcoholic beverage is purchased
from the outdoor sidewalk cafe, the purchaser is seated at a table, and the
alcoholic beverage is served and consumed with food ordered from a menu,
prepared and served for pay by the outdoor sidewalk cafe permittee. Provided,
however, the origin, consumption, and types of alcoholic beverages and
containers permitted at an outdoor sidewalk cafe for holders of Class N
licenses are governed by subsection
 5-13-5(S) of this chapter. (Ord. 2732, 4-6-2009)
      8.   No patron may have more than one (1) alcoholic drink at any one (1)
time.
      9.   All alcoholic beverages must be served in plastic or glass
containers or aluminum cans. No bottles, taps, kegs, coolers or other alcoholic
beverage storage devices shall be allowed in the permit area.
      10.   Adequate security must be provided by the licensee.
      11.   No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, delivered, transferred,
distributed or given away in the outdoor sales area after nine thirty o'clock
(9:30) P.M. All patrons shall vacate the permit area no later than ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M.
      12.   Stricter hours of operation and such other conditions as the local
liquor control commissioner deems necessary to protect the use and enjoyment of
adjacent properties may be required by the local liquor control commissioner as
a condition of granting an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit which allows the sale
of alcoholic liquor as permitted under this subsection (D).
   (E)   Permit Application:
      1.   Application for an outdoor sidewalk cafe permit or renewal thereof
shall be submitted to the mayor and shall include the following:
         (a)   A detailed drawing or sketch including the dimensions of the
proposed outdoor area where the outdoor sales will occur with measurements
including a representation showing that at least five feet (5') of unobstructed
sidewalk space will remain for pedestrians.
         (b)   The location and number of tables and chairs to be used. The
application shall state the type of furniture that will be used.
         (c)   The type of fencing materials and dimensions.
         (d)   A nonrefundable filing fee in an amount as may be established
from time to time by the mayor.
         (e)   A certificate of insurance evidencing commercial general
liability insurance with limits of not less than five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) per occurrence, and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) in the
aggregate combined single limit, for bodily injury, personal injury and
property damage liability. The city of Dixon shall be named as an additional
insured on a primary, noncontributory basis for any liability arising directly
or indirectly from the operations of an outdoor sidewalk cafe and shall provide
that the policy shall not terminate or be canceled prior to the expiration date
without thirty (30) days' advance written notice to the city. Proof of such
insurance, issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state
of Illinois, shall be delivered prior to the issuance of an outdoor sidewalk
cafe permit.
         (f)   Outdoor sidewalk cafes that are authorized to sell alcoholic
beverages must also provide proof of dramshop insurance coverage on the permit
area.
         (g)   The application shall demonstrate that the outdoor sidewalk cafe
will not unreasonably interfere with pedestrian flow, access to the building
entrances, pedestrian and traffic safety, and the aesthetic quality of the
surrounding area.
         (h)   Applicants having an A or A-1 liquor license shall provide proof
that the applicant has a full service, fully equipped kitchen intended,
designed and used in the preparation of meals, other than only a counter with a
hot plate, microwave oven or similar warming device.
      2.   All applications shall be reviewed by the city building department
to determine compliance with the requirements of this chapter and with the city
building code. No outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be issued or renewed until
the city building official has certified that the outdoor sales area is in
compliance with said requirements.
      3.   The following standards shall be applicable within the permit area:
         (a)   All barrier material must be maintained in good visual
appearance.
         (b)   All furniture other than tables, chairs and umbrellas is
prohibited. Furniture and fixtures must not be secured to street signs,
hydrants or any other street infrastructure. Tables and chairs are not
permitted to be white plastic. All chairs used within a particular permit area
must match each other by being of visually similar design, construction and
color. Umbrellas must be contained within the permit area; all advertisements
on umbrellas must be approved by the city building official.
         (c)   Sectional fencing must be of metal or wood construction. Such
fencing must be portable and freestanding without any permanent or temporary
attachment to the sidewalks. Fabric inserts of any size are not permitted. The
use of chainlink, cyclone fencing, chicken wire or similar appurtenances is
prohibited.
      4.   The mayor shall be the approving authority of all permit requests.
Any permit for an outdoor sidewalk cafe may contain such conditions as the
mayor, or his designee, deems warranted to protect the use for adjacent right
of way for its intended purpose and to otherwise carry out the purpose and
intent of this section and this code.
      5.   The mayor shall have the authority to promulgate regulations to
carry out the purpose of this section, including, without limitation,
regulations governing location, arrangement, design, types of food and
beverages, landscaping and other aesthetic components, the safety of
pedestrians and auto traffic, the prevention of an excessive number of outdoor
sidewalk cafes, and any other matter pertaining to this section. All permittees
shall comply with the regulations promulgated pursuant to this section which
shall have the full force and effect of a city ordinance.
      6.   An outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be for the exclusive use of
the licensed retail food establishment stated on the application. Sharing or
joint use of the outdoor sidewalk cafe location by more than one retail food
establishment shall not be permitted.
   (F)   Display: The outdoor sidewalk cafe permit shall be displayed in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
   (G)   Termination: To the extent that a permit area is needed by the city
for sidewalk purposes, or any other public purpose, the mayor may immediately
terminate the permit and assume full possession and control of the permit area.
In such an event, the city shall be authorized to remove all furniture and
other objects of the permittee from the permit area.
   (H)   Violation:
      1.   Any outdoor sidewalk cafe permit issued pursuant to this section may
be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter or any of the
provisions of this code.
      2.   Any suspension for violation shall be conducted pursuant to this
chapter.
      3.   Any violation of this section shall also constitute grounds for the
suspension or revocation of the liquor license of the applicant. (Ord. 2644, 6-
18-2007)
5-13-24: DIXON WELCOME CENTER:
   (A)   The city council does hereby authorize and permit the sale of wine
only for consumption off the premises by the tourism development board from the
property having a common address of 106 W. River Street, Dixon, Illinois, and
known as the Dixon Welcome Center.
   (B)   The sale of said wine is permitted during the following periods of
time on the following days:
      1.   Mondays through Saturdays from ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. to ten
o'clock (10:00) P.M.; and
      2.   Sundays from twelve o'clock (12:00) noon to five o'clock (5:00) P.M.
   (C)   The welcome center may be open to the public during other times but
shall not be permitted to sell wine other than the times set forth in
subsection (B) of this section.
   (D)   The sale of wine to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years
is expressly prohibited.
   (E)   Only persons twenty one (21) years of age or older may sell said wine
from the premises.
   (F)   The city clerk is hereby authorized and directed to issue a liquor
license designated as a "city license" to the tourism development board for the
premises located at 106 W. River Street, Dixon, Illinois, and is further
authorized and directed to apply for a state liquor license with the Illinois
liquor commission for said premises. (Ord. 2749, 7-20-2009)
5-13-25: SALES BY LICENSEES AT LOCATIONS OTHER THAN LICENSED PREMISES:
   (A)   Temporary License: Notwithstanding any other provision of this
chapter, either: 1) a holder of a class A, A-1, B, B-1, C, C-1, D or D-
1 license, or 2) the holder of a license equivalent or substantially equivalent
to the foregoing issued by Lee County and whose licensed premises are connected
to city water or sewer service, may be issued a temporary license for sales of
alcoholic beverages at off premises locations in conjunction with a religious,
charitable, civic, educational or literary event to be held within the
corporate limits of the city. Applications for such temporary license shall be
made with the mayor at least fourteen (14) days prior to the date of the
intended sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages and shall be made in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2974, 8-17-2015)
   (B)   Provisions: A temporary license issued under this section may be
issued for a period not to exceed one day and shall be subject to the
provisions of sections
5-13-8,
5-13-9, and
5-13-10 of this chapter regarding the locations and time of sale, unless the
Liquor Commissioner further restricts the location and/or time of sale. Sunday
sales may be permitted under such license.
   (C)   Application: In addition to any other requirements contained in an
application for a liquor license, the applicant shall include the following
information:
      1.   A description of the location and premises for which the license is
sought;
      2.   A copy of an agreement or other written authority for the licensee's
use of the location if the applicant is not the owner of the location;
      3.   A statement setting forth the purpose for the issuance of said
license, to include a description of the intended function or event;
      4.   A statement setting forth the applicant's arrangements for security
and crowd control;
      5.   A certificate of insurance showing evidence of dramshop and
liability insurance coverage for the premises for which the temporary license
is requested;
      6.   A request for a specific time and date for the term of said license.
(Ord. 2809, 1-3-2011)
   (D)   Fees: The fee for such a temporary license shall be fifty dollars
($50.00) for each calendar day or part thereof for which the license is issued
and shall be paid in full at the time that the license is issued.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, for events where less than fifty dollars
($50.00) in retail cost of alcoholic beverages are to be sold, the fee shall be
five dollars ($5.00) for each calendar day or part thereof for which the
license is issued. (Ord. 2986, 12-21-2015)
   (E)   Underage Persons: Persons under the age of twenty one (21) are
permitted to be present on the premises during the time for which the temporary
license has been granted for the purpose of purchasing food or nonalcoholic
beverages only and only if accompanied by a parent or guardian.
   (F)   Display: The license issued under this section shall be prominently
displayed. (Ord. 2809, 1-3-2011)
5-13-26: DIXON THEATRE EVENT VENUE:
   (A)   Temporary License: The holder of a Class A, A-1, B, B-1, C, C-1, D or
D-1 license may be issued a temporary license for the sales of alcoholic
beverages at the Dixon Theatre. Application for such temporary license shall be
made with the Mayor at least fourteen (14) days prior to the date or dates of
the intended sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages and shall be made in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2811, 1-18-2011)
   (B)   Provisions: A temporary license for any such licensee for the sale or
distribution of alcoholic beverages at the Dixon Theatre may be issued for a
period not to exceed four (4) days and shall be subject to the provisions of
sections
5-13-9 and
5-13-10 of this chapter regarding such sales or distributions unless the Liquor
Commissioner further restricts the time of sale. Such temporary license may be
issued to any such licensee for the Dixon Theatre notwithstanding the
provisions of subsection
5-13-8(A) of this chapter restricting the sale and retail of any alcoholic
liquor within one hundred feet (100') of certain specified institutions. Sunday
sales may be permitted under a license issued pursuant to the terms of this
chapter. No such temporary license may be issued under this section except in
conjunction with functions or events to be held at the Dixon Theatre. (Ord.
3058, 9-18-2017)
   (C)   Application: In addition to any other requirements contained in an
application for a liquor license, the applicant shall include the following
information:
      1.   A copy of an agreement, lease, or other written authority from the
Dixon Theatre for the licensee's use of the Dixon Theatre; (Ord. 2811, 1-18-
2011)
      2.   A statement describing the purpose for the issuance of said license,
to include a description of the intended functions or events; (Ord. 3058, 9-18-
2017)
      3.   A statement setting forth the applicant's arrangements for security
and crowd control;
      4.   A certificate of insurance showing dramshop and liability insurance
for the Dixon Theatre incident to the issuance of the temporary license; (Ord.
2811, 1-18-2011)
      5.   The specific times and dates for the term of said license. (Ord.
3058, 9-18-2017)
   (D)   Display: The license under this section shall be prominently displayed
on site at the Dixon Theatre during the term of the license. (Ord. 2811, 1-18-
2011)
5-13-27: DELIVERY AND CARRY OUT OF MIXED DRINKS:
   (A)   Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this
section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (a),
except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
 
                         Any beverage obtained by combining ingredients
                         alcoholic in nature, whether brewed, fermented, or
COCKTAIL OR MIXED DRINK: distilled, with ingredients non-alcoholic in nature,
                         such as fruit juice, lemonade, cream, or a carbonated
                         beverage.
                         A container that is filled, sealed, and secured by a
ORIGINAL CONTAINER:      retail licensee's employee at the retail licensee's
                         location with a tamper-evident lid or cap.
RETAIL LICENSEE:         Any establishment holding a valid Class A, A-1, C, C-
                         1, D, or D-1 liquor license issued by the city.
                         A rigid container that contains a mixed drink, is new,
                         has never been used, has a secured lid or cap designed
                         to prevent consumption without removal of the lid or
SEALED CONTAINER:        cap, and is tamper-evident. "Sealed container" does
                         not include a container with a lid with sipping holes
                         or openings for straw or a container made of plastic,
                         paper, or polystyrene foam.
                         A lid or cap that has been sealed with tamper-evident
TAMPER-EVIDENT:          covers, including, but not limited to, wax dip or heat
                         shrink wrap.
 
   (B)   Sale Of Mixed Drinks: A cocktail or mixed drink placed in a sealed
container by a retail licensee at the retail licensee's location may be
transferred and sold for off-premises consumption if the following requirements
are met:
      1.   The cocktail is transferred within the licensed premises, by a
curbside pickup, or by delivery by an employee of the retail licensee who:
         (a)   Has been trained in accordance with the provisions of Section 6-
27.1 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act (235 ILCS 5/6-27.1);
         (b)   Is at least twenty-one (21) years of age; and
         (c)   Upon delivery, verifies the age of the person to whom the
cocktail is being delivered;
      2.   If the employee delivering the cocktail is not able to safely verify
a person's age or level of intoxication upon delivery, the employee shall
cancel the sale of alcohol and return the product to the retail licensee;
      3.   The sealed container is placed in the trunk of the vehicle or if
there is no trunk, in the vehicle's rear compartment that is not readily
accessible to the passenger area;
      4.   The sealed container shall be affixed with a label or tag that
contains the following information:
         (a)   The cocktail or mixed drink ingredients, type, and name of
alcohol;
         (b)   The name, license number, and address of the retail licensee
that filled the original container and sold the product and the date sold;
         (c)   The volume of the cocktail or mixed drink in the sealed
container; and
         (d)   The sealed container was filled less than seven (7) days before
the date of sale.
   (C)   Compliance With Executive Orders: If there is an executive order of
the Governor of the State of Illinois in effect during a disaster, the employee
delivering the mixed drink or cocktail must comply with any requirements of
that executive order, including, but not limited to, wearing gloves and a mask
and maintaining distancing requirements when interacting with the public.
   (D)   Limitations: Cocktails or mixed drinks may not be sold or delivered,
and the authorizations of this section do not permit such sale or delivery if:
      1.   A third party not employed by the retail licensee delivers the
cocktail or mixed drink;
      2.   A container of a mixed drink or cocktail is not tamper-evident and
sealed;
      3.   A container of a mixed drink or cocktail is to be transported in the
passenger area of a vehicle;
      4.   A mixed drink or cocktail is delivered by a person or to a person
who is under the age of twenty-one (21); or
      5.   The person delivering a mixed drink or cocktail fails to verify the
age of the person to whom the mixed drink or cocktail is being delivered.
   (E)   Violations: Any violations of this section shall be subject to any
applicable penalties, including, but not limited to, the penalties specified
under Section 11-502 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-1 et. seq.) and
the penalties contained within this chapter.
   (F)   This section shall be effective beginning on and after June 1, 2020
and shall expire on June 1, 2021 unless further extended by ordinance approved
by the city council and mayor. (Ord. 3200, 6-15-2020)
CHAPTER 14
AMUSEMENTS

CHAPTER 15
MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES
SECTION:
5-15-1: Definitions

5-15-5: Unobstructed View

5-15-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall be an operator, an operator of an amusement center, or a
distributor without first having obtained the license for that purpose. No
operator or operator of an amusement center shall set up a mechanical amusement
device belonging to such person unless a license has been issued for the number
of devices authorized to be placed upon the person's property pursuant to
section
5-15-4 of this chapter. No operator or operator of an amusement center shall
set up a mechanical amusement device belonging to a licensed distributor
unless: a) a license is first issued to a distributor, and b) a license has
been issued for the number of devices authorized to be placed upon the
operator's or the operator of an amusement center's property pursuant to
section
5-15-4 of this chapter. The license issued hereunder shall be nontransferable
and nonassignable and shall be prominently displayed upon the premises where
the machines are operated. (Ord. 1192, 8-1-1983; amd. Ord. 3354, 6-5-2023)
5-15-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license shall be made in writing to the mayor, and said
application shall set forth the full name of the applicant, the address, the
location and character of the building or place where the mechanical amusement
devices are to be located, whether such devices belong to the operator or the
operator of an amusement center or to a distributor, and the number of such
devices. Any application for a license under this chapter shall include the
names and addresses of all partners, if the proposed licensee is a partnership,
and shall include the names and addresses of all owners, officers and directors
if such proposed licensee is a limited liability company, corporation or other
entity. Upon receipt of the application accompanied by the proper license fee
as herein provided, the chief of police shall investigate the character of the
applicant, the premises in which it is proposed to carry on the business of the
applicant, and the type of machine to be used. The chief of police shall then
transmit the results of his or her investigation to the mayor, together with
his or her recommendation as to the granting or denial of such license.
Additionally, prior to the issuance of any license, the city building official
and the fire chief shall inspect and determine that any premises for which the
license is sought complies with the city's building and fire codes and
regulations. The mayor shall not issue a license until the city building
official and the fire chief have certified that the premises is in compliance
with said codes and regulations. (Ord. 1133, 4-30-1982; amd. Ord. 3354, 6-5-
2023)
5-15-4: LICENSE
The city clerk, upon the mayor's approval of the application, shall issue a
license stating the number of mechanical amusement devices licensed hereunder
and authorized to be distributed within the municipal limits by a distributor
annually to the distributor. The city clerk, upon the mayor's approval of the
application, shall issue a license stating the number of mechanical amusement
